summary: Paul Merson restarted a Twitter row with Andros Townsend after Townsend was brought on in the 83rd minute of Tottenham’s 0-0 draw with Burnley, tweeting “did you miss the coach? #RubberDub #7minutes.” The spat followed Merson’s earlier Sky Sports column suggesting Townsend shouldn’t have been in the England squad, a view undermined when Townsend scored a stunning equaliser for England in a 1-1 friendly with Italy; Merson admitted he was wrong and praised the goal, while Townsend replied on Twitter mocking Merson’s initial criticism. Despite apparent reconciliation after the international goal, Merson again taunted Townsend following the Burnley draw.

Chelsea have made a formal summer offer for 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, club president Naoki Ogane said; if the move goes ahead he would be loaned to Chelsea’s Dutch partner Vitesse Arnhem next season and, if signed, would be Chelsea’s first Japanese player. Muto, who graduated from Keio University with an economics degree two weeks ago, has 37 club appearances with 16 goals (including 13 in his debut season) and 11 caps, 1 goal, for Japan; a £4m fee has been reported though Muto has not decided whether to join and says he is honored by the bid. Ogane denied Chelsea’s interest is linked to Chelsea’s recent £200m, five-year shirt-sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber, which may prompt a two-week pre-season tour of Japan.

A large-scale Finnish study published in Pediatrics found that infants given antibiotics in the first six months of life, and those with repeated prescriptions during infancy, were more likely to be overweight or obese by age two—with one in five boys and one in ten girls classified as overweight or obese; boys showed a stronger association and were slightly taller if exposed. Researchers suggest antibiotics might promote weight gain by altering gut bacteria that would otherwise consume food or by increasing appetite, though the study does not prove causation. Lead author Dr. Antti Saari warned that early or repeated antibiotic exposure may contribute to the childhood obesity epidemic and underscores the need for judicious antibiotic use; previous studies have linked early antibiotics to higher risks of eczema and digestive problems, and concerns persist about antibiotic overuse and rising drug-resistant infections.

A Buckingham Palace Queen's Guard slipped on a manhole cover and fell while taking up position in his sentry box during the Changing of the Guard, an incident caught on a tourist's camera; he slid sideways, knocked his bearskin, dropped his rifle, then scrambled to his feet embarrassed as colleagues marched on and hundreds of tourists gasped. The fall—attributed by onlookers to metal protectors on his boots—was filmed by holidaymaker David Meadwell; the Ministry of Defence declined to comment beyond noting a young man fell while doing his job. The Changing of the Guard, watched by thousands daily in summer (and alternately in winter), involves two detachments for Buckingham Palace and St James's Palace and comprises fully operational soldiers under the Captain of The Queen's Guard.

A&E Networks (A&E, Lifetime and History) announced a 2016 simultaneous remake of the landmark 1977 miniseries Roots, which tells the saga of Kunta Kinte, an African captured, enslaved and brought to a Virginia plantation, and his descendants; LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce, Mark Wolper (son of the original producer) is executive producer, and producers will consult African and African-American history scholars to make the new version “original” and “contemporary” while drawing more from Alex Haley’s novel, aiming to introduce the story to both fans of the original and a new generation shaped by events such as Barack Obama’s presidency, the film 12 Years a Slave, and current racial unrest.

Former royal footman Christopher Lawler alleges that on his first day working at Clarence House in January 1978, men who were palace aides attempted to force him into a sexual encounter: after being offered a drink in a bedroom he says a younger man began to masturbate, another touched and grabbed him, and a senior staff member and others held him in a chair trying to remove his trousers; he escaped, was followed and threatened, and left the job the same day after an angry response to his complaint. Now 64 and a former Port of Liverpool police officer, Lawler says he was haunted by the incident, contacted the Palace again last year amid wider inquiries into historical VIP child-abuse allegations, was initially rebuffed twice before his complaint reached Scotland Yard months later, and police are investigating; a retired royal aide in his 80s denied involvement, the Palace said the Royal Household would cooperate with police, and a police spokesman declined further comment while investigations continue.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child in a parody rap video set to the '90s sitcom The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air theme that has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube; the clip shows them rapping in a car about buying a house, trying to conceive for two months, Melissa discovering a positive pregnancy test, and ends with them smiling and sharing a sonogram, and they told KPTV it took five takes to film, was intended to inform distant loved ones, and might be followed by a gender-reveal video, while local coverage noted Jesse is a great-great-grandson of pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek and referenced a similar announcement video made last year in Pennsylvania.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind—a slate blue-gray jacket and full skirt ensemble that has faded to light gray and features a black zigzag applique—sold at Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills for $137,000 as part of a sale of more than 150 items from the film; the collection came from James Tumblin, former head of hair and makeup at Universal Studios, who began collecting film memorabilia in the 1960s after buying the dress for $20 when it was about to be discarded, and other notable auction sales included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), Clark Gable’s Rhett Butler trousers and jacket ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland ($30,000); Gone With the Wind, based on Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary last year and featured Hattie McDaniel, the first African-American actor to be nominated for and win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell 10 to 12 feet into the cheetah exhibit pit at Cleveland Metroparks Zoo on Saturday after his mother dangled him over the railing; his parents rescued him before firefighters arrived. The child, taken to MetroHealth Medical Center, suffered minor bumps, bruises and a leg injury and was listed in stable condition; the cheetahs did not attack or approach him. Zoo officials, citing eyewitness accounts, said it was likely the child was dangled over the railing and plan to press child endangerment charges against the family; the exhibit was closed after the incident.

A decommissioned bright yellow Gatso speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which has not been working for more than two years since around 300 obsolete fixed cameras were switched off across the West Midlands in March 2013, has been turned to point directly at a house on Wellington Road; mystery remains over who re-angled it, Birmingham City Council said it is aware and will have an engineer visit to take appropriate action and possibly remove the device, confirmed it will not be included in a planned digital-camera pilot, and the house owners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2–3, the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association announced; the six-time Olympic gold medallist said he is fit, healthy and ready to run, enjoyed the event's atmosphere last year, and aims to make the country proud, while JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle welcomed his selection and promised "sprint magic"; the full Jamaican team will be announced shortly.

Neymar and teammate Dani Alves attended Barcelona’s EuroLeague basketball El Clásico, which Barcelona won 85-80 over Real Madrid, who nevertheless top the EuroLeague division on points difference; Neymar attended with his sister Rafaella and friends. Earlier Neymar, Brazil’s captain, helped Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile at the Emirates, enduring several harsh challenges (including an incident where Gary Medel appeared to stamp on him). Before the international break Luis Enrique’s Barcelona had won their La Liga El Clásico to move four points clear, and Neymar and his teammates return to La Liga on Sunday to face Celta Vigo as they pursue a treble.

Italy is facing a surge of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting Mediterranean crossings; the Italian coast guard rescued 8,480 people between Friday and Monday and on one Monday received SOS calls from 20 boats, while Save the Children reported survivors fearing 400 missing from a capsized ship purportedly carrying 550 about 80 miles off Libya—a claim the coast guard says it cannot confirm and for which search operations found no evidence of a capsized vessel or bodies. The International Organization for Migration reported Italy logged over 10,000 arrivals in the first three months of 2015, about 2,000 were rescued during one April weekend in the Channel of Sicily, most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia and Syria using Libya as a transit point, and at least 480 people have died so far this year due to bad weather, overcrowded smuggler vessels, and sometimes abandoned boats.

Arsene Wenger says he does not know exactly why Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool but is pleased the £32m Chilean signed for the Gunners, has adapted instantly to English football and scored 19 goals so far this season; Wenger acknowledged Liverpool interest likely related to Barcelona’s pursuit of Luis Suarez last summer and that such leverage would have made sense in negotiations, praised Sanchez’s qualities and impact on the team, and downplayed transfer speculation linking him with Liverpool winger Raheem Sterling while complimenting Brendan Rodgers’ work at Liverpool after Suarez’s departure and Sturridge’s injury.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt the UCI Hour Record on June 7 at London's Lee Valley VeloPark, aiming to beat Rohan Dennis's February mark of 52.491km; tickets (priced £49, £39, £29) go on general sale via Sky Tickets from April 19 at 10am and the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. The 35-year-old four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner finished his Team Sky career at Paris–Roubaix, will ride the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire for his eponymous team, and is preparing the Hour as part of a track return while targeting a potential British-record eighth Olympic medal in Rio 2016; recent attempts after UCI rule changes saw Jens Voigt (51.115km) and Matthias Brändle (51.852km) set interim marks before Dennis. Wiggins hopes a 6,000 sell-out crowd will spur him on and said the Hour is a "holy grail" he wants to try to inspire others to challenge themselves.

Serena Williams, a two-time French Open champion and world No. 1, struggled but ultimately beat Italy’s Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in the Fed Cup play-off, improving her head-to-head to 8-0, yet admitted the match was an “eye-opener” about her unpreparedness for clay ahead of the claycourt season; despite her singles win, the US lost the doubles 6-0 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, relegating the United States to World Group II, prompting captain Mary Joe Fernandez to urge harder work to regain a spot among the elite next year.

River Plate are interested in signing Manchester United loanee Radamel Falcao, with vice president Matias Patanian saying “we dream of Falcao” and “the doors are open,” though any deal is complicated; the 29-year-old Colombian has struggled at Old Trafford this season with just four Premier League goals during a season-long loan and may return to parent club Monaco if United do not exercise an option to keep him, but he has recently scored three goals in two international games to equal Colombia’s all-time record with 24 goals; Falcao previously joined River Plate at 15 in 2001, made his first-team debut four years later, and scored 34 goals in 90 Primera División appearances over four seasons.

Ella Henderson, the 19-year-old X Factor finalist, has been announced as the official face of Batiste's 2015 "Ready For It" dry shampoo campaign—her first brand collaboration—shot against a blurred city backdrop showcasing various hairstyles (glossy waves, a tousled half-ponytail) in glamorous outfits; the international campaign, fused by the MILES agency, launched with a TV advert featuring her single "Mirror Man," and both Henderson and Crown Talent & Media Group CEO Mark Hargreaves expressed enthusiasm about the partnership with the UK's number-one dry shampoo brand.

Family and friends of 26-year-old Aaron Siler, who was fatally shot by Officer Pablo Torres on March 14 after Siler allegedly armed himself during a vehicle and foot pursuit while wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant, are in shock and calling for removal of a Kenosha billboard paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association that features Torres and thanks the community for its support; they say it feels like a thank-you for killing Siler and was upsetting to his mother. The police association says no offense was intended and the billboard was meant to thank the community for support for the officer, his family and the department. Torres is on leave while the investigation into Siler’s death continues; investigators from the state Division of Criminal Investigation are involved. Ten days before Siler’s shooting, Torres shot 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives and later charged with recklessly endangering safety; that shooting was turned over to the district attorney, who later deemed it justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border in Negur; Iranian state media said three militants were killed and that the attackers crossed into Iran from Pakistan, with authorities asking Pakistan to capture survivors. The militant group Jaish al Adal, a Sunni anti-Iranian organization active in Balochistan that has targeted Shiites and claimed prior attacks on Iranian soil (including 14 border guards killed in October 2013), claimed responsibility. Iran has accused Pakistan of failing to curb such groups; Pakistan condemned the attack as terrorism, said its security agencies are investigating, requested evidence from Iran, and vowed to apprehend any militants who returned to Pakistan.

Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani told the Diet that the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs, saying jets sometimes visually investigate unidentified objects that turn out to be birds or non-aircraft but not beings from beyond Earth. His statement followed a question from flamboyant lawmaker and former wrestler Antonio Inoki—who has claimed to have seen a UFO—about whether aircraft had been scrambled for extraterrestrial threats and whether research into alien visitors was underway. The exchange, noted for Inoki's colorful public history and prior political stunts, echoes earlier Japanese political debates, including a 2007 remark by then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba about the constitutional implications of defending against an outer-space invasion.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts requiring several dozen stitches to his left leg and buttocks after a porcelain toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Anhui Province smashed to the floor while he was standing on its rim because he feared the seat was unclean; he called traveling companions for help rather than shout, was taken to a Hefei hospital, initially confessed to friends he had been squatting but later told police he was sitting—possibly to avoid paying compensation—and authorities called the incident an accident, reminding people toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera under a bathroom sink; prosecutors say investigators traced the camera to Rebbie and discovered 41 videos—34 showing victims showering—captured over three to four years and uploaded to his computer, some containing close-up images of children’s genitalia. The girl told police Rebbie had watched her undress and believed she was asleep for years and that he began entering and molesting her while she slept from age nine to 13. Rebbie admitted filming several victims, including juveniles, and allegedly purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old; he faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children and invasion of privacy, is held on $500,000 bail, and has a preliminary hearing on May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s latest series, from a book roughly translated as Daughter and Salaryman, pairs po-faced teenage daughters in casual clothes with their sharply suited fathers leaping or striking energetic poses—sometimes looking slightly pained—against various Japanese landmarks; the images aim to show normally serious fathers expressing a fun, heroic side and have attracted online interest, though little else is known about the project.

Following Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director, attention has shifted to the start of the county championship season and Kevin Pietersen's possible return to the England set-up. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014 and last played for England on the unsuccessful Ashes tour in Australia, rejoined Surrey and participated in a jovial yet reflective team photo session at the KIA Oval ahead of Surrey's season opener at Glamorgan on April 19 and an upcoming match against Oxford MCCU; his presence and form for Surrey are seen as a way to force his way back into the Test side.

Relegation-threatened Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week after a poor run of results: he was fired Wednesday, briefly reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone, then dismissed again following a 2-0 loss to mid-table FC Botosani that left Ceahlaul 16th and six points from safety; the 41-year-old former Inter and Parma right back, capped 25 times by Brazil, had replaced Florin Marin in January as the club’s third coach of the season and will be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar, a former Monaco team-mate, says Radamel Falcao likely regrets his season-long loan move to Manchester United despite being unhappy at Monaco; Falcao, who previously starred at Atletico Madrid but suffered a serious knee injury, has struggled at United this season—scoring only four goals—and United are unlikely to make his move permanent given the £46 million fee, while Dirar notes Falcao would have played and featured in the Champions League had he stayed in Monaco.

New Zealand police are asking the public to help identify a very tall man who robbed a Christchurch Union St dairy on Saturday while wearing a distinctive oversized cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt; security footage shows him demanding cash from the owner's daughter, who ran out screaming, then throwing the cash register to the ground and escaping with the till drawer and up to $1,500, with no weapons reported, and police urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, 24, a math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was first arrested on March 19 after admitting in a police interview to kissing a 15-year-old student and letting him touch her breasts in April of the previous year; she was suspended and placed on administrative leave. Days later police investigated and, based on school reports, a second 15-year-old student alleged Granado had sex with him in her car on consecutive nights (January 18–19) across the road from another Dallas school; she was booked into Irving County Jail again, released after posting $50,000 bail, and it is not known how she will plead to the new charges.

A widely viewed video shows a large American crocodile swimming through Puerto Vallarta marina with a dead black pet dog wearing a red collar held in its jaws; New Zealander tourist Tim Weston photographed and described the croc holding the dog for hours near a sanctuary 200m up the river, while crowds watched and reacted with horror after the clip was posted on the Bogged Facebook page; crocodiles are commonly seen in Puerto Vallarta—whose mangrove setting and urbanisation bring 6‑metre American crocodiles closer to people, with sightings also reported on the resort’s golf course.

Steve Bruce insists he can keep Hull City in the Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton that leaves them two points clear of the drop with six games to go; he had initially targeted 10 wins but Hull have only six so far and he hopes "nine or eight might be enough." Hull were the better side first half but conceded a James Ward-Prowse penalty and a late Graziano Pelle goal, and Bruce blames long-term injuries to key players (Mohamed Diame just returned from five months out, James Chester from three, while Michael Dawson and Nikica Jelavic missed half the season and Robert Snodgrass has not been available) for their struggles, yet remains convinced the squad can get results against a run of tough fixtures including Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. Southampton moved up to fifth after the win, but manager Ronald Koeman warned his squad after Sadio Mane attempted to take Ward-Prowse’s penalty and said he would address team rules with the players.

A teacher, 31-year-old Ian Guffick of Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after admitting he altered pupils' SATs exam answers and asked pupils to change theirs after the test session ended, actions that led the Department for Education to annul the whole school's 2014 SATs results; a local authority probe found changes had been made outside exam conditions and Guffick also amended some papers himself, he claimed he only asked for legibility improvements, the conduct panel deemed his behavior dishonest though not fraud, noted his remorse and cooperation, and he was given 28 days to appeal to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, the Danish goalkeeper who joined Manchester United from Aalesunds in 2010 and has made just 19 league appearances in five seasons and been limited to cup matches, is currently third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes and has been told he can leave (a proposed move to FC Midtjylland fell through). Off the pitch he is happily married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri—who has Albanian roots, over 17,000 Instagram followers and regularly posts modelling photos—after dating since 2012 and marrying in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius; the couple have a son and Lindegaard recently shared a cheerful Instagram post about a day off with his wife.

The 13 glowing blue letters that had hung over Yankee Stadium since 1976 failed to attract bids at a Sotheby's auction; they were expected to fetch $300,000–$600,000 but only saw a Sotheby's employee paddle for $260,000. The current owner is Reggie Jackson, who bought the 10-foot-tall letters after the stadium's final 2008 game and attended the auction, saying he hoped a new generation would enjoy them and joking he may have gotten ahead of himself given their size; he had promised to visit any U.S. buyer. Also sold at the auction was a late-1960s New York Mets bullpen car estimated at $20,000–$30,000 that instead sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers admonished Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe over recent incidents—Sterling was pictured inhaling nitrous oxide and both were seen with shisha pipes—but after speaking with them neither will be disciplined and Rodgers wants to move on. Rodgers reminded the young players of their professional responsibilities and noted that certain ordinary actions can be perceived differently for elite athletes. He declined to say whether Steven Gerrard, now available after a three-match suspension, will be recalled for Sunday’s FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, emphasizing his priority is getting Liverpool into their first FA Cup final under his tenure and that past near-misses are part of the process of learning and improving.

Mesut Özil returned to London after international duty, posting a “Home Sweet Home” photo of himself relaxing with his dog; he had impressed for Germany in a 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifier win over Georgia and is targeting Arsenal’s upcoming Premier League match with Liverpool, having missed the previous Arsenal game vs Newcastle through illness amid unproven nightclub rumours that Arsène Wenger denied. Signed from Real Madrid for £42.5m in 2013 and formerly of Schalke, Özil has scored three goals and provided four assists for Arsenal since January after returning from injury and says he is adapting well to English football’s demanding schedule, feeling he “fits in perfectly.”

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu said the club are "very happy" with manager Luis Enrique, who signed a two-year deal last summer and has a contract until 2016; despite speculation about replacement, Bartomeu refuted those claims, praised Enrique's preparation and performance as Barcelona chase multiple trophies, and noted Enrique is focused on La Liga. The passage also reports Barcelona beat Valencia with early goals from Luis Suarez (after one minute) and Lionel Messi at the Nou Camp.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term contract with Liverpool, expected to run until summer 2020 and be worth around £100,000 a week; he had 14 months left on his previous deal and negotiations involved his advisors earlier this season. The 24-year-old, signed from Sunderland in June 2011 for £16 million, has improved markedly under Brendan Rodgers, contributing seven goals and 13 assists this season, and is the third key player to extend his stay after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. He is vice-captain and could be considered to replace Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard departs for LA Galaxy; talks with Raheem Sterling are on hold until season’s end though Liverpool expect Sterling to remain long-term.

Filipe Luis says he wants to remain at Chelsea until his three-year contract ends despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him; he has struggled to secure the left-back spot at Stamford Bridge, played for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile, and says manager Jose Mourinho demands focus as Chelsea face a difficult nine-game Premier League run-in.

Nathan Hughes’s three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North while scoring for Northampton on March 27 was overturned on appeal and his red card rescinded after the appeal panel, having seen evidence not available to the original hearing, concluded the incident was accidental and not foul play; Hughes had been sent off and suspended despite no intent, missed Wasps’ Champions Cup quarter-final against Toulon while awaiting the appeal, and is now free to play though not selected for the upcoming match against London Welsh and unlikely to return before the April 26 trip to Exeter; North was left unconscious, taken off on a stretcher, has suffered his third head knock in two months and been advised to take at least a month off, and the original suspension drew strong criticism from figures including James Haskell, Andy Goode, Austin Healey and Joe Marler.

Fiery red sunsets in Seattle and across parts of Oregon, Washington and British Columbia were caused by smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia, which began when farmers burned grass and then spread out of control on April 14 due to strong winds; although rescue crews extinguished the fires and they destroyed dozens of villages, lingering smoke was carried across the Pacific by atmospheric winds, and smoke particles filtered out shorter-wavelength colors (greens, blues, yellows, purples) so red and orange light dominated—especially at sunrise and sunset when light travels through more atmosphere—and as the smoke dissipates air quality will improve and the intense reddish hue will fade.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis discovered her new 2015 Ford Fusion had been stolen from her driveway a little over a month after purchase; police recovered the car after a tip from Mick Sexton, but it had been altered with spray‑painted red rims, red side detailing and orange accents on the steering wheel, and smelled strongly of cigarettes and marijuana, so Schoenig is having it professionally cleaned; instead of being angry she posted a photo on Facebook thanking the thieves for "pimping out" her car and, to honor Sexton, is creating a smoothie called the Sexton on Wheels at her restaurant The Hot Pot.

Manchester City players stand to lose about £500,000 each in bonuses—and the squad around £12 million in total—if the club fail to qualify for the Champions League group stage this season, because many stars (Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, Yaya Toure, James Milner) are on incentivised contracts tied to finishing in the top four to meet Financial Fair Play rules; after a 169th Manchester derby defeat to United that left City fourth but only four points clear of Liverpool (if Liverpool win their game), manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the season has “disintegrated” with seven losses and early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League, and City face crucial remaining fixtures (West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, QPR, Swansea, Southampton) while also confronting a tougher task in the transfer market to sign world-class targets like Paul Pogba amid United’s rising position under Louis van Gaal.

Manchester United's Under-18s beat Manchester City 1-0 in a local "mini-derby" at Altrincham's Moss Lane before nearly 1,000 fans, with England Under-17 Callum Gribbin scoring a curled free-kick just before the hour after creating the foul; United, who adopted a three-at-the-back formation with wing-backs to mirror the first team, nearly extended their lead through Cameron Borthwick-Jackson, while City's Marcus Wood and Marcus Rashford (for United's opponents? — actually Rashford played for the home side) had notable chances and Dutch winger Javairo Dilrosun hit the bar from a late free-kick. The win gives United two wins in this season's cross-town matches and leaves them two points behind Middlesbrough with a game in hand, whereas injury-hit City have lost both play-off matches; the match showcased several homegrown talents who might merit first-team opportunities.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italy veteran Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" and an inspiration after Buffon earned his 147th cap in a 1-1 draw with England; Hart—10 years younger—said he’s still learning by watching Buffon, celebrated earning his own 50th cap at the Juventus Stadium, and expressed his desire to continue playing well for club and country to add more international appearances.

Chipotle is partnering with Postmates to offer delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities, entering the $70 billion food delivery market; Postmates’ delivery fees start at $5 and rise with distance and demand, and Chipotle will add a nine percent service charge. Chipotle had previously resisted third-party delivery but approved Postmates, which uses independent-contractor drivers, and joins other chains—Starbucks (delivering in parts of Seattle and New York), Taco Bell (testing delivery), McDonald’s (planning McDelivery), and Burger King (pilot via bkdelivers.com)—in pursuing delivery. The chain has grown recently and been frequented by public figures such as Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton, who were both spotted at Chipotle locations.

Bill and Denise Richard, whose 8-year-old son Martin was killed and 7-year-old daughter Jane severely injured in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, wrote a front-page Boston Globe opinion urging the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for the convicted attacker, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, and instead have him serve life without parole and waive appeals; they say, having witnessed the trial’s graphic evidence and endured ongoing grief and surgeries, that continued pursuit of capital punishment would prolong their anguish and the pain for their surviving children, and they seek to "turn the page" for their family, Boston, and the country.

A custom-built Boeing 747-8 has been converted over three years into a £400 million luxury private jet for a single billionaire owner, reconfiguring the 600-passenger airliner into a hotel-like residence with bedrooms (including a master bedroom and an "aeroloft" on the top deck with eight full beds), multiple lounges and state rooms, a central dining room attached to a kitchen for a private chef, a conference room with a long table, office/guest rooms with porthole windows, and extensive guest relaxation areas capable of carrying several dozen passengers, with interior plans and artist impressions produced by Greenpoint Technologies.

SpaceX launched a two-stage Falcon 9 from Cape Canaveral carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo ship to the International Space Station; Dragon is en route and will dock in a couple of days to deliver over 4,300 pounds (1,950 kg) of supplies (including research equipment and an ISSpresso espresso maker), with the crew spending about five weeks unpacking it and later loading it with over 3,000 pounds of experiments, trash and other items to return to Earth via Pacific Ocean splashdown off California. The Falcon 9’s first-stage attempt to land on a droneship failed—Elon Musk said the rocket landed but tipped over (after a previous January attempt where it hit at an angle and exploded)—but SpaceX intends to keep trying to recover boosters to reduce launch costs by enabling rocket reuse; the rocket’s upper stage will carry Dragon to orbit then break away and burn up on reentry. This was the sixth SpaceX ISS mission and the second launch attempt for this flight, after a scrubbed attempt Monday due to weather.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the inaugural wedding in a newly unveiled Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel at the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas, a venue tied to Elvis’s long run of concerts there; she collaborated with NBC's Today show on a contest awarding one Elvis-obsessed couple an "ultimate wedding"—the winners (to be announced next Monday) will marry at the chapel on Thursday, April 23 and receive a free reception, two-night hotel suite, airfares and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show—and Priscilla, who helped design the chapel as part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis, emphasized the event is "first-class" and will not include impersonators; applicants must submit photos or video plus an explanation of why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his side can close the four-point gap on Manchester City after a 2-0 win over Newcastle that marked his and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet's 47th appearance of the season, equalling a record for the top five European leagues. Henderson said recent Premier League performances and results had been disappointing but the win showed they can keep winning and put pressure on City. Raheem Sterling opened the scoring in the ninth minute with skill, and Joe Allen added a second from a defensive mistake—his first Anfield goal—20 minutes from time; Allen acknowledged he did not have his best game but that the goal was important after recent defeats. Newcastle had a strong penalty claim when Dejan Lovren appeared to foul Ayoze Perez, which Allen also thought was a spot-kick.

Roma ended a four-month home winless run by beating Napoli 1-0 in Serie A, second-place Roma moving four points clear of Lazio; Miralem Pjanic scored after a 25th-minute counter from a pass by Alessandro Florenzi following Juan Iturbe's run, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made numerous second-half saves, including stops on Dries Mertens and Manolo Gabbiadini, to preserve the win; Napoli extended their five-match winless run and remained fifth, with heightened security (Campania residents barred from tickets and 1,000 police deployed) due to past violence, while Roma were missing injured Francesco Totti and Gervinho and Napoli introduced Lorenzo Insigne late on in his return from a November knee injury.

Doncaster Rovers have endured an uninspired League One season, sitting in mid-table mediocrity; their home match against Fleetwood Town, whose play-off hopes had faded, ended 0-0 at the Keepmoat Stadium, testing fans' patience and leaving the club’s media team to post a very short 27-second YouTube highlights clip containing 14 seconds of match action—just the kick-off, a goal kick and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux films his close interactions with a blood parrot cichlid in which he repeatedly cups and strokes the fish in its tank, and the fish responds by relaxing, remaining still, circling his fingers, swimming up his arm, burying its face in his hand, and following his hand to the surface when he withdraws it; Giroux began hand-feeding the fish frozen blood worms and removed two tankmates that were bullying it, after which the fish became more sociable and now requires about 15 minutes of daily massage and play or becomes frustrated; the blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlids first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes as a fiery, exuberant England cricketer who needs careful man‑management to channel his aggression productively rather than let it become destructive; his recent clash with Marlon Samuels was handled well after coach Peter Moores spoke to him, and Stokes has recovered from a difficult year including a wrist injury at Kensington Oval and a slight back niggle. The writer values Stokes’s character and believes England should allow him freedom while reining him in when needed, as long as it produces runs and wickets, and notes a selection dilemma in Barbados between playing two spinners (Adil Rashid) or retaining all‑rounders like Stokes and Chris Jordan, with England keen for both to gain experience and develop.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium has sold out its 33,000 capacity after Wales’ 3-0 win over Israel raised expectations of automatic qualification; both Wales and Belgium sit on 11 points in Group B with Belgium top on goal difference, and Wales prefer playing at the smaller Cardiff City Stadium rather than the 74,500-seat Millennium Stadium, which could not be used anyway due to UEFA rules preventing venue changes within 120 days of the match.

England under-17 coach John Peacock has named a 20-man squad for next month’s UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria; the Young Lions, defending champions who qualified with a 100% record, are in Group D with Holland, Italy and the Republic of Ireland and open vs Italy in Burgas on May 7 (also facing Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13). The squad: goalkeepers Paul Woolston (Newcastle) and Will Huffer (Leeds); defenders Danny Collinge (Stuttgart), Reece Oxford (West Ham), Easah Suliman (Aston Villa), James Yates (Everton), Jay DaSilva (Chelsea) and Tayo Edun (Fulham); midfielders Trent Arnold (Liverpool), Daniel Wright (Sunderland), Herbie Kane (Liverpool), Tom Davies (Everton), Marcus Edwards (Tottenham), Nathan Holland (Everton) and Chris Willock (Arsenal); forwards Layton Ndukwu (Leicester), Stephy Mavididi (Arsenal) and Ike Ugbo (Chelsea). Notable points: Arsenal’s Stephy Mavididi and Chris Willock earn call-ups (Willock for the first time), Chelsea’s Jay DaSilva and Ike Ugbo included, and Liverpool’s Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold return after missing the Elite Round.

Manchester City are pursuing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, a highly regarded youth talent who previously turned down Barcelona’s La Masia at 12 to continue his studies; Arsenal and Barcelona have shown interest, and City have discussed a compensation package with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock as Manuel Pellegrini seeks to build for the future by signing him.

A 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found strangled and beaten to death in a £400,000 flat in Romily Court, Fulham, south west London, on March 28 after the London Ambulance Service was called at about 9:30pm; she died of head and neck injuries. A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death and subsequently bailed to return for further questioning. Santillan, who had been visiting London from Miami and worked as an escort in London, Paris and Miami according to her website, had posted about loving London and Paris in the weeks before her death. Scotland Yard, led by Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves, is appealing for anyone who saw or had contact with her in the hours before her death to come forward; police say they will do “everything” to solve the case.

Dawn, a woman who has suffered seven miscarriages and buried one baby, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show after discovering £207 saved toward a £500 headstone for her baby Daniel James had been stolen; she suspected housemate Jamie and his girlfriend Carol, and a lie detector on the show indicated Jamie — who has a prior burglary conviction — had taken the money, while Jeremy Kyle also revealed a Facebook message from Jamie confessing to taking the cash and blaming Carol; Dawn broke down in tears, stormed off the show, and afterward said she felt betrayed and devastated.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis — mostly women and children, plus some ill or elderly — who were received by Peshmerga and sent to the Kurdish regional capital Irbil; officials gave slightly different counts (Nuri Osman said 217, Peshmerga commander Rassol Omar said 228) and said Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release, though motivations were unclear. Yazidis, a Kurdish-descended, pre-Islamic religious minority long persecuted and wrongly labeled as devil worshipers, suffered extraordinary brutality by ISIS after its summer takeover of northern Iraq, including the Sinjar massacre, mass killings, reports of rape and enslavement of women, and mass displacement (hundreds of thousands fled, some trapped in mountains). International responses included airdropped supplies, rescues, and U.S.-led airstrikes beginning in August; about 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq, under 1% of the population.

Harry Kane, having broken into Tottenham's first team and Roy Hodgson's England squad during a remarkable season, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season; Copa90 released an animated video titled "Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?" that uses layered still photographs to showcase his best goals and celebrations—including his long-range strike vs Chelsea, a headed goal vs Arsenal, his England debut goal, and his 20th Premier League goal of the season scored past Tim Krul against Newcastle—released ahead of the awards ceremony where he competes with players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher backed Brendan Rodgers to remain Liverpool manager despite a trophy-less third consecutive season and likely finish outside the top four, saying one game should not determine Rodgers’ future and that many summer signings have yet to bed in; Liverpool sit seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City with a game in hand and were knocked out of the FA Cup by Aston Villa in a disappointing semi-final. Carragher said Rodgers, staff and players will aim to improve next season, with correct signings crucial to progress, and he defended the existing squad. Carragher received a Beacon Award in London for community work through his 23 Foundation, which provides coaching in eight schools in deprived Merseyside areas; he described his Bootle roots and desire to help his community.

Four-year-old James Hayward had a brightly coloured plastic Nerf-style toy gun confiscated and was frisked by security at East Midlands Airport after the toy showed up on X-ray; his father Phil criticised the “over‑zealous” checks as ludicrous because they were rushing to catch a flight to Lanzarote, so they left the £6 semi-automatic soft-dart gun behind and later bought a replacement on eBay. East Midlands Airport apologised for the inconvenience, said it had offered to post the toy home, and defended the action by citing government-set security regulations that prohibit items resembling replica or model guns in hand luggage.

A 31-year-old man calling himself "Rich" from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory posted a Gumtree advertisement seeking a girlfriend/wife, listing extensive personal details and partner requirements: he described himself as athletic, white, heavily tattooed, 175 cm, brown-haired/eyed, well endowed, non-drinker/non-smoker, drug-free, property owner, financially successful, and outdoorsy; he offered accommodation, possibly a company car, phone and laptop, free gym membership, and other benefits, promised to spend on his partner, and sought someone who loves pets and the outdoors, is fit, non-drinking/non-smoking, reliable, honest, loyal, handy, a good cook and great in bed, "also a princess when need to be"; he said former partners need not apply and that "all reasonable offers will be considered," and Daily Mail Australia could not contact him.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke is pushing proposals to raise the minimum number of home-grown players in Premier League club squads from eight to 12 and to redefine "home-grown" as having trained in England for three years before age 18 rather than before 21; he has been backed by five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson and Steve McClaren—who warned in a letter that blocking the changes would harm English football, reduce the pool of top-level English talent and hinder efforts to win major honours, noting only 81 of 220 Premier League starters (36.8%) were England-eligible in the last round and arguing that while promising young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling and Harry Kane are emerging they lack sufficient opportunity.

Demelza Poldark, previously barely showing, is now portrayed as having given birth to Ross Poldark’s daughter in tomorrow night’s episode: viewers will see Ross gaze at the newborn within ten minutes of the installment, and he tells Demelza she makes him a better man; critics note an implausible timeline—last episode announced the pregnancy, yet the new episode opens with Demelza (Eleanor Tomlinson) saying she’s eight months pregnant and then gives birth minutes later, echoing a prior rapid pregnancy jump between episodes for Elizabeth, which fans mocked on Twitter.

Leicester boss Nigel Pearson has told his players to stay focused on their own performances and ignore relegation rivals after back-to-back wins left them three points from safety but still bottom of the Premier League; following Jamie Vardy’s injury-time winner at West Brom that gave them a survival lifeline, Pearson warned against shifting emphasis to other teams’ form or becoming overly optimistic, stressing their future is in their own hands and they must ensure their own run-in gives them a realistic chance.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed a nearly 14,000-mile (22,500 km) migration—reported by Oregon State University researchers—making it the longest mammal migration on record and surpassing the prior Guinness World Records humpback whale round-trip of about 10,190 miles. Varvara traveled from feeding grounds off Russia’s Sakhalin Island across the Pacific to Baja, Mexico, and unexpectedly visited three major eastern gray whale breeding areas, prompting researchers led by Bruce Mate to suggest she may originate from the eastern population. Her journey highlights impressive long-distance navigation and raises questions about the distinction between western and eastern gray whales—potentially reducing the already small estimated western population of about 150 and indicating a need for closer genetic study.

Residents on Hokkaido’s Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu woke to about 1,000–1,640 ft of seabed thrust above water, forming a new coastal stretch roughly 100 ft wide and rising 30–50 ft in places after a nearby landslide; geologists say melting ice and snow caused a section of land to drop and pivot the underwater area into the air, and aerial surveys and local officials report no sounds or tremors were felt, the event is considered different from earthquakes and unrelated to a recent 7.8 magnitude quake in Kathmandu, authorities do not expect further expansion, and marine life such as seaweed and sea urchins remain attached to the exposed mass.

Gregory van der Wiel denied reports he'll leave Paris Saint-Germain, saying he is happy at the club, loves the team and city, wants a new contract, and will accept the coach's decisions after a recent spat with Laurent Blanc over being dropped for the Chelsea game; however PSG remain linked with Barcelona's Dani Alves, which could affect Van der Wiel's future.

Carlos Tevez, 31, has informed Juventus he wants to leave this summer to return to former club Boca Juniors despite a contract running until 2016; Boca president Daniel Angelici says Tevez must terminate his Juve contract and that a deal is close, while Juventus—reluctant to lose the Serie A top scorer (17 goals this season)—have accepted his desire to leave and begun seeking replacements; Argentina manager Tata Martino says a move to Boca would not harm Tevez’s international prospects, noting both clubs are strong and that Tevez will decide what’s best for his future.

At the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich thrashed Porto 6-1 to overturn a 3-1 first-leg deficit and reach the Champions League semi-finals, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso and a Robert Lewandowski brace; amid the 5-0 half-time lead and jubilation, Bayern manager Pep Guardiola accidentally ripped the left leg of his grey trousers, briefly exposing his underwear and joking he would need to buy new ones, later removing his blazer as the match progressed.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a three-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway 2 km south of Fernvale on Wednesday afternoon. A 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain were airlifted first to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain; six others—including an infant and two young girls—were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment. One person was trapped and freed by Queensland Fire and Rescue using hydraulic cutting gear, Rescue 500 landed and airlifted multiple patients, two females escaped injury, a man suffered hand lacerations, and the affected highway stretch was closed with diversions south of Fernvale for a few hours.

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil, who has four goals in 25 matches this season, showed off a new Apple Watch he bought at an Apple store ahead of Sunday's 4pm Premier League match at the Emirates against leaders Chelsea, posting on Instagram that the gadget is "just like Michael Knight's watch" from Knight Rider; Arsenal trail Chelsea by 10 points with six league games left but have been boosted by Jack Wilshere's return from a five-month injury layoff—he was on the bench for the FA Cup semi-final win over Reading—and club legend Ray Parlour praised Wilshere as the club's future if he can stay fit, citing injuries as the key concern that has affected players like Abou Diaby.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will take charge of the Manchester derby at Old Trafford on Sunday; he has sent off three players this season when including Vincent Kompany’s red for Belgium (suspending Kompany for Wales) but in the Premier League has shown only two reds this season, both to Manchester United players (Tyler Blackett in the 5-3 loss to Leicester and Luke Shaw in the 1-1 draw with West Ham). Clattenburg, regarded as one of the Premier League’s leading referees alongside Michael Oliver despite courting controversy, will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin with Jonathan Moss as fourth official. The derby is intensified by United’s recent five-game winning run and their move a point above City after Crystal Palace’s shock 2-1 win, while City have slipped from title challengers to chasing fourth place.

Federal MP Bob Katter, of Lebanese descent, sparked controversy after accusing the Queensland Government of treating MP Billy Gordon "like a little black puppet on a string" following Gordon's resignation from the Queensland Labor Party amid accusations of domestic violence and failing to disclose his criminal history; Gordon announced he would remain in parliament as an independent, imperiling the government's slim majority. Katter, who said he has faced racist attitudes and sympathised with Gordon, defended his language as drawn from his own background ("because I'm dark and I come from Cloncurry") and intended to call out racial overtones, citing examples of independents allegedly becoming government "puppets" while insisting Gordon would not repeat that. The remark drew social media criticism for its terminology.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, who was born with cerebral palsy, creates enthusiastic dance videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others; despite being bullied and stared at, she emphasizes that she is much like other people—she drives, attends college, and dances—and hopes her videos and motivational speaking at local Chicago-area schools will make people look past her disability and treat her like "one of us."

Orlando City have expressed interest in Manchester United forward Javier Hernandez, who has struggled on loan at Real Madrid but remains wanted by eight European clubs and several Premier League sides; United are willing to sell the 26-year-old, who has one year left on his contract, for around £8 million, with reported interest from Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio and Inter Milan. Separately, Manchester United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has attracted contact from Paris Saint-Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven and Feyenoord via his father after rejecting United’s initial offer; Pereira was on the bench against Aston Villa.

A group of at least three people allegedly attempted to carjack a man pumping gas at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles around 12:15 a.m. on Saturday, then poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger and set it on fire while two passengers were inside; no one was injured but the car’s front end was destroyed. The driver’s grandmother said the suspects pulled a gun and demanded the car, then sprayed it with fuel; the Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, surveillance video is being used, and the suspects remain at large.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor in Lamoni, southern Iowa, admitted to bartering sex for services and performing exorcisms on patients and has surrendered his state chiropractic license under an agreement requiring he not seek reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove the circumstances leading to revocation no longer exist before resuming practice; he also advised some patients to stop prescribed medications. Despite these admissions, his online presence lists a residential practice address and three highly positive patient satisfaction reviews (5/5) on HealthGrades.com, while a woman answering his home declined comment and a contact at his former practice said he had not worked there for some time.

The United States is formally complaining to Moscow after a Russian SU-27 intercepted a U.S. RC-135U over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland, an encounter the Pentagon called "unsafe and unprofessional" because of aggressive, high-speed maneuvers close to the U.S. aircraft; Russia's Defense Ministry claimed the RC-135U had its transponder off and said the SU-27 circled to identify it, a claim U.S. European Command disputed, and the Pentagon and State Department plan to lodge a diplomatic protest — a complaint similar to one last year when a Russian jet made a dangerously close pass within 100 feet of an RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk; such encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft are common in Northern Europe and between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent’s sniper rifle was stolen from his car overnight March 27 in the Marriott Springhill Suites parking lot in Salt Lake City — a hard case that was reportedly secured to a truck safe with padlocks and chains was allegedly ripped through a broken rear right passenger window after a thief tied a rope to the case handle or cable lock and used a vehicle’s momentum to pull it free, leaving skid marks, rope and the broken case handle behind; the agent’s gear bag, backpack, clothing and tools were also taken (some items later found at a nearby Residence Inn), the rifle has not been recovered, its serial number was entered into the National Crime Information Computer, the hotel has no surveillance cameras, police don’t know if the agent was targeted, and the Secret Service was notified before President Obama’s visit to Utah about a week later.

A jury heard that Luigi Costa, 71, accused of killing his neighbour Terrence Freebody in July 2012 at a Red Hill, Canberra home, was believed by forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen to have been suffering dementia compounded by alcohol at the time of the attack; Mullen cited fluctuating mood during 000 calls, a trail of faeces to the toilet, and declining mental state before and during the incident as evidence that Costa was confused and may not have understood his actions or consequences, a view contested by prosecutor Shane Drumgold who suggested Costa feigned memory loss while Mullen denied that claim; Costa’s mental state is central because the jury could return a not guilty verdict if an unstable mindset at the time is proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley after the young midfielder unexpectedly took and missed a 10th-minute penalty against Burnley—saved by goalkeeper Tom Heaton—despite regular taker Leighton Baines (15 from 16 in the Premier League) being on the pitch; Martinez said Barkley was within his rights to volunteer and that he prefers several players able to step up, citing that Romelu Lukaku would have taken it if he had been playing, and noting there was no dispute as Barkley “showed incredible responsibility”; the miss proved harmless as Kevin Mirallas scored the match’s only goal in the 29th minute for a 1-0 Everton win.

Two passengers were found dead inside their stateroom on Holland America Line’s ms Ryndam in San Juan, Puerto Rico; the ship’s cleaning staff discovered them after knocking on the cabin door, and the cabin was secured at 11:30 a.m. Thursday while authorities including the FBI were notified and are investigating an apparent murder‑suicide; the vessel had departed Tampa on March 29 on a 14‑day Southern Caribbean cruise.

Patrick Kluivert, former Netherlands forward and assistant coach, has begun his tenure as Curacao coach with a win in 2018 World Cup qualifying as Curacao advanced to CONCACAF's second qualifying round by defeating Montserrat 4-3 on aggregate after a 2-2 draw in the second leg and a 2-1 first-leg win in Willemstad; the tie was heading to extra time until Charlton Vicento, a former Netherlands U21 international, scored in the 87th minute five minutes after coming on as a substitute. Curacao will face Cuba on June 8 and 16, and Kluivert—whose mother is from Curacao—was a World Cup semi-finalist in 1998 as a player and in 2014 as assistant to Louis van Gaal.

Esteban Cambiasso, who won major titles with River Plate, Real Madrid and especially Inter Milan (15 trophies including five Serie A, four Coppa Italia, four Supercoppa, Champions League and FIFA Club World Cup), says helping keep Leicester City in the Premier League would feel like winning another trophy; despite Leicester being seven points from safety with eight games left and winless since January, Cambiasso—signed on a one-year deal last summer and quickly established as a key player—is optimistic they can avoid relegation, is happy with life in the East Midlands, and may stay beyond his current contract.

A 23-year-old woman named Gemma, mother of two children under five by different fathers, handed both infants to her 52-year-old mother Debbie when they were four months old and has since continued heavy drinking, partying and using the legal high MKat; Debbie, who stepped in after social services threatened to take the children, claims Gemma is unemployed, has a history of stealing (including admitting to stealing money and items from Debbie and, per a lie detector test on TV, an iPad), has been neglectful of her children, and now faces being banned by Debbie from the house and from seeing the children because Debbie believes Gemma is unfit, puts partying before motherhood, and cannot be trusted.

After Eden Hazard's opening goal for Chelsea at Stamford Bridge, Sky Sports pundits agreed John Terry's strong challenge from behind on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao—which sent Falcao to the ground and led to Cesc Fabregas collecting the loose ball and releasing Oscar to set up Hazard—should have been penalised; Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp and Graeme Souness (who described it as a "decent forearm smash" with an elbow to Falcao's head) all stated the tackle warranted a foul despite some acknowledgement that Falcao might have tried to stay on his feet.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott’s tour bus caught fire on a Texas Interstate 30 freeway northeast of Dallas Thursday morning after a rear tire blew out, but everyone on board — Scott, her husband, the tour manager and the driver — was safely evacuated; dramatic video shows smoke and flames from the bus’s rear, and Scott posted Instagram photos saying the fire destroyed the bus’s back lounge except for her Bible. The tour manager said the bus burst into flames after everyone had gotten off, the band’s other members Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not on the bus, and Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas, on Sunday.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing orbiting satellites covered in mirrors and using semiconductors to convert harvested sunlight into laser beams that could be beamed back to Earth to boost solar panels, power homes (even in places like Scotland), or restore power to disaster zones; initial trials in Scotland were successful and he plans trials in Portugal, though he cautions control of the satellites could be a concern. The article contrasts these beams with fictional space weapons and with a separate Riken proposal to fit the ISS with a telescope‑guided laser to nudge small (<1 cm) debris into the atmosphere—both real systems are far weaker than cinematic lasers and not intended as weapons.

Stephen Munden, 54, a convicted paedophile described as having a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit after last being seen leaving a hospital near Hook/Winchfield, Hampshire at 6:15pm on Tuesday; officers launched a manhunt and released images showing him with and without a beard, noting he is about 5ft 8in, heavy build, dark hair, may have shaved, and suffers from autism and mild learning difficulties. He was detained under a hospital order after being convicted last August of sexually touching a three-year-old on a bus—sitting near the child and stroking her hand in view of her family—and admitting ten unrelated offences of possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children, with children’s clothes, books and dolls found at his home; police stress urgency in locating him.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay more than $2.6 million in gifts after Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling sued, alleging Stiviano targeted wealthy older men and that Donald Sterling used the couple’s money to buy Stiviano a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover and help her acquire a $1.8 million duplex; Stiviano argued the gifts were legitimate and she didn’t take advantage of Sterling. Shelly Sterling’s lawyer called the decision a family victory and a precedent for recovering such gifts. Reported gifts also included smaller items like a $391 Easter bunny costume, a $299 blender and a $12 lace thong. The dispute followed release of an audio recording in which Sterling made racist remarks to Stiviano about her posting photos with African-Americans, including Magic Johnson; the NBA banned Sterling, fined him $2.5 million and moved to terminate his ownership of the Clippers.

Thierry Henry criticised Arsenal's recent transfer dealings and urged them to buy four key players — a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive (holding) midfielder and a top-class striker — if they are to challenge for the Premier League title, arguing they need a stronger "spine" like Chelsea built by signing Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fàbregas and Diego Costa; speaking after Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea, Henry said Arsène Wenger must act, and though he praised Olivier Giroud's work and noted Giroud has 14 league goals that season, he questioned whether Giroud could lead Arsenal to a title.

A young woman who was abused for years by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn has told Sydney’s District Court that the abuse — for which Van Ryn has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences including persistent sexual abuse of a child — has had severe, lasting effects on her life: she didn’t understand the abuse was wrong as a child, kept it secret until she learned he was caught, has since attempted suicide, been hospitalized for self-harm, suffered depression since age 14, fears for future relationships and worries about him being in the community again; the hearing continues.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal and Germany Under-21 midfielder whose progress was halted by a serious knee injury after last featuring in the Champions League last-16 second leg against Bayern Munich in March 2014, is nearing a comeback: he has recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under-21s (his second 90-minute outing in a week) in a 1-0 loss to Reading, says he is "feeling better and better," is over his injury worries and is looking forward to the next game.

Graduate accountant Jacob Phillips, 23, fell to his death after plunging 70ft down a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, when he ran from a taxi to avoid paying the fare following a night out in Cardiff. Phillips and two friends, lacking money to complete the journey home, exited the cab to “use an ATM” and then split up; Phillips ran into the pitch-black area, leapt over a fence and became disoriented before falling off the disused Northern Promenade (The Dardanelles). His body was found the next morning on the rocky beach by a dog walker; paramedics attended and the coroner recorded an accidental death, concluding Phillips could not have known the danger ahead. Phillips, who had grown up in Barry, studied accountancy at the University of Birmingham and worked for the Pretty Green clothing label.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer’s passport backlog received little compensation despite the HM Passport Office making a £42.3m surplus; managers also received bonuses (total £1.8m in 2013–14, average £499, highest £3,500). The backlog arose as 3.6 million people applied and by mid-June over 500,000 passports were delayed; ministers offered free fast-track upgrades for urgent cases but refused a blanket refund, saying it would set a precedent. Between April and January only 2,191 compensation applications were approved (barely up from 2,077 the prior year), totaling £203,066 (average £92.68), with payouts ranging £1–£5,463; many claimants who paid for upgrades or missed trips received nothing, and the Passport Office could not state how many claims were rejected due to a customer-complaint database failure.

A semi‑detached three‑bedroom house in Horfield, Bristol, unchanged since the 1930s, is for auction on April 30 with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000; it retains original features including stained‑glass windows (ships in the hallway, coats of arms in the living room), wood‑panelled hallway, vintage mint‑and‑black bathroom with original tiles, wooden floor, yellow wallpaper and green sink, original kitchen cupboards and glass‑panelled door, brick open‑face fire, dated sink, oil‑fired central heating, and a hallway shelf holding original tins (Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk, Tate & Lyle sugar, Colman’s Mustard); the house is double glazed but auctioneers warn renovation costs may deter developers while it could suit an antiques‑loving family.

Colin Kaepernick began his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith, became the San Francisco 49ers' starter in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion, remained the starter for the rest of the season, and led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent much of her early life there, then moved to Texas and later to San Francisco; Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London and around Colchester, Essex, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and later formed Blur; their debut album Leisure was released in 1991 to mixed reviews, and drawing on influences including alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae and pop, the band released a self-titled album in 2001 to worldwide success. Albarn’s debut solo studio album, Everyday Robots, co-produced by XL Recordings CEO Richard Russell, was released on 28 April 2014 and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as samples of rants by Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, locally called Hamar and also rendered Muqdisho and مقديشو, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, hosting many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails from their debut extended play (EP), Broken (1992).
Andrew Kevin Walker (born August 14, 1964) is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA.

The franchise centers on Bob Lee Swagger: in the 2007 film Shooter, Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger (Mark Wahlberg) is framed for murder by a rogue private military unit; in the TV series Shooter, Ryan Phillippe stars as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is drawn back into action after discovering a plot to assassinate the president.
House (also called House, M.D.) is an American television medical drama that originally aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, running from November 16, 2004 to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found in 1971 guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people—Abigail Ann Folger, Wojciech Frykowski, Steven Earl Parent, Sharon Tate Polanski, Jay Sebring, and Leno and Rosemary La Bianca—which were carried out by group members at his instruction; he also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea, and after he was charged recordings of songs he wrote and performed were released commercially.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary subfield of computational linguistics that develops methods and technologies for converting spoken language into text, drawing on linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Sheikh Ali Salman of al-Wefaq told the BBC that meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain requires the government to offer concrete solutions and to involve a royal-family representative, naming Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa—a reformist seen as willing to accommodate the Shia majority—as a partner for talks; he said al-Wefaq welcomes and is ready for dialogue despite hardliners around long-serving Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa opposing concessions for fear of encouraging further demands. Salman acknowledged youth disillusionment with opposition parties and insisted peaceful demonstrations remain the only viable pressure tactic under a ban on public gatherings, while calling for the release of 13 opposition figures convicted on allegedly torture-obtained evidence. He recalled that a seven-point plan toward a constitutional monarchy had been agreed with the crown prince hours before GCC troops intervened on 14 March 2011 and urged stronger, public US and UK pressure—expressing hope in John Kerry and criticizing the UK’s private-only approach—to end rights abuses and ensure dialogue success.

Christopher Hogwood, who died at his Cambridge home after a months-long illness, was a pioneering conductor and key figure in the early-music movement who founded and led the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) for about 30 years, directing it across six continents and producing over 200 CDs including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments; his notable recordings include the acclaimed 1980 Handel Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson. Trained in keyboard at Cambridge and with teachers such as Rafael Puyana, Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt, he began as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, was a founding member of the Early Music Consort of London, and served as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society; he also taught at Harvard, was honorary professor at Cambridge and professor-at-large at Cornell. Colleagues and musicians praised his generosity, scholarship, influence in training leading players, and his commitment to letting the music speak for itself; his funeral will be private with a memorial planned for a later date.

In the year to 31 March 2016 Scotland recorded 57 homicides—five fewer than the prior year and the lowest 12‑month total since 1976 and half the number from nine years earlier—with only one 2015–16 case unresolved; 51% (29 cases) involved a sharp instrument (26 of those knives), 31% of accused (20 people) were identified as under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs, and many accused had unknown alcohol/drug status. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the long‑term fall and urged continued education, enforcement and multiagency work to prevent violence and address alcohol misuse. Scottish Labour’s Claire Baker cautioned about the figures, noting past revisions (2014–15 victims were initially 59 then revised to 62) and pointing to a 45‑year high in sexual crime and a 27% rise in attempted murder and serious assault in the past year.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 at Sunderland, the first Premier League defeat Sunderland have had this season; Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal in three games but Sunderland replied through Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty. Bournemouth also failed to score despite having chances and playing against ten men after Steven Pienaar was sent off. Manager Howe said the lack of goals shouldn't be down to confidence, noted they had scored six against Hull recently, lamented that many chances have gone unconverted, and emphasized the importance of how the team moves on.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott defended Australia’s strict policy of detaining migrants who try to reach its shores by boat and sending them to offshore processing, saying "stop the boats" is the only way to prevent drownings; the New York Times called the policy "brutal," "inhumane, of dubious legality" and warned Europeans should not copy it. Abbott described the death of three-year-old Alan Kurdi as "very sad" but reiterated stopping illegal boats had stopped drownings in Australia. He also sparked anger by saying Islamic State was worse than the Nazis—arguing IS "boast[s] about their evil"—a comparison criticized by the Executive Council of Australian Jewry’s Robert Goot as unjustified given the systematic state genocide perpetrated by the Nazis; Abbott said he stood by his comments but was not "in the business of ranking evil."

The United States suspended bilateral channels with Russia intended to sustain the Syria ceasefire, accusing Russia and the Syrian regime of intensifying attacks on civilians—including repeated air strikes on rebel-held eastern Aleppo, hits on a main trauma hospital, and obstruction of humanitarian aid such as the 19 September strike on an aid convoy—and saying Russia failed to ensure Syrian compliance; Moscow denied responsibility for the convoy strike, blamed Washington for not improving Aleppo’s humanitarian situation or separating jihadists from the moderate opposition, and regretted the US move; US personnel awaiting a joint implementation centre were withdrawn and planned Geneva coordination on strikes was halted, though both sides said they would continue counter‑terrorism dialogue to avoid clashes.

Policy Exchange proposed selling high-value social homes when they become vacant to raise about £4.5bn a year (after paying off debt) — enough, it estimates, to build 80,000–170,000 social homes and potentially cut the 1.8 million social housing waiting list by about 500,000; Downing Street backed the idea and said councils can already choose to do this to use stock more efficiently, while Policy Exchange defines "expensive" social housing as properties worth more than the regional average (21.8% of stock, about 816,000 properties, worth up to £159bn nationally and more than £70bn in London), with roughly 3.5% of stock vacant each year allowing sale of about 28,500 homes annually; proponents argue the policy would enable more families to be housed and boost building, whereas critics including Labour, the National Housing Federation and MPs warn it would displace low‑income families from affluent areas, break up mixed communities and create segregation, and call instead for alternative funding such as a bank bonus tax and increased affordable‑homes investment.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died last week at his Swansea home amid a measles epidemic in the city that has reached 942 cases; laboratory tests confirmed he had measles but an examination could not establish whether measles was the main cause of death, so an inquest will be opened and adjourned to allow further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment.
