His mother said he had recently been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital, developed a widespread rash a few days after discharge, visited an out-of-hours GP on 17 April with a rash “from head to foot” but not on his arms, and was found dead the next morning; the family say they do not know how he contracted measles because no close family member, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, has the disease.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged by Cumbria Police with a historical offence against a boy under 16, alleged to have occurred in 2001; he is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Neil Aspin's Gateshead, unbeaten in nine National League matches, drew 1-1 at home with Adam Lockwood's Guiseley, who were unbeaten in five. Guiseley took a surprise lead on 15 minutes when a throw-in found James Hurst and Jake Lawlor finished into an empty net; Simon Walton was later booked. Gateshead threatened before half-time with Liam Hogan blocking Jordan Preston and Guiseley keeper Jonny Maxted saving from Wes York. At half-time Derek Asamoah replaced Kevan Hurst; after the break Guiseley made further substitutions (Michael Rankine on for Jordan Preston, Adam Boyes for Jake Cassidy) and Gateshead brought on Luke Hannant for Gus Mafuta (who received a yellow). Gateshead equalised on 62 minutes when a slip by Asamoah allowed Wes York to curl in from the edge of the box, and the match ended 1-1.

Bristol Sport Ltd, which owns the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity as an alternative to a delayed Ashton Vale stadium proposal halted by a town green application; majority shareholder Steve Lansdown said at a shareholder meeting that council-approved work will proceed pending signing a section 106 agreement, a six-week judicial review period, and if no review by March they will start redevelopment in May.

Cuadrilla has suspended fracking operations as a precaution after a 1.5 magnitude tremor near the Preese Hall drilling site in Lancashire — the second small earthquake in two months — and will review British Geological Survey (BGS) data before deciding whether to resume; the BGS found the April quake occurred about 2 km from the site at ~2 km depth, had similar waveforms, location and mechanism to a magnitude 2.3 event on 1 April, and noted that injection of pressurised fluids during shale gas (fracking) can fracture rock and induce earthquakes; Cuadrilla’s CEO said they stopped operations to share information and consult authorities, the BGS is monitoring fracking as a precaution, and while fracking is controversial over environmental concerns (including US reports of gas in water), a Commons committee recently urged ministers to support UK shale gas with tight regulation and good industry practice.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool piper who has busked in the city centre for over 30 years, denied three counts of fraud but was found guilty of one count after performing in April 2015 with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes; a jury cleared him of the other two counts at Liverpool Crown Court. Sgt Chris Gaynor said Carpenter gave the impression he was collecting money for the campaign, while Carpenter insisted he was simply busking and that the banner was a tribute, noting he had piped for the charity before and is a familiar match-day figure. Kenneth Derbyshire, chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, confirmed he had allowed Carpenter to design and display a banner with the eternal flame and the word "justice" but said he had explicitly told him not to use it to collect funds. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich beat QPR 3-0 with Grant Ward opening the scoring, Luke Varney adding a second after QPR keeper Alex Smithies miscued a clearance, and Tom Lawrence finishing a Cole Skuse assist for the third; Ipswich dominated chances despite a recent scoring drought, Berra and Skuse among others missing opportunities, while QPR offered little threat though substitute Sandro hit the post from a late corner. The win moved Mick McCarthy’s side up to 14th (above QPR in 15th), and McCarthy praised Varney and his team’s response after poor recent results; QPR boss Ian Holloway blamed a “calamity” second goal, defensive lapses and mental frailty rather than solely his keeper.

Wells, 23, had a strong T20 Blast season with 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66, and he said the club is heading in the right direction, praising the coaches for creating an elite-performance environment that players want to join.

Redruth (the Reds) moved to fifth in National Two South with a 29-12 win over third-placed Chinnor for their second straight victory, a performance coach Churcher credited to front-row players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey and Craig Williams and the pack making 70-plus tackles; Churcher called the display dogged but incomplete, warned the team must build on it or the result will be wasted, and noted their upcoming slate includes seven lower-placed teams and league leaders Old Elthamians.

Police say 28-year-old Nazrul (aka Nazu), an allegedly Bangladeshi citizen, was the man who raped a 74-year-old nun during a 14 March attack in Ranaghat in which a convent school was ransacked and money stolen; he was arrested at a Kolkata railway station after allegedly returning from Bangladesh and has been named by five previously arrested suspects, bringing the total arrests to six; police have identified eight suspects overall, two of whom remain untraced, and earlier in May they arrested Milon Sarkar, described as the gang leader though his exact role was unclear; the incident sparked nationwide outrage and street protests.

Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, explains in an interactive video how changes such as the arrival of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports altered what UK consumers buy; the video also explores shifting ownership and rankings of major UK brands, works best full screen, may not function on older browsers, and links to non-interactive supplemental materials including items on China’s ownership, tips on freezing food, a BBC Good Food annual top-20 consumer brands survey, and the Museum of Brands.

Two recent scams involved callers posing as BT technical support who tricked elderly women into giving remote access to their computers and stole money: a 71-year-old in Sandyhills on 15 September and a woman in Stranraer seven days later. PC Siobhan Pellett warned that perpetrators easily gain access to victims' computers and take substantial sums, urging people not to give banking or account details over the phone, since banks, building societies and reputable businesses never ask for such information.

Duffy, 37, has signed a one-year contract to join the third-placed Championship side Featherstone after leaving Swinton Lions; he will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Featherstone chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy’s coaching, citing his remarkable work in difficult circumstances at Swinton, where Duffy — a former Leigh, Widnes and Salford player with a 16-year career and Scotland assistant coach — has been succeeded by his former assistant Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew with a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter went to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday to assist a rider who had head injuries and was very cold after lying unconscious on wet sand; she was treated and then flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries at the ITU-organized World Radiocommunication Conference agreed to allocate a radio frequency for satellite reception of aircraft automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions, enabling real-time global tracking of planes to address weaknesses exposed by the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in March 2014; the current ground-radar system leaves about 70% of world airspace uncovered, debris from MH370 was later confirmed on Reunion Island, ITU leaders hailed the rapid response, and ICAO has set a November 2016 deadline for new tracking guidelines requiring position reports at least every 15 minutes or more often in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, has been found at 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland; Bobby, 53, was arrested and is jailed in Cuyahoga County, Ohio, on charges including tampering with records to obtain a 2012 driver’s licence and is held on $250,000 bail. The FBI received a tip on 30 October after the teen had problems applying for college, and worked with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm his identity; Julian’s mother has been notified. Authorities had suspected around the time of the 2002 disappearance that the father might be responsible, and a missing persons database shows Mr. Hernandez reported taking his son to preschool in August 2002 then fled.

Firefighters spent several days at a Duncan Street site after a blaze on 2 March that disrupted train services and travel; the Environment Agency has suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste and decided to revoke the company's environmental permit effective 7 August (subject to appeal), though the firm must still remove all waste. The site, run by Asset and Land Group, was visited nine times by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service in the past year and was described as "broadly compliant" with fire safety legislation, but GMFRS had raised concerns with the EA in February about potential impacts on residents, transport and the environment, prompting joint visits and EA enforcement action. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has proposed two Duma bills tied to the Ukraine crisis that would ease Russia's acquisition of territory and speed up granting Russian passports in areas with strong pro-Russian sentiment, notably Crimea and Sevastopol; one bill would allow Russia to accept a territory whose people clearly express a desire to join without a treaty in cases where a neighbouring state is disintegrating, and proponents cite past actions in Abkhazia and South Ossetia, while the other would fast-track naturalization by waiving state tax, residence, funds and renunciation requirements, allowing Ukrainians to apply at Russian missions before 1 August and gain citizenship in two months instead of a year, framed as protecting Russian-speaking Ukrainians from a perceived "brown threat," and accompanied by visits from Russian MPs and public figures to Crimea.

The passage traces McLaren's fall from a dominant F1 team—182 wins, 23.18% win rate, 12 drivers' titles and eight constructors' crowns—to its current slump where modest goals like fourth-row grid positions and some points are seen as progress; the decline began in 2013 with poor chassis design while Honda remained strong, but now the car has improved and the Honda power-unit is the weakness. It recalls McLaren's greatest eras: the Honda-powered dominance of 1988 with Senna and Prost (15 of 16 wins), later success with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes in 1998–99, and earlier titles in the 1970s, while noting scandals—2007 espionage that expelled them from the constructors' championship and a $100m fine, and 2009's "lie-gate" leading to a public apology and sackings—and a drying up of titles after 2012 despite Hamilton and Jenson Button wins. Ron Dennis's long leadership and returns after downturns are described; he insists McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance and that recent car gains plus Honda's expected improvement will restore "championships, plural," but for now belief is all that stands between the team and its hoped-for revival, including Alonso's chance at a third title.

Thomas "Tommy" Baker, 44, of Everton, was found critically injured at Stanley Meat Market in Old Swan, Liverpool on 27 January after being shot in the head and chest; he later died in hospital. Merseyside Police have arrested three local men (two aged 29 and one 32) who remain in custody. Detectives say Baker had left Phoenix Gym at the market shortly before getting into his car, that those involved had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour, and that officers are searching for a silver VW Polo seen leaving the scene at speed along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road and Queens Road. Investigators also urge people captured on nearby CCTV to come forward as they may hold key information.

The passage describes several ways Christians are using online and digital media to celebrate and share Christmas: Everyday Church Online runs global virtual Sunday services with chat rooms and themed sermons (its first Christmas theme is Star Wars, billed as "The Hope Awakens"); the Scripture Union team created Guardians of Ancora, a free fantasy game for 8–11-year-olds with Christmas Bible quests about finding Jesus' birth; viral nativity videos—such as Viral.de's 2010 "The Digital Story of Nativity" and the Churches Advertising Network's "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle"—have attracted large audiences (nearly six million and about 250,000 views respectively), though a cinema ad was rejected for being "too religious"; Next Manga, after distributing millions of printed Bible-story manga, has launched apps and e-books including the Manga Messiah nativity available in 33 languages and with large Arabic print runs sent to refugees; and churches and Christian media increasingly use platforms like Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to prompt spiritual reflection rather than straightforward gospel outreach, with commentators suggesting Jesus would have used Twitter.

An eight-day inquiry in Ebbw Vale is considering a proposal to take over 250 hectares of common land, with supporters including Blaenau Gwent council offering about 320 hectares of replacement land; experts gave conflicting evidence on habitat and plant damage from the proposed circuit, Natural Resources Wales said it was "difficult to conclude" the replacement land was of equal value but did not oppose the development, developers presented an ecology report claiming a biodiversity "net gain" via nearby habitat enhancements which Gwent Wildlife Trust disputed, and the Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend after the inquiry before Welsh government ministers make the final decision.

Chechen Muslim clerics condemned a Novaya Gazeta report on 1 April alleging that more than 100 men had been detained as homosexuals in Chechnya—with at least three killed—and called the report an insult warranting “retribution,” prompting the paper to urge Russian authorities to prevent attacks on journalists; the Russian LGBT Network, which confirmed the report and says detainees were tortured near Argun and is helping victims flee, alleges authorities ignore the abuses and may take the case to the ICC if no prosecutions occur, while Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov and his spokesman deny there are gay people in Chechnya; Novaya Gazeta said some detainees included clerics close to Kadyrov and TV presenters, its editor vowed to continue investigating, and the paper notes past unresolved murders of its reporters and critics linked to Chechnya.

Investing Solutions, a large lettings agency set up in 2002 by Samir Patel and operating alongside the charity Fresh Start Housing (founded 2010) from the same south London storage-unit address, has been receiving substantial housing benefit by placing single homeless men—referred by London homeless charities—into private houses as multiple unrelated tenants and claiming benefit per person, resulting in benefit payments significantly higher than the rent passed to landlords; examples include one property where the agency claimed £2,114 monthly while the owner received £1,150, yielding an annual gross profit of £11,568, and Wandsworth Council paid the agency over £2.1m in two years. The company focuses on men over 35, exploiting rules allowing private rather than shared accommodation for that age group and charges up to £260/week per room in its boroughs. Tenants like Nigel McCann report unsuitable, unsafe conditions (no heating/hot water, rats, damp), and homeless sector critics describe the charity–agency link as a “new low.” Investing Solutions and Fresh Start say the charity is independent with its own trustees and that most rent is passed to private landlords; Fresh Start reports housing 788 homeless people since founding but would not disclose how many were placed via Investing Solutions. Local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayers’ money and inspecting private sector housing.

London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13 as GB led for much of the first three quarters before the Netherlands, paced by Worthy De Jong’s 18 points, overtook them in the fourth to win after scoring the first 10 points of that quarter; GB had led 35-24 on Lawrence’s three in the second, the Dutch took the lead early in the third, Gordon hit three straight threes to restore GB’s advantage, and despite a late GB comeback the hosts lost; coach Joe Prunty, who used his strongest line-up in the final warm-up before cutting the roster for Eurobasket qualifying, said the key will be competing on every play and praised Gordon’s showing and stretch in the third quarter.

The Nevada Athletic Commission received Conor McGregor's waiver request on time for his boxing debut vs. Floyd Mayweather, and will publicly debate on August 16 whether to allow 8oz gloves at the 154 lb limit (NAC rules normally require 10oz from 135 lb up, with 8oz allowed only between 135–147 lb via waiver); Mayweather had announced he would wear 8oz gloves but had not submitted a waiver then. NAC director Bob Bennett, prioritizing fighter safety, reviewed extensive material on McGregor — including sparring footage, his knockdowns of Nate Diaz and attributes like chin, youth, reach, and advised hiring a boxing referee; Hall of Famer Joe Cortez was hired after overseeing volatile sparring, and trainer Paulie Malignaggi later left the camp following a contentious sparring image.

Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, long-time Fleet Street journalists for the Dundee-based Sunday Post, are among the last to leave the area as its London office closes, marking the end of an era when Fleet Street — home to Britain's first daily paper (the Daily Courant, 1702) and once the national press hub — concentrated most major newspapers and a bustling journalist culture of pubs, bars and smoke-filled newsrooms; veterans recall the street's heyday of noisy typewriters, hot-metal presses, heavy drinking and male-dominated newsrooms, while its decline accelerated after Rupert Murdoch moved major titles to Wapping in 1986 and newspapers adopted cheaper computerised printing, leaving former press buildings repurposed (eg Mirror Group site now Sainsbury's HQ), and prompting Smith to go freelance and Sherriff to write memoirs as Fleet Street's historic role fades.

J.K. Rowling said supportive comments on Twitter reminded her there are more decent people than not, after receiving abusive messages that crossed her "personal line"; she blocked some users she believed were SNP supporters who called her a "traitor" over her past £1m donation to the Scottish No campaign (she gave £1m to Labour in 2008), but also engaged with "really nice SNP supporters" and noted shared political common ground with many of them, joking she would "bring marshmallows" in response to a suggestion her books be burned; the SNP won 56 of 59 Scottish seats in the election and became the UK's third largest party.

A University of Edinburgh study tracking 4,300 young people since 1998 found that poverty strongly increases both victimisation and offending: children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crime as better-off peers, poorer youths are about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision, and extreme poverty raises chances of being victims and perpetrators; poverty also increases likelihood of violence for boys and girls, with boys three times more likely than girls to be violent and poor girls twice as likely as affluent girls to engage in violent crime even after controlling for other risks. A history of police trouble was the strongest predictor of being not in education, employment or training at 18, and the authors warn that juvenile justice contact can reproduce conditions that foster violence. A related Edinburgh study found that recent falls in overall crime have not benefited the most deprived areas—high-crime communities remain concentrated in neighborhoods with chronic health problems and unemployment—prompting questions about whether inequality is being adequately tackled, while the Scottish government points to falling recorded crime and measures to address poverty.

Karl (Mr) Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate, Kilkee, in the early hours of Sunday and was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital at 06:00; knives and golf clubs were recovered at the scene, including a knife handle and a bloodied blade. Robbie Walsh, of Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody to appear again next week, with a judge noting community tension and remanding him until 14 August. At Ennis District Court Det Sgt Padraig Frawley said it is alleged Walsh and two others entered the Marian Estate shortly after 01:00, called at houses looking for Mr Haugh, encountered Mr Haugh and another man, and a fight involving weapons ensued; two other men arrested were released without charge and files are being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions.

Sinn Féin MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted in May 2014 that MP Tom Elliott, a former UDR member (1982–1992) who has a clear MoD record, had "harassed and shot" people; the tweet was deleted within an hour after being pointed out to Elliott by campaigner Ann Travers and DUP assembly member Arlene Foster. In court, Flanagan admitted the claim was "untrue and wholly without foundation," must post a Twitter apology by Friday, and Mr Justice Stevens reserved judgment on compensation; the insurance that covers MLAs at Stormont refused to indemnify Flanagan and he is challenging that refusal separately. Elliott said he was vindicated and disappointed at the delay in resolving the matter.

Hawick Knitwear, established in 1874 and employing over 230 staff, has boosted sweater production from about 7,500 to 9,500 per week after stronger-than-expected sales of its own Hawick Knitwear-branded range launched in January and continued growth in private-label supply; bought by managing director Benny Hartop in November, the company supplies European markets (Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, Spain) and non-European markets (USA, Canada, Mexico, Japan), and Hartop attributes the surge in orders and positive outlook to dedicated staff.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a married mother of three and a lollipop lady for 20 years, suffered serious head injuries last December outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston while escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road when traffic lights turned red; her VW Golf-driving assailant, 55-year-old Brian Wright of Kempston, told Luton Crown Court he was blinded by the setting sun, accepted he had struck her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, and expressed remorse while the jury heard his car failed to stop for a red light and the trial continued as Mrs Blackburn is now being treated in residential care.

Nato is conducting "Dynamic Mongoose," a major anti-submarine exercise in response to increased Russian submarine activity and growing concern about a gap in UK defenses; German U-boat U33 and its 28-man crew act as the unseen adversary while ten warships led by USS Vicksburg, plus a Royal Navy frigate, helicopters, a French Atlantique maritime patrol aircraft and, for the first time, underwater drones search for periscopes and sonar signatures. Russia has invested heavily in a fleet of about 60 advanced, often quiet submarines that can operate undetected for months, prompting Nato to sharpen skills in detecting them—an effort complicated by difficulties distinguishing contacts from marine features. The exercise highlights the value of long-range maritime patrol aircraft and unmanned underwater vehicles, and underscores Britain’s vulnerability because it currently lacks maritime patrol aircraft, a shortfall RUSI experts say must be addressed in the upcoming defence review.

United Nations officials warn that genocide or ethnic cleansing could be unfolding in South Sudan after violence that began in July in Juba spread into Equatoria, forcing 340,000 people to flee into Uganda—more refugees this year than from Syria—and adding about 2,500 new refugees daily; accounts from escapees describe killing, rape and ethnically targeted attacks (notably against Equatorians, Nuer and by Dinka-aligned forces), with survivors recounting murders, sexual violence and destruction of towns like Yei. Refugees cross informal border points into Uganda, where the government and aid agencies have rapidly allocated land, shelters and plots for farming within 36 hours, and settlements such as Bidi Bidi have swollen into massive camps (now part of nearly a million refugees in Uganda), but resources—especially water—are strained and the UN appeals for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders as civilians are massacred.

McKenzie, 38, will face Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight title; a former Norwich and Peterborough footballer who turned professional in boxing in 2013 after quitting football in 2011, he has a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights, is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie, and is trained by his uncle Duke McKenzie, a former three-time world champion.

The coalition is funding Bridgwater Community Hospital as part of a £330m national investment in new NHS facilities, with the local project costing £33m and the remainder to be covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust; the new hospital—aimed for completion by autumn 2014 pending planning permission for Bowers Lane—will provide 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X‑ray and space for mobile scanners to replace the cramped, outdated 1813 building described by Matron Sue Taylor as poorly maintained and uncomfortable, and is seen by local clinicians (including GP/medical director Dr Donal Hynes) as improving patient care and supporting integrated, one-stop services, following replacement of three of Somerset’s 13 community hospitals in the past five years and concurrent work on the Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, Sheffield, around 13:35 GMT after being found with a gunshot wound to the chest near or in a black Mercedes; armed police sealed the scene and he was taken to Northern General hospital where he died. Neighbours said he was from a nearby family that had been holding a celebration and relatives rushed out after hearing the shot. The incident follows several recent shootings elsewhere in Sheffield, including a serious shooting in Shiregreen, shots fired through a Southey Green couple’s living room window believed to be a case of mistaken identity, and shots at houses in High Green in January.

The passage describes cyberwarfare around the Ukraine conflict, highlighting pro-Ukrainian and pro-Russian hacker groups that leak documents, deface sites, hijack devices and disrupt services. Pro-Ukrainian Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, have claimed hacks of Russian interior ministry servers and police emails, shared data used by volunteers (Inform Napalm) to identify Russian military casualties, run DDoS attacks against rebel websites, target rebels' electronic payment accounts, monitor hijacked CCTV for troop movements, and even hijack network printers to print pro-Ukrainian messages; officials deny using hacker data for artillery targeting. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, aims to thwart Ukraine’s military plans, has defaced Ukrainian government sites during Joe Biden’s visit, claims to have retrieved documents about U.S. military assistance, hacked billboards with graphic anti-Ukrainian content, says it disrupted electronic voting, leaked defence data and blocked the president’s website, and allegedly published a hacked Facebook exchange implying Ukrainian responsibility for MH17 (unverified). Russian activist Anonymous International (b0ltai/Shaltay Boltay) has leaked Kremlin documents and purportedly emails involving ex-FSB colonel Igor Girkin; its sources and methods are unclear and its site is blocked in Russia. The reporting is from BBC Monitoring.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond delivered valedictory speeches ahead of the 5 May election; McNeil, an MSP since 1999, warned Holyrood must learn from Westminster on committee scrutiny and accountability, while Salmond reiterated his view that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse," welcomed additional powers under the Scotland Bill but said it fell short of referendum-era unionist pledges, joked about timing against the Chancellor and Cheltenham, wished candidates luck "with varying degrees of enthusiasm," and concluded "it's goodbye from me... for now"; Marwick thanked Salmond for his service, and former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also joked she would miss dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Sarah Rochira, Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales, seeking testimony from pensioners, their families and friends to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. She aims to highlight both good care and the harms of poor care, assessing factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care home environment, and will also hear from care providers, social care staff and public bodies. Care Forum Wales chair Mario Kreft supports the review’s aims but criticizes the advisory panel for lacking a provider expert and any member who has lived in, worked in, managed or owned a care home, saying this excludes partnership working with the sector.

Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group reported a rise in pre-tax profit of £800,000 to £3.5m for the year ending June 2016, despite turnover falling by £1m to just over £100m; international sales grew in Europe and new markets, while the Turriff-based firm manufactures and supplies feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry sectors and runs 19 Country Store outlets across Scotland selling farming and rural products such as fireside supplies, clothing and footwear. In its Companies House accounts the company noted agriculture’s unpredictable outlook and recent challenges over the past 12–18 months but called the industry robust and said the board is confident the group is well positioned for potential Brexit-related business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house on Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted on Saturday; a man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Detectives are treating the death as murder and urgently want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), warning the public not to approach him; he is described as white, about 6ft tall, average build, with straight greying collar-length hair, and believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Police have urged anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers and are conducting extra patrols in the area for resident reassurance.

David Lipton of the IMF warned the global economy is weakening and at a "delicate juncture," noting the IMF's latest reading shows a weakening baseline; his remarks follow China’s weaker-than-expected trade data, with exports down about 25% year-on-year, and the IMF likely to downgrade its current 3.4% global growth forecast when it issues new predictions in April, a deterioration with lasting implications for businesses and industries that relied on China’s growth.

At a council scrutiny meeting about problems with the new chain ferry, council leader Dave Stewart announced Cowes crossings would be free until 2 July to acknowledge issues and gather feedback, and said auditors would review the project; since its launch on 14 May the ferry has broken down, run aground, been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training issues, and caused damage to cars boarding and disembarking. Affected shopkeeper Angie Booth warned local businesses have lost almost six months of trade and asked about compensation; transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation is under discussion but defended the ferry as a prototype with teething problems that included electrical faults now fixed, ramp extensions have been authorised to stop vehicles scraping concrete, and seamanship-related groundings have been resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the on-scene death of a 32-year-old man; a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention, and the road between Thursley and Liphook remained closed until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, a London agency that markets itself as an international temp service for "beautiful and talented people," ran job adverts seeking personal characteristics such as "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup" and a "sexy female driver" to drive a Porsche for £40,000–£50,000, prompting condemnation from the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) as "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women" and plans to seek clarification of the agency's hiring practices; campaigners and lawyers said such ads likely breach the 2010 Equality Act by implying discrimination (including on age and sex), with employment tribunal risk and unlimited compensation, while agency founder Nathalie Jansen defended clients’ appearance requirements—claiming they are driven by specific client demands and noting clients like MTV, Louis Vuitton and Harrods and that the firm has placed about 5,000 people worldwide.

A shooting at a hostel attached to the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore involved an alleged gunman, office assistant Mahesh, who police say barged into 18-year-old Gautami’s room on Tuesday evening and shot her in the head, then shot another student, Sirisha, who suffered severe injuries but is believed to be out of danger; Mahesh was arrested Wednesday after a manhunt and remanded until 12 April. Incidents of gun crime at Indian schools and colleges are very rare, India has strict gun control laws despite many feuds being settled with firearms, and a 2007 case is noted in which a 14-year-old was shot dead by two fellow students near Delhi.

Glaad's analysis of scripted broadcast, cable and streaming series airing or confirmed between June 2016 and May 2017 counted 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender representation rising from seven to 16; however, the group noted more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off (including Poussey Washington from Orange is the New Black and Bea Smith from Wentworth). The report also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, driven largely by shows such as Empire, Luke Cage and How to Get Away with Murder, and Glaad president Sarah Kate Ellis said progress was heartening but numbers are only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he will not seek re-election ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed; this follows BBC reporting that millions of pounds loaned to Northampton Town FC while he was leader of the borough council—about £10.25m—appear to have vanished, the loan is under police investigation for "alleged financial irregularities," and a football stand remains half built; Mackintosh has denied wrongdoing, had intended to stand again, and said it had been an honor to serve since 2015 but that it is the right time for constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former Balch Springs police officer, was indicted for murder after firing a rifle into a car leaving an April house party in which underage drinking was reported, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards and prompting his firing for policy violations; footage contradicted initial police claims that the vehicle had reversed aggressively, instead showing it driving away, and Oliver also faces four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon for shooting at the other teenagers in the car (including two of the victim’s brothers); he is free on bail, faces five to 99 years on the murder charge, no trial date has been set, and the case is being prosecuted by the Dallas County DA, with the Edwards family’s lawyer saying a murder indictment is appropriate but noting it has been more than 40 years since a police officer was convicted in Texas.

The president-elect says Melania Trump and their son Barron will move to Washington “very soon” after he finishes school, though no date is set; her decision to delay moving drew criticism and support online because only two previous First Ladies did not live in the White House, but historians note children often stay behind to finish school. Past first families have varied in arrangements—some First Ladies spent limited time in the White House or delegated hostess duties, and school-age children like Chelsea Clinton and the Obamas lived at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue from inauguration day (the Obamas moved early to avoid mid-term school changes). Melania has emphasized Barron as her priority and likely will not take on a full-time public First Lady role, though she has expressed interest in tackling cyber-bullying; family members (e.g., Ivanka or Chelsea in past administrations) have sometimes assumed duties, and historians stress the First Lady’s public role shapes the president’s symbolic image while families try to preserve normal routines and privacy.

A 72-year-old man was found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October; the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service has instructed the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, to investigate the initial police response to his call, with Pirc to submit a report of findings to COPFS in due course and Police Scotland saying it is fully engaging and awaiting the investigation's findings.

A yellow wind warning was issued predicting local gusts up to 75 mph (120 km/h), especially west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly direction likely to increase impacts and cause travel disruption on roads and at sea in Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys; overnight gusts felled a tree in Menai Bridge, Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which the council said would likely remain closed for most of Monday for clean-up.

Derrick Walser provided a short-handed opener for the Giants, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers; in the second period Mike Forney scored a power-play breakaway to make it 2-1 before Andy Bohmback tied it, then Mike Radja and James Desmarais pushed the score to 4-2 with Nottingham's David Ling replying; the teams meet again Saturday in the second game of a double-header, and Nottingham lead the league with 28 points, Sheffield Steelers have 27 and Belfast 25.

Lewis Hamilton started from the back after a first-lap collision that broke his front wing, forced five pit stops and left his car damaged and aerodynamically compromised, limiting his recovery as he failed to catch Nico Rosberg, who maintained the lead after Daniel Ricciardo’s early puncture and a safety-car period; Sebastian Vettel finished second despite colliding with team-mate Kimi Räikkönen on lap one (Räikkönen recovered to fifth after passing Hamilton late, aided by Ferrari’s choice of soft tyres for the final stint), while Red Bulls Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo finished third and fourth respectively, Kvyat defending his aggressive move that Vettel had criticized, and Hamilton now faces overcoming a 36-point deficit with 18 races remaining.

Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly came out as gay in an interview with Die Zeit to prompt discussion about a topic he said was ignored in German football, becoming the most prominent footballer to reveal his homosexuality; his announcement drew widespread praise from former teammates (including Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich), international figures (Gary Lineker, Joey Barton, John Amaechi), his first club Bayern Munich, German football leaders (former DFB president Theo Zwanziger and Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball) and politicians (Chancellor Angela Merkel’s spokesman Steffen Seibert and openly gay MP Volker Beck). The move was framed as a courageous, potentially watershed moment for combating homophobia in German football, where openness about sexuality has been rare—highlighted by past controversy over Philipp Lahm’s 2011 comments discouraging players from coming out, the 2007 account of second-tier player Marcus Urban that several Bundesliga players were too scared to reveal their sexuality, and calls for the German FA to encourage active players to be open.

Chris Sidwell, 34, made 32 Championship appearances this season to help Brighton earn promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years and now hopes to sign a new contract when his current deal expires at season’s end. Brighton confirmed promotion with a win over Wigan and sit four points clear of Newcastle, aiming to clinch the league title in the final two matches. Sidwell, who had a 2015–16 loan at Brighton from Stoke before signing a one-year deal in June 2016, has previously played in the Premier League for Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke; he believes he has performed well this season, deserves another chance at the top level and is keen to negotiate a new deal.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1 as Jamille Matt put Blackpool ahead after 12 minutes with a close-range finish from Nathan Delfouneso's chip, but Colchester equalised from the resulting corner when Kurtis Guthrie prodded home; both sides had chances—Colchester goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made several strong saves including from George Elokobi and Guthrie hit the bar, while Tom Aldred missed a late headed chance for Blackpool—and Colchester finished with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a violent tackle on Jim McAlister; the match featured multiple substitutions, bookings for Matthew Briggs, Tom Eastman and Andy Taylor, and various blocked and saved attempts.

The 29-year-old defender made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One; Reid, who has previously played for Charlton, Bradford and Preston, could debut for the U's in Wednesday’s EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa, while Colchester began the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington.

PC Keith Palmer's murder in March increased calls for a permanent police memorial; the UK Police Memorial Trust has appealed for £1.5m toward a £4m memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, which will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff who have died in 250 years of service, include a brass screen with leaf-shaped cutouts given to families as personal memorials, and is expected to be completed by 2019, with the government (Home Secretary Amber Rudd) committing £1m.

Manchester United extended their lead to 15 points with eight games remaining after a 1-0 win at Sunderland, marking 25 wins from their first 30 matches and 50 of 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games as they chase Chelsea's 95-point record; Sir Alex Ferguson said the squad is focused only on upcoming matches, noted injuries to Rafael, Anderson and a knock to goalkeeper David De Gea from a collision with Nemanja Vidic, and confirmed changes for Monday’s FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea with the availability of Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez and uncertainty over Wayne Rooney.

Mr Schmidt said Google paid £10m in UK corporate taxes from 2006–2011 and that the company paid only what was legally required, arguing taxes are not optional and that if the UK changes its tax laws Google will comply and pay more or less accordingly; he advocates that corporate taxes be levied where economic activity and risk occur and calls for international tax reform and clearer rules set by politicians. Margaret Hodge proposed a new committee to oversee major firms’ tax arrangements, possibly taking evidence in secret to prevent confidentiality hiding, while Google—whose UK sales are largely routed through Ireland—has been criticised for organising affairs to minimise UK taxes; EU leaders recently agreed to tackle tax avoidance via automatic information exchange between tax authorities.

NHS Improvement says the NHS has fallen behind on reducing agency staffing costs after spending £3.6bn last year and wants to cut this by £1bn by the end of the financial year; an October cap limiting agency pay to no more than 55% above normal shift rates (excluding senior managers) has reportedly saved £600m so far but trusts remain about 10% off target. The cap covers all staff types and aims to lower agency fees and reliance on agency workers, which are costly due to agency fees and employer costs; figures do not include in-house "bank" staff or overtime for employed staff. NHS Improvement will publish league tables of trusts’ agency spending and collect data on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust amid concerns some are still paid excessive rates (examples include trusts quoted £130/hr for a surgeon vs a £76 cap and £70/hr for a junior doctor vs a £35 cap). CEO Jim Mackey warned the NHS cannot afford continued high agency spending.

Longford Town Centre, built as a modern commercial hub, became emblematic of Ireland's post-Celtic Tiger economic collapse, with local traders like Matt O'Brien reporting business down 30% at its worst and staff cuts, though he says trade has recently improved after diversifying into childrenswear and dress-hire; political debate surrounds investment priorities, with Fianna Fáil and TD Robert Troy criticizing the government and IDA for failing to attract foreign direct investment and arguing funds (such as for water meters) should instead boost broadband, while the government points to a proposed €200m Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon—which could employ about 1,000 people when it opens in 2019 but still needs planning permission—as evidence of support; local Fine Gael TD James Bannon praises the region’s natural assets for tourism, but traders urge practical measures such as free parking to further revive the local economy, concluding that recovery is beginning but more action is needed.

The tournament runs until 29 May at the same stadium, with eight teams each playing the others twice and the top four progressing to play-offs (Qualifier 1, Eliminator, Qualifier 2, Final). BBC Sport provides scores, fixtures and results. Leading run-scorers listed are Warner (294), Kohli (267) and De Villiers (249); most sixes Warner (12), De Villiers (12), Kohli (8); highest innings De Kock (108), Warner (90*), Gambhir (90*); leading wicket-takers McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), Rahman (7). Four current or former England players are taking part: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils) and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). The full fixture list runs from 25 April through league matches in May (many at 15:30 BST, some at 10:30), culminating in play-offs on 24, 25 and 27 May and the final on 29 May.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported 200 million more plastic carrier bags since 2013, many of which are hard to recycle and are discarded after single use, ending up in dumps and rivers and harming the environment; from October people in England will be charged 5p per plastic bag to encourage reuse, following examples in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland where charges reduced bag use, and campaigners hope the English charge will similarly cut waste and help the environment.

High winds across Wales, under a yellow warning in force until midnight Friday, caused damage and disruption: part of a school roof was ripped off at Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon, hundreds of homes lost power, train services faced delays and speed restrictions (notably between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead), and major bridges (A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge) had earlier restrictions that were later lifted as winds eased Friday evening. The highest gusts were at Mona on Anglesey; Irish Ferries canceled six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, moving passengers to cruise ferries; the National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle; and Rhyl’s Boxing Day Dip was postponed to 27 December due to a blustery Christmas weekend forecast.

Michael B. Jordan told The Hollywood Reporter he was "super excited" to reunite with Creed director Ryan Coogler on Black Panther, saying he wanted "to put a different spin on it" though he didn't specify his role; he also expressed eagerness to work with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the Fantastic Four reboot, Nyong'o voiced CGI character Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens, Nyong'o won a 2014 supporting actress Oscar for 12 Years a Slave, Boseman currently portrays Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War, and Black Panther is scheduled for release in February 2018.

The Grade-Alexandra Palace theatre, founded in 1875 and long unused but retaining much original decor and stage machinery, is slated for restoration along with the BBC studios in the east wing to host theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy and live music; the glazed east court will become public exhibition space as part of a larger project to transform Alexandra Palace into a cultural destination. The entire east wing refurbishment costs £26.6m, with the Heritage Lottery Fund contributing £18.8m, Haringey Council £6.8m, and Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust committed to raising the remaining £1m by summer 2017; if fundraising succeeds the theatre aims to reopen in 2018.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player aged 30, earned 61 England caps after debuting in 2009, was part of squads at two World Cups and two European Championships (playing only three minutes at Euro 2016), holds the record for most England Under-21 caps with 46 since 2004, and scored his sole international goal in England’s 5-0 win over Moldova during 2014 World Cup qualifying; he commented that a decision reached was “about common sense” and wished Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters success.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped a house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador after her son David, who was the only one awake because he was on FaceTime with his father, woke them when he saw flames; the house was completely destroyed and their dog and cats died, the fire apparently started from rubbish burned in the wood stove (something Mrs. Smith said she had done many times), the fire alarm did not sound, the family fled in pyjamas, and the community has since donated clothing, shoes and a bike while Mrs. Smith praises David for saving them.

Reports suggested an energy drinks company considered a £200m bid for West Ham; Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in 2010 valuing the club at £105m and now own over 85%. Since the club's move to London Stadium in August, Qatari and Chinese groups have also been linked with takeover interest. Sullivan previously said selling a minority stake to clear debts was possible but that he and Gold planned to pass ownership to their children.

At a fan-voted awards ceremony in Los Angeles described as "definitely not the Oscars," The Fault in Our Stars was the night's big winner, taking best movie while star Shailene Woodley won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award and best kiss with Ansel Elgort and dedicated her speech to author John Green; other winners included Bradley Cooper (best male performance for American Sniper), Channing Tatum (best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street), Meryl Streep (best villain for Into the Woods), Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, Rose Byrne, and Kevin Hart (comedic genius, who accepted with his children), and Robert Downey Jr., who received the Generation Award with fellow Avengers—Scarlett Johansson, Chris Evans, Chris Hemsworth, Mark Ruffalo and Jeremy Renner—onstage; the ceremony also showcased clips from upcoming summer films including Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck and Marvel's Ultron, and featured fan-voted categories like best kiss and best shirtless performance (won again by Zac Efron).

Cammy Smith, 21, joined St Mirren on loan from Aberdeen in July (having been at Dundee United), has five goals this season, and previously made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 with four goals in 89 appearances and a Scotland Under-21 cap; manager Jack Ross called him a brilliant acquisition, a mature player who adds an attacking option, and St Mirren, bottom of the Championship, host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council says warmer weather allows its Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes, aiming to fill about 145 potholes per day over the next four months, while extra staff will repair rain-damaged drainage systems and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016 on EnQuest’s Thistle platform off Shetland, six Wood Group contractors removing pipework were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM); rigging supervisor Steve Innes said workers lacked proper PPE for hours, fear cancer, and he has struggled to find work since raising concerns, while EnQuest and Wood Group say they took precautionary steps, notified the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), conducted joint investigations and medical assessments, and maintain existing NORM controls; EnQuest stated exposure was under 1% of the reportable HSE threshold, HSE confirmed it was made aware but the incident was not reportable under RIDDOR so no investigation was opened, and the union called for openness and learning from the safety incident.

Singapore’s Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007; the dealer’s manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the bronze now being returned, revelations that surfaced during a 2012 court case over antiquities trafficking. The sculpture is believed to have been taken from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, and after discussions between Singapore’s National Heritage Board and India’s Archaeological Survey of India (ASI)—which officially requested its return in May—the ACM agreed to repatriate it, noting there is no conclusive proof of theft but acknowledging the dealer’s confession of criminal possession of 150 stolen objects. The piece was one of 30 objects ACM bought from that dealer (no others are thought to be listed as stolen, though the ASI was allowed to inspect them), and the museum plans legal action to seek compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck at 15:48 (14:48 GMT) at a depth of 15.5 km with its epicentre in Garfagnana, 35 km north of Lucca; it was felt as far as Milan, Florence, Bologna and Modena, produced several lower-magnitude aftershocks, knocked out phone lines and power in Garfagnana, and prompted precautionary school evacuations though there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Italy, prone to quakes, suffered nearly 300 deaths in a 2009 L'Aquila quake; six scientists and an ex-official were later convicted in 2012 for giving "inaccurate, incomplete and contradictory" reassurance before that disaster, which contributed to deaths when residents stayed indoors. Two earthquakes last May in the same area killed more than 20 people, the strongest being magnitude-6 with significant damage.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, had doubted South Yorkshire's climate for growing fruit but finally saw results on 8 September 2016 when an unripe fruit remained attached to the plant, prompting him to say he was "literally jumping for joy."

Rockstar has delayed the game's release from 27 January to 24 March, saying it needs a few extra weeks of testing and polish and that the change was made in the game's and fans' best interests; meanwhile the company announced that online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC release, released PC screenshots promising greater detail with Los Santos and Blaine County running at 1080p/60fps and supporting up to 4K and triple-monitor setups, published the minimum PC specifications, and reminded that Grand Theft Auto V was the fastest-selling entertainment product ever upon its 17 September 2013 release, earning $1bn in three days.

Seventy-six-year-old Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery for Squint (19), a roughly 7ft (2.1m) high work from a series depicting leper squints—holes in medieval churches—whose relatively small size for his series helped prompt its entry; Simpson, a 1991 shortlisted artist who has been longlisted three other times, said the prize money will buy canvases, stretches and quality paints. Judge Ansel Krut praised Squint (19) as "quite extraordinary" and likened it to a subtle, gradually building "tone poem" with minimal but sympathetic technique, calling it an ideal winner. The biennial John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain’s oldest art awards, with past winners like David Hockney and Peter Doig and Sir Peter Blake—now the prize patron—having won the junior title in 1961.

Two pro-government Istanbul newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked almost simultaneously early Thursday: four masked assailants attacked the Yeni Safak building, windows at both papers were shattered by gunfire, and numerous spent shell casings were found; firefighters extinguished a blaze at Yeni Safak, police cordoned off the area and are hunting the assailants, no casualties were reported and no group has claimed responsibility. Last September pro-government protesters attacked the Hurriyet offices accusing it of misquoting President Erdogan.

A 24-year-old, previously under contract with the Stags and formerly with Burton, will join Marcus Bignot’s Mariners on a free transfer officially on 1 January after spending the season’s first half on loan at Crawley where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, becoming Bignot’s first signing for the club.

Arsène Wenger, whose contract runs until summer, praised interim England manager Gareth Southgate’s observational skills and experience following England’s win over Malta and draw with Slovenia, saying Southgate should prove his competency through decisions to earn the permanent job ahead of upcoming matches versus Scotland (11 November) and Spain (15 November); Wenger also dismissed speculation linking himself to the role and stressed competency over big names. Before Arsenal’s game with Swansea, Wenger said 21-year-old right-back Héctor Bellerín — who has nearly three years left on his contract and has been linked with Barcelona and Manchester City — will be offered a new contract and that, for him, Bellerín’s long-term future is at Arsenal. He also confirmed midfielder Aaron Ramsey (25) will miss “one or two” more games with a hamstring injury suffered on 14 August.

Officers say a local man employed at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday; Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint inquiry, and the company is fully cooperating.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement that will transfer contracted services back to operator Serco Northlink next month to resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight vessels, Hellier and Hildasay, which the RMT union said had crew paid under £4 an hour; Seatruck, which had been operating the ships for Serco, argued the UK minimum wage did not apply to many non-UK crew and declined Serco Northlink’s offers to bridge and backdate pay, while the new charter will ensure all crew are paid at least the minimum wage once financial and regulatory details are finalised.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at Rockley Park, Poole; Jamie Mitchell, 35, of Apple Close, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother and had pleaded guilty to common assault, while he and his mother Samantha, 57, also of Apple Close, admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about events—initially telling police Mr Dickie had pushed Mrs Mitchell and she pushed back, later saying Jamie tried to push the couple apart causing a "tragic accident"—the jury returned a verdict that left Jamie visibly shaking and saying "yes," and the pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, nicknamed "The Invisible Man," died in London last week aged 66 after a brief aggressive battle with cancer, his family requesting privacy; a prolific British songwriter born in Cleethorpes, he rose from playing keyboards in 1970s disco group Heatwave—writing hits such as Boogie Nights, Always & Forever and Groove Line—to penning multiple songs for Quincy Jones and Michael Jackson, including Off the Wall, Rock With You, Burn This Disco Out, Thriller, Baby Be Mine and The Lady in My Life, which helped make Thriller the best‑selling US album (32 million copies), and his songs were recorded by artists from Anita Baker to Aretha Franklin; he won a Grammy in 1990 for Birdland, earned two Oscar nominations in 1986 for The Color Purple soundtrack, and was widely mourned by peers including Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan and BBC's Gilles Peterson.

Researchers including Swansea's Dr Neil Loader and Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, with teams from Exeter, Reading and Brazilian universities, have found over 450 large geometrical ditched enclosures—or geoglyphs—in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon, possibly about 2,000 years old and long concealed by bamboo-dominated rainforest until recent deforestation revealed them. The sites are unlikely to be villages or defensive works because of few artefacts and their layouts; instead they were probably sporadic ritual gathering places, though unlike visible Maya pyramids these geoglyphs appear to have been built beneath tall canopy vegetation, calling their purpose into question. Dr Loader’s analyses of phytoliths, charcoal and carbon isotopes show the geoglyphs were constructed amid taller vegetation and reveal that, contrary to the prior view of a pristine pre‑European Amazon, humans over the past 6,000 years concentrated and mixed a variety of economically valuable plant species—creating a kind of “prehistoric supermarket” or agroforestry—and there is tantalizing evidence that some of Acre’s remaining forest biodiversity still reflects these ancient practices.

Australian 21-year-old Nick Kyrgios, ranked a career-high 12th and fresh off winning the Japan Open, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round; Kyrgios said fatigue, poor sleep, travel to the Qi Zhong Stadium and recent travel had left him tired and quieter than usual, and he was previously fined $1,500 at last year's Shanghai Masters for a foul-mouthed outburst.

Scientists, charities and medical organisations are urging the Welsh government to extend the school HPV vaccination programme, currently given to 12- and 13-year-old girls (with an 85% uptake since its 2008 rollout), to boys to help prevent rising head and neck cancers caused by HPV. They plan to deliver a letter pressing for the change, citing increasing cases—predominantly in younger, non-smoking men around age 55—and noting HPV accounts for about 5% of the global cancer burden. The Welsh government says it will await advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering any changes.

Fifteen-year-old Jak Trueman, who had the rare gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, documented his illness and treatment on a Facebook page called Jak's Journey that amassed over 28,000 Likes; after diagnosis last August his story and positive attitude drew wide support, visits from sports figures and entertainers, and fundraising efforts for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. In January doctors found his cancer had spread and ceased further treatment; he vowed to make the most of whatever time remained. He briefly attended a prom held in his honour, where he was greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson, received a Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy, and later died, a fact announced by his mother on Facebook.

In a low-chance Group D match in Port-Gentil, Egypt beat Uganda 1-0 thanks to Abdallah El Said’s 89th-minute close-range finish set up by Mohamed Salah, after Uganda had an earlier goal by Joseph Ochaya correctly ruled out for offside; the result leaves Egypt and Ghana contesting top spot (Ghana had already reached the quarter-finals with a 1-0 win over Mali), while Uganda—making their first tournament appearance since 1978—are eliminated and now must beat Mali in their final group game with Mali needing specific results to qualify.

Lancashire County Council has identified land at the former Glenburn Sports College and the unused Westbank campus of Skelmersdale College as preferred sites for a new railway station after Network Rail compared these and a site near the Concourse shopping centre; the council, which owns Glenburn, says the plans developed with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council could provide Skelmersdale with two direct trains per hour to Liverpool, and that the preferred location allows for future expansion, good highway access and connectivity; the authority will begin acquiring the land.
Police searching a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning discovered plants in "an elaborate grow house" and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

A 28-year-old German woman of Kurdish origin was found with serious injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, late on Sunday after having been dragged by the neck through several streets; she underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner from nearby Bad Muender, also a German of Kurdish origin, handed himself in and is now in custody. Prosecutors say the motive is unclear, police have secured the scene, and are asking witnesses to come forward.

A study of 4,600 workers using the 2013–14 Australian workplace relations survey found women ask for pay rises as often as men but are less likely to receive them: when comparing like-for-like full-time with full-time and part-time with part-time workers, men who asked were 25% more likely than women to get a raise. The research found no support for the idea that women are more reticent to ask or more fearful of upsetting bosses, and results accounted for employer size, industry, parental status and qualifications. Co-authors noted surprise at the findings, suggesting an element of discrimination, but also observed that men and women under 40 asked for and received raises at similar rates, indicating younger women may be negotiating more successfully.

Oxford City Council has spent funds on ground investigations for potential new burial sites but found none suitable; two existing cemeteries (Wolvercote and Botley) have space only until about 2018 and 2021, and after they are full only reopening family plots, a few reserved plots and ash interments will be possible. Council member Linda Smith said they have long searched for new sites but, as with housing, suitable land in Oxford has been exhausted—identified council-owned sites were ruled out due to size, ground conditions, high water table or restrictive covenants. The last increase in Oxford’s burial space was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July will offer an augmented-reality app allowing visitors to trigger online content from signs and posters—including videos and band interviews—viewable on phones and tablets; acts this year include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean, and director Caroline Maclennan says the feature both enhances the on-site experience and lets people worldwide access updated messages, interviews, ticketing and festival atmosphere before and during the event.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse Many Clouds collapsed and died after narrowly beating Thistlecrack to win the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham; veterinary staff treated him but he was pronounced dead and the British Horseracing Authority confirmed a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage" as the cause. The BHA’s acting chief veterinary officer, Tony Welsh, said such episodes are rare, can occur in horses without underlying health issues, and the sport seeks to better understand and prevent them. Many Clouds had shown prior post-race ataxia symptoms—overheating and "wobbling"—and received treatment and close welfare monitoring after his Grand National win, but had not shown ataxia in this race; he had previously won the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup, was described by trainer Oliver Sherwood as the "horse of a lifetime," and this report concludes his death was due to a rarely seen racetrack haemorrhage rather than significant underlying health problems.

A 15-year-old girl met David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004; Ayrton, now 34 and living as Davina, was charged with raping the teenager in the garage while two others slept, a crime the victim said she vividly remembered despite having drunk one and a half cans of Foster's; Ayrton denied the charge at trial in Portsmouth Crown Court, spoke about her sexuality and said she had made no physical changes or taken medication, and had changed her name in 2012; the court heard Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide the previous summer, told a care-home worker in 2014 about the attack; Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody—likely at a male prison in Winchester—with protocols in place for her detention, saying bail posed substantial risks and sentencing is set for 4 March.

The Serbs lost 6-4, 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, a day after Novak Djokovic was eliminated from the singles by Argentina's Juan Martin del Potro; Djokovic, world number one and 12-time Grand Slam winner, had earlier suffered a surprise third-round Wimbledon loss to Sam Querrey but then won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada and the US will compete Saturday in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms using only chainsaws (no other carving tools) to carve logs into animals and people; last year’s winner Pete Bowsher of Moffat will return to defend the Claymore Trophy.

Tommy Webb, 27, who has been out since a serious foot injury during a World Cup warm-up in September, says he's close to returning and is in a pre-season stage of rehab, taking progress week by week and hoping to be ready before Wales' Six Nations opener at Dublin on 7 February. Capped 16 times, he has renewed a national dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay with his home region where he debuted in 2007, saying he wants to put himself in the best position to play for Wales.

Border agents near Sumas, Washington, encountered two men with backpacks five miles east of the border and say they interrupted an attempt to smuggle 58 lb (26 kg) of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco; when ordered to stop one man dropped his pack, fired at agents and fled while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was detained. Canadian and US police searched and Abbotsford police arrested Nathan Hall, whose backpack allegedly contained a California licence bearing the name William Nickerson but Hall’s photo. Investigators later arrested Kali Henifin of Bellingham, who allegedly planned to pick them up, and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, who reportedly expected $11,000 to drive the drugs to San Francisco; Henifin said they fled after hearing a police radio report of a shooting. The three in US custody face conspiracy, possession and distribution charges; the area is a known smuggling route and such prosecutions are a major focus of the US attorney for the Western District of Washington.

Childline reported counselling over 4,500 children in the past year about online abuse, up from about 2,400 in 2011–12, with the true number likely much higher; victims include children as young as seven who are tormented, abused and scared to go to school. The charity says online trolls cause widespread misery and humiliation, with cyber-bullying following children home and becoming inescapable persecution unless adults—parents, teachers—and schools intervene. Dame Esther Rantzen called the figures a wake-up call and urged adults to protect children and encourage them to ask for help. The report coincides with the start of Anti-Bullying Week coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which is working with parents, schools and other organisations to combat the problem; a quoted young victim described being told to kill themself by online peers and feeling helpless because parents don’t understand how upset they are.

Following the UN Security Council's passage of a resolution condemning Israeli settlement construction—which the US abstained from and which Netanyahu angrily accused the White House of helping draft and push—Israel rejected the resolution and retaliated diplomatically and with aid cuts; more than 500,000 Jews live in about 140 settlements built since 1967, which are deemed illegal under international law though Israel disputes this. The resolution declared settlements have no legal validity and are a major obstacle to a two-state solution; anger focused particularly on East Jerusalem. Netanyahu summoned the US and other ambassadors, recalled envoys to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal and canceled a Ukrainian visit. Plans to vote on 492 new homes in Ramat Shlomo and Ramot were postponed at the prime minister's office request to avoid straining relations with Washington ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech outlining his vision for ending the conflict; Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas said the resolution paves the way for a 15 January French peace conference.

The passage describes BBC coverage and events marking the Queen's 90th birthday: Prince William praised the Queen as a guiding example and discussed his own approach to duty, acknowledging criticism of being "work-shy" but saying he will take on responsibility when appropriate; political leaders, including David Cameron and Jeremy Corbyn, expressed birthday wishes in Parliament. Celebrations included the release of ten commemorative stamps (one sheet showing four generations), the Queen and Prince Philip visiting Windsor Royal Mail delivery office—marking the postal service's 500th anniversary—attending the opening of a new bandstand where schoolchildren sang Happy Birthday, unveiling a plaque for The Queen's Walkway on her actual birthday, and the Queen lighting a beacon to start over 900 beacons worldwide; Barack and Michelle Obama were due to lunch with her at Windsor Castle the following day. The passage also notes republican group Republic criticized the BBC's coverage as unbalanced and celebratory rather than proportionate.

West Ham beat Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup after taking control before half-time with quick goals from Diafra Sakho (his first since November, created by Sam Byram) and Andre Ayew, both finishing into the same bottom corner; West Ham could have scored more as James Collins and Sam Byram had chances and Angelo Ogbonna’s header was cleared off the line by Kyle Storer, while keeper Jonathan Flatt made a save to deny Sakho from Ayew’s cross. Cheltenham, unchanged from their recent league defeat, offered respectable moments — notably Harry Pell’s volley and Jordon Forster’s header, and a near-miss by substitute Dan Holman — but did not seriously trouble West Ham’s goalkeeper; Cheltenham’s exit eliminated League Two from the competition.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died after Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, failed to see him and turned his VW Transporter right on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion, causing a fatal collision; Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years, with prosecutors noting the victim’s family saw no value in imprisonment, describing the crash as a momentary lapse, while Werner expressed remorse and had no explanation.

Imran Khawaja, 27, from Southall, west London, is described as one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return from Syria after leaving the UK in January and fighting with Rayat al Tawheed, an Islamic State‑affiliated group that produced slick propaganda aimed at British recruits; masked in online videos and images, he posted battlefield footage, appeals for donations, life diaries and gruesome scenes including a photo of him holding a severed head. MI5 monitored him and arrested him in June when he attempted to re‑enter Britain—having faked his own death online and enlisted his cousin Tahir Bhatti to help bring him home—leading to prosecutions at the Old Bailey; Khawaja, held in Belmarsh’s high‑risk terrorism unit, has admitted four offences, Bhatti has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender, and an original additional charge of soliciting to murder will lie on file.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season for Wrexham, who finished eighth; he turned down a new Wrexham contract and has become Barnsley's third signing for next season, with caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praising his pace and attacking style.

Bottles began washing up at Poldhu Cove on the Lizard and nearby coves after a container is thought to have gone overboard from a ship during stormy weather; National Trust volunteers are clearing them because they may threaten wildlife, and witnesses say some sealed bottles have leaked. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency confirmed the MV Blue Ocean lost a container of 'Vanish' but said there is no definitive evidence linking those bottles to the Cornish beach finds. Cornwall Wildlife Trust and conservationists are highly concerned about detergent harming sensitive marine life.
