Cornwall Council, working with partners including the Maritime and Coastguard Agency and Natural England, will monitor beaches; the National Trust has cleared bottles at Poldhu and the public are advised to keep children and dogs away and not to recover any bottles.

A crash on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00 caused several people to receive minor injuries, led to the road being closed with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road, and is under ongoing Police Scotland inquiry.

Dervite, 28, a French centre-back who joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions, made 14 appearances last season to help Wanderers finish second in League One and achieve promotion; manager Phil Parkinson said Dervite had been "a bit of a forgotten man" but contributed excellently late in the campaign, and he has signed a new contract with Bolton alongside David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan following promotion to the Championship.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being willing to "concede everything" after cooperation between the two opposition parties—previously used to inflict defeats on the government over EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal—collapsed when MPs rejected those amendments; Lib Dems insisted on the amendments while Labour deferred to the Commons, prompting a Labour Lords source to call Lib Dem actions "grandstanding" and criticise them for raising "false hope" for worried people, while Lib Dem Europe spokesperson Baroness Ludford accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans" and aligning with Conservatives on a hard Brexit; despite a history of joint opposition on issues from higher education to housing and Ludford saying Lib Dems will keep working with peers across the House, the Labour source foresaw "residual tensions" and little appetite for social unity, though leaderships will remain "business-like."

The passage argues that defence is a low-priority issue in the current election despite growing global instability; polls and politicians show little appetite to prioritise it, and manifestos offer scant detail. UK armed forces have been significantly cut—regular Army down from 102,000 to 82,000, Royal Navy 19 warships, RAF eight (soon seven) frontline fast-jet squadrons—and capability gaps exist (no Maritime Patrol Aircraft, reliance on NATO for submarine hunting). The UK has fallen from fourth to sixth in global defence spending and likely will miss NATO’s 2% GDP guideline (projected to drop to 1.7% or lower without an extra £25bn over five years), undermining credibility with the US. Further MoD cuts appear likely as parties aim to reduce the deficit; Conservatives promise Trident replacement, 1% annual equipment budget growth and no further army size cuts, constraining savings, while Labour avoids firm commitments. Trident and successor submarines (estimated £20bn; large share of equipment spending) are contentious—parties differ on CASD and some favour scrapping the deterrent—so a post‑election Strategic Defence Review is expected. Major procurements like two new aircraft carriers and F‑35s face manpower and equipment shortfalls (planned carriers difficult to crew; only 12 F‑35s planned aboard despite capacity for 36), risking a “hollow force” unable to sustain Britain’s traditional claim to punch above its weight.

Barcelona denied wrongdoing over Neymar's transfer but said it made an additional tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to cover potential differing interpretations of fiscal obligations related to the deal; the club insists the original tax payment was correct. Barca paid £48.6m (57m euros) for 22-year-old Santos striker Neymar, whose parents received £34m, and when including initial fee, signing-on fee, wages over five years, agents' fees and the extra tax payment the total cost to the club is £106.8m. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriation and is under investigation but denies wrongdoing. A Spanish judge recently ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer, and it is unclear whether the case will be dropped after Barcelona’s payment. Neymar has scored seven league goals in 18 appearances and three goals in seven Champions League matches this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, of Nottingham, was killed when a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way by 77-year-old Albert Kenneth Newman collided with the van in which Luciw was a passenger on 12 October near Kegworth; Newman also died and Luciw’s colleague and driver Andy Harrington was seriously injured. Luciw’s family, who described him as a generous delivery driver and father of a baby girl, urged regular driving tests for older or retired drivers, arguing slowed reactions and calling for in-car assessments or medical checks; Harrington also backed medical examinations. The DVLA said drivers over 70 must renew licences every three years via self-assessment and notify medical conditions but has no plans to restrict licences by age, arguing evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents, while Age UK emphasized supporting older people to drive safely for as long as possible.

Many women have reported painful, debilitating side effects from transvaginal mesh or tape implants used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse; over 20,000 women in Scotland have had such implants in the past 20 years and more than 400 are pursuing legal action. An independent review concluded these procedures should not be offered routinely for pelvic organ prolapse, recommended offering a range of treatments with full information for informed choice, and called for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Two patient members and a consultant resigned in protest, alleging parts of the final report had been removed and criticizing the review as watered-down; Tracey Gillies, who took over as chair late in the process, apologized for failing to achieve consensus. Professor Alison Britton will examine how the review reached its conclusions, while the health secretary said the government cannot ban the procedures because that authority lies with the UK regulator, the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British indoor 5,000m record at Glasgow's Emirates Arena with a time of 14:49.12, 14 seconds faster than the previous mark; McColgan said she was excited her record was broken but had questioned whether Muir's mixed 3,000/5,000m race—in which Muir was the only athlete to complete 5K and lapped other runners—met UK Athletics criteria such as being a "genuine race" and having drug testing, though British Athletics said the time is expected to be ratified and rules do not require doping control for a British record at events without it; McColgan praised Muir's talent, suggested she could run nearer 14:30 and win world medals with better race tactics, and noted similarities to her own solo record race, while Muir has also held and broken the British 1500m record and reached the 1,500m Olympic final in Rio 2016.

Germany's Jung won riding Sam (a late replacement after Fischertakinou's July infection) to take gold, France's Astier Nicolas silver and American Phillip Dutton bronze; GB's William Fox-Pitt, 47, finished 12th after leading post-dressage but dropping to 21st following cross-country time penalties despite a faultless final show-jumping on Chilli Morning, and had returned to competition just 10 months after an induced coma from a fall. Ireland's Jonty Evans was ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift. The passage also mentions attending Official Team GB fan parks to meet and ride Henry the mechanical horse, a special guide to getting into equestrian, and a BBC Sport newsletter subscription.

Andy Murray beat Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in a 2hr 39min match, clinching match point at 20:57 BST to reach the last 16 at Wimbledon for the 11th time and will face Benoit Paire in the fourth round; Murray said the match was tense and not his best, noted fading light and potential roof delay, and that he hadn’t moved as well but has days to recover. Fognini, the 29th seed, had five set points to force a fifth set, showed both strong and temperamental play (including a penalty for an obscenity and an ankle issue), double-faulted early, rallied to level the match, but lost momentum as Murray won five consecutive games late to seal victory. Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week with a 6-4 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari.

Paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014; police later found patrons still in the bar and till receipts indicated alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. At Limavady Magistrates Court, license holder Colleen O'Neill, 43, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours and James Thomas, 44, faced one count; the defence admitted the premises had not been properly run and licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly adhered to. The judge, describing O'Neill’s record as "appalling" and the case as exceptionally bad, ordered the bar closed for three months and fined O'Neill £3,000 and Thomas £1,000, expressing concern he lacked power to impose a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt, launching the Ulster Unionist manifesto titled "Real Partnership," said "Domination doesn't work, partnership does" and suggested post-election cooperation could include the SDLP rather than Sinn Féin, a remark that drew attention after colleague Danny Kennedy publicly distanced himself; Nesbitt defended his comment, saying he wouldn't withdraw it and stressing voters should back Ulster Unionists and then any candidate they trust, noting he had received support while campaigning in unionist areas. The manifesto calls for action on waiting lists, raising PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritising the York Street interchange, standing up for the LGBT community, guaranteeing no group is worse off because of Brexit, and cleaning up Stormont, and the party wants the election framed as a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle and on "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption."

Justice Minister Claire Sugden secured executive agreement to bring a legislative consent motion before the assembly to pardon convictions for abolished sexual offences, aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales' recently announced "Turing's Law"; the motion is expected to mirror those provisions by granting posthumous pardons and allowing living gay and bisexual men to apply for pardons, with arrangements to be implemented "as soon as possible" to provide equal treatment and quicker redress than an assembly bill.

Laura Muir, 23, from Kinross finished second to Faith Kipyegon in 4:19.12, setting a Scottish record and surpassing Yvonne Murray's 1994 time of 4:22.60; the time places her second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd (4:17.57). Muir, who also holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records and finished fifth at last year's World Championships, said she was pleased as it was her first race of the season at the distance and was encouraged by closing so near to Kipyegon. She hopes to secure a place for Great Britain at the Rio Olympics at the British trials in Birmingham (24–26 June), began the season with an 800m win in Montbeliard last week, will next run a 1500m in Stockholm, and fits training around veterinary studies, having just completed her fourth year; Murray's husband Tom Mooney posted Yvonne's congratulations on Facebook.
The passage states that it contains some pictures from the 26 beaches in Scotland that were ranked as "most excellent" for water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC told an inquiry that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, but that the Russian state "is likely to have been the sponsor of this plot" and had many reasons to wish him death; Litvinenko, who defected to the UK in 2000 and had publicly attacked Putin and accused the FSB of murders and corruption, drank tea laced with polonium-210 during a 2006 meeting with Kovtun and Lugovoi and died nearly three weeks later. Horwell said the presence of polonium indicates some form of Russian state participation, though he stressed this did not implicate President Putin personally or prove he ordered it, and he argued the suspects left a "trail of polonium" with no credible answer to the scientific evidence. He added Litvinenko was poisoned twice before his death, the risk to the London public from polonium exposure will never be fully known, attempts to extradite the men have failed so trial is unlikely, Kovtun was criticized for not giving evidence, and the inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed Australia’s ongoing one-day and stand-in Twenty20 captain with David Warner, 28, named vice-captain; national selector Rod Marsh praised Smith’s talent and suitability to succeed Michael Clarke after Clarke, 34, retired following Australia’s Ashes loss that left England 3-1, noting Smith had previously captained in three Tests during Clarke’s injury. Smith has played 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Marsh acknowledged Warner’s past disciplinary issues but said he has matured and will handle the added leadership responsibility; Smith and Warner will lead the team in the limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test at the Oval beginning 20 August.

Tim Farron, after winning the Liberal Democrat leadership, told the BBC he is "passionate about LGBT-plus rights," will prioritize defending and extending equal marriage, and wants to remove the spousal veto that limits transgender people's marital rights; however, he repeatedly refused on Channel 4 to say whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead saying "we are all sinners." He defended his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill by citing concerns about "protection of individual liberties"—saying the Lib Dems had tabled an amendment and when it was defeated he voted against the bill—while asserting he is "absolutely in favour of equal access under law for all people whatever their sexuality."

Accord Healthcare will reopen and use the former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, closed in 2015 with the loss of 450 jobs, aiming to fill many positions with ex-Sanofi staff; the company and local leaders expect the investment to have an "extremely positive" impact, boost the local economy, strengthen Newcastle and the North East's science and healthcare reputation, and bring highly skilled jobs and long-term investment; Accord develops, manufactures and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to about 60 countries.

Richard Ellis is leaving Friday at the end of his contract; Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance, has also been acting as deputy chief executive; Monaghan heads the chief executive's office and Sutherland leads human resources and customer services. SNP opposition leader Stephen Flynn said the departures show the council cannot retain senior staff and he expects more to leave in coming months. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the three for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants detonated explosives at the gate of Kabul’s 400‑bed Sardar Daud hospital, entered with guns and grenades, and opened fire on staff and patients before commandos who landed on the roof killed all four attackers after several hours; more than 50 people were wounded and TV footage showed people hiding on ledges outside upper‑floor windows. The so‑called Islamic State claimed the attack, the Taliban denied involvement, and Afghan leaders including President Ashraf Ghani and Abdullah Abdullah condemned it; the assault, beginning at 09:00 local time, is seen as a shift by IS fighters—using tactics like blowing gates to engage security forces in the capital rather than primarily targeting civilian Shia gatherings—and suggests IS may now have increased resources and training to expand attacks despite being under pressure in eastern bases.

English rider Martin said the Fireblade has suffered mechanical problems and after crashing at this year's TT he announced he was quitting road racing but later clarified on Facebook that he hasn't given up on racing or road racing entirely, only that he has no plans to do more road races on Hondas this year. He skipped the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness crashed in practice and will not compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix, which the team withdrew him from after he warned the bike wouldn't be competitive. Describing the TT as "a bloody disaster," Martin said he ended up acting as a test rider, didn't enjoy the event aside from walking the dog and racing the Mugen, feels there's no unfinished business, and wants to race classics and oddball events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governorships declared from Saturday’s elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999 and reinforcing PDP’s loss of last month’s presidential poll to APC’s Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on 29 May; PDP won eight governorships mainly in the south-east, held Rivers State, lost in key northern states including Katsina and Kaduna and in Adamawa, while Taraba remains outstanding and Imo was inconclusive, with elections not held in seven states. Analysts say APC’s gains have relegated PDP to a regional party with support concentrated in the south-east and Niger Delta, as most northern states and Lagos went to APC, though APC won none of the five oil-producing states—raising concerns about oil revenue and militant disruption for the incoming president. Elections saw 66 violent incidents reported by INEC, mostly in southern states like Rivers, but were overall more peaceful than previous years; PDP’s long rule, defections to APC, allegations of corruption and perceived failure to tackle the Islamist insurgency are cited as reasons for its defeat and the need for party introspection and rebuilding.

A US environmental group, Mighty, alleges in a report that agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder Temasek may be linked to unsustainable palm-oil practices—including sourcing from rogue suppliers and contributing to slash-and-burn haze affecting Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia—claims both Olam and Temasek deny. Olam says it buys 99% of its palm oil from third parties, accounts for under 1% of the global market, enforces a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy, has agreed to release its 14 supplier names, and is still vetting suppliers; it will remove non-compliant producers. Temasek states it supports no-burn policies, does not direct portfolio companies’ operations, and rejects Mighty's allegations. The passage notes the palm-oil industry's global issues with deforestation, burning and labor abuses, tensions between NGOs and industry over policing third-party suppliers, and Mighty's additional claim that Olam clears rainforests in Gabon—an accusation Olam counters by saying its Gabon public–private partnerships are responsible, transparent and limited to converting a small percentage of low-value forest for agriculture.

A restaurant began serving "puppy platters" after a new law allowed dogs to eat at restaurants provided they were outdoors; a clip shows what appears to be a chaotic or messy scene described as "a right dog's dinner."

Forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee issue, having only been able to appear from the bench in the last two games; Derby County striker David Nugent (groin) could return after missing Monday's draw with Huddersfield; and midfielder Jacob Butterfield, who came off the bench to score a late leveller against the Terriers, is hoping for a recall.

Pakistan lifted its 2012 YouTube ban after Google launched a Pakistan-specific YouTube; the telecom regulator directed ISPs to restore access, and the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority said Google has provided a web process for the PTA to request blocking of offending material for Pakistani users. Young Pakistanis welcomed the move but activists demand transparency about the deal’s terms. YouTube denied that authorities can filter content automatically, saying removal follows its community guidelines and that government removal requests are reviewed and recorded in its Transparency Report. The 2012 ban followed the upload of the US-made amateur film Innocence of Muslims, which provoked deadly protests; blasphemy is a crime in Pakistan that can carry the death penalty. Google also launched local YouTube versions for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian like presidential candidate Gianni Infantino; Liberia Football Association boss Musa Bility demands Scala withdraw by Thursday or he will take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, citing Article 7.4 which bars committee members with conflicts of interest, and noting Scala and Claudio Sulser stepped aside in 2015 when incumbent Swiss Sepp Blatter was a candidate. Scala's spokesman Andreas Bantel counters that sharing nationality with a candidate is not a conflict under FIFA regulations and Scala only voluntarily withdrew in 2015 as a precaution because the candidate was the incumbent; with five candidates now and no incumbent, Bantel says no conflict exists. Bility, who was denied eligibility to run in November and has pledged his vote to Prince Ali, demands explanation for the different treatment before the 26 February election, warning the Liberian FA will challenge if Scala does not resign within three working days; the vote by FIFA's 209 members in Zurich will choose among Prince Ali, Infantino, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman and Tokyo Sexwale to replace Blatter.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while believed to be working in a paint-spraying area at Harford Attachments, which makes buckets for diggers, on Spar Road; their bodies were removed Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search has been carried out at the company, and Det Ch Insp Paul Durham said progress had been made with forensic inquiries and witness statements, with evidence suggesting a flashover explosion from a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition caused a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive said its inspectors and electrical safety experts would be gathering evidence.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologising to CAF over complaints stemming from a controversial late penalty they contested in the 2015 quarter-final against host Equatorial Guinea, while Morocco were allowed back into the 2017 qualifying draw after CAS overturned a ban and reduced their fine related to being stripped of the 2015 hosting rights over Ebola fears; Tunisian FA vice-president Maher Snoussi and Moroccan FA chief Fouzi Lekjaa said relations with CAF have been mended following meetings with CAF president Issa Hayatou, and the 2017 draw placed Tunisia in Group A with Togo, Liberia and Djibouti and Morocco in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya and Sao Tome, with Tunisia able to extend a potential record to 13 consecutive Nations Cups if they qualify.

Manchester City were charged after a mass fracas in the 95th minute of the Etihad Stadium match Chelsea won 3-1; City players Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off (Aguero received a four-match ban for a second violent conduct dismissal this season after a high, late challenge on David Luiz; Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban after clashing with Cesc Fabregas), while Fabregas will face no further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologised for his team's part, and both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Cynlluniwyd prawf peilot yng Nghwm Cynon a Chastell-nedd i ganolbwyntio ar gleifion heb symptomau clir ond y mae meddygon teulu yn amau bod ganddyn nhw ganser, gan ganiatáu i feddygon teulu gyfeirio o fewn saith diwrnod at ganolfannau diagnostig yn Ysbyty Brenhinol Morgannwg, Llantrisant (40 meddyg, tua chwech o gleifion yr wythnos) ac yn nes ymlaen Ysbyty Castell-nedd Port Talbot; nod y cynllun, a ddatblygwyd ar ôl ymweliad â Denmarc a sefydlu canolfannau diagnostig yno, yw lleihau oedi mewn diagnosis (lle mae cleifion heb symptomau aml yn cael eu cyfeirio nôl ac ymlaen ac yn dioddef oedi wythnosau), codi cyfraddau diagnosis cynnar a chyfyngu ar achosion sy’n dechrau trin pan fo’r canser eisoes datblygedig, gan ddechrau gydag arbrofion chwe mis yng Nghwm Cynon ac ehangu’r gwasanaeth os yw’n llwyddiannus.

England beat Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, levelling the series after scoring 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared to set up their second biggest run win over Pakistan; Joe Root, promoted to number three, was man of the match for his 254 and an unbeaten 71, plus four catches and a wicket, while captain Alastair Cook made 105 and 76 not out. Commentators praised England’s batting, bowling and discipline on a pitch offering little to bowlers, with Geoffrey Boycott saying Pakistan’s spirit was broken and Michael Vaughan calling it possibly the best Test innings from Root; Pakistan managed only two scores above 50 in the series so far (Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq), and Misbah lamented poor shot selection and confidence as Pakistan prepared for a Worcestershire tour game before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand and has named Rob Howley as interim coach in his backroom team, while forwards coach McBryde will assume head coach duties for the third time after previous Wales tours in 2009 and 2013; McBryde described it as an honour and an exciting opportunity he looks forward to at season’s end. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to support McBryde and is in advanced discussions to confirm the full management team next week, WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips said. Union chairman and Lions selector Gareth Davies believes Welsh coaches’ involvement will benefit national rugby, calling 2017 a “summer of opportunity” that will develop coaches, invigorate players, and provide the ultimate test in New Zealand to mentally stimulate and inspire individuals.

Hull came from behind to beat Southampton 2-1 at the KCOM Stadium after Charlie Austin’s sixth-minute penalty put the visitors ahead; Hull lost strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries but introduced Robert Snodgrass, who scored in the 61st minute and provided the free-kick that Michael Dawson headed home shortly after. David Marshall made several key saves and Sam Clucas produced a late goalline clearance to secure Hull’s first league win since 20 August, ending a six-game losing streak though they remain in the bottom three; managers Mike Phelan and Claude Puel both reflected on injuries, concentration and lessons to take into the international break.

A collision at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton near Woodhall Spa involved a motorcyclist, who was killed, and a tractor whose driver was uninjured; Lincolnshire Police said the motorcyclist was a local resident but gave no further details, appealed for witnesses, and closed the B1191 both ways between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov canceled an investigation into alleged abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, saying he wanted to "put an end to the agony" before early June elections and claiming to "defend national interests"; his action—condemned by opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who called it illegal and urged protests that drew several hundred people, and by EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who said it undermined the rule of law and risked Macedonia's EU hopes—follows a crisis sparked by recordings since February 2015 that Zaev says show ministers plotting vote-rigging, wiretapping 20,000 people, corruption, misuse of funds, dubious prosecutions and even cover-ups of murder, claims the government denies while accusing Zaev of trying to destabilize the country, a charge he rejects.

After Bob Bradley was sacked, Curtis and assistant Paul Williams will take charge for Saturday's match while Swansea seek a permanent manager, with ex-Derby boss Paul Clement the preferred candidate; Curtis emphasized urgency to avoid relegation and warned that dropping to the Championship would make immediate promotion difficult given stronger competition and the club’s limited ability to retain top players. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011 after a rise from near-bankruptcy and almost leaving the Football League in 2003, built a reputation for possession-based football but, Curtis says, have lost direction since Michael Laudrup’s 2014 departure due to frequent managerial changes and player turnover, diluting the “Swansea Way.” He believes the current squad can still stay up and tells new signings about the club’s history (via the Jack to a King documentary) to instill the importance of survival for the club and the community.

Dagenham & Redbridge, promoted to League One in 2010 and to the Football League for the first time in 2007, were relegated to the National League after a defeat in which Jay Simpson put Leyton Orient 2-0 up before Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona halved the deficit and Armand Gnanduillet scored the winner to keep Orient's play-off hopes alive; Dagenham, managed by John Still who returned in December for his third spell, finish with League Two's worst goal difference, having conceded 20 more goals than at the same point last season and struggled offensively (40-year-old Cureton has nine goals compared with 20 in 2014–15), while Still vowed to help the club seek promotion back from the National League and reflected that a lack of organisation and discipline this season has prevented Dagenham responding to defeats.

Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to his former club in February as a youth coach — his first role since retiring in November after a 19-year playing career — and Klopp, who praised Gerrard’s desire to become a manager, called the appointment “wonderful news.” Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998 and left in 2015 for LA Galaxy after winning the Champions League, UEFA Cup, FA Cup and three League Cups, has been linked with the MK Dons job but felt it was “too soon,” and is working toward his UEFA A coaching licence required for Premier League management.

McManus opened the scoring around the 15th minute and Ross Forbes’ deflected strike soon made it 2-0 to Morton; Kyle McAusland pulled one back for Alloa before half-time, but a second McManus goal and a late Denny Johnstone strike secured a comfortable home victory for Morton.

Ofsted found children being taught in squalid conditions at several unregulated education sites—18 investigated recently, mainly in Midlands Muslim communities—with three Birmingham venues closed and their owners under investigation for running illegal schools; ministers are consulting on tighter regulation (including for places teaching more than 6–8 hours a week and the existing requirement to register if teaching over 20 hours a week), have funded a six-inspector team to investigate illegal schools, and the education secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare prosecution cases (prosecution requires the Education Secretary’s consent); Sir Michael Wilshaw warned these cases may be the "tip of the iceberg" and stressed enforcement applies to all religious groups operating unsafe, unhygienic provision.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, operates from a very small production still housed in a cowshed and aims to capture local flavour using wild botanicals from the Teviot Valley to express Borders "terroir"; lead distiller Kate Macinnes and John Henderson of Born in the Borders highlight its complementarity with the on-site Scottish Borders Brewery, local sourcing ethos, and the significance of it arriving amid proposals to open the region's first whisky distillery since 1837; the gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary heroine associated with the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor (also called Lilliard's Edge), reflecting the landscape and the company's strong female production team.

Harry Whitlam was killed in August 2013 when 51-year-old Gary Green reversed a tractor into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell; Green was found to be more than twice the legal alcohol limit and had likely consumed the equivalent of 13 pints before going to bed at 02:00 BST. The incident occurred around 09:15 on private farm land in a closed-off area while Green backed the vehicle toward a worker; he admitted failing to ensure others' safety and was prosecuted under health and safety law, receiving a 16-month-and-two-week jail sentence. Whitlam’s mother, Pam, who worked at the farm café, said the family had been "changed forever," lamenting that their memories of Harry are dominated by the day of the accident, and HSE inspector Julian Franklin called the case "extremely tragic" and Green’s behavior "reckless."

The CAS ruled that Luis Suárez’s FIFA-imposed sanctions for biting Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini at the 2014 World Cup are largely upheld but were excessive in banning him from all football-related activity, so he may now train with Barcelona, play in friendlies, attend matches and take part in promotional activities, though he still must serve the remaining eight competitive international match ban of a nine-match suspension and cannot play in organised competitive games; Barcelona will present him at Camp Nou and he could debut competitively in El Clásico on 26 October, while his lawyers called the appeal a success, FIFPro expressed disappointment at the limited reduction, commentators noted the allowance to train balances club interests, and the ruling acknowledged past incidents including prior biting suspensions and a 2011 racism ban.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a 380-metre race that includes hurdling haystacks, climbing a steep slope and dodging water pistols, beating Lithuania's Vytautas Kirkliauskas carrying his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene; the competitors—who do not have to be married—included men carrying women, men carrying men and one woman carrying a woman, and Rich and Anna will compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond told Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that replacing paper car tax discs with an electronic system in October 2014, including a monthly direct-debit payment option, will likely reduce refunds and require changes to job roles and training at the DVLA, but any reductions in staff numbers would be managed by redeploying employees to other growth areas rather than by redundancies; Hedges welcomed the assurances while noting the changes will reduce DVLA job opportunities despite the advantages of direct debits and no longer needing to display a tax disc.

Hungary rejects EU interference in what it calls national matters after facing criticism over three laws — on asylum controls, higher education, and NGOs — that critics and European institutions say threaten rights and could force the Central European University (founded by George Soros) to close; Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said Poland would veto any EU move (such as stripping Hungary of voting rights, which requires unanimity), while the government of Viktor Orban has already passed two of the laws, forcibly houses asylum seekers in secured containers, and faces warnings from the European Commission that it may act if no changes occur.

The live-action Beauty and the Beast film, directed by Bill Condon and beginning filming at Shepperton Studios in May, stars Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Kevin Kline as Maurice, with an actress (previously voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury in 1991) cast as Mrs Potts; it is set for US release on 17 March 2017.

Sunday Times columnist Adrian Gill, born in Edinburgh in 1954, has died after a brief illness described as the "full English" of cancers; he had been undergoing chemotherapy and wrote a final column about his diagnosis to appear in the paper. Praised by colleagues and editors as a brilliant, fearless and compassionate writer who joined the Sunday Times in 1993 and dictated copy because of dyslexia, Gill was widely mourned by peers including Martin Ivens, Jay Rayner and former editors John Witherow and Andrew Neil. Known for both celebrated prose and frequent controversy—comments about animals, regions and public figures occasionally drew complaints and censure—he began as an art critic in the 1980s and later wrote for Tatler before the Sunday Times. Gill attended St Christopher’s, Central Saint Martins and the Slade, was married twice (to Cressida Connolly and Amber Rudd, with whom he had two children), and was engaged to longtime partner Nicola Formby, with whom he had twins.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and lead singer of Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked while performing in Ulan Bator—reportedly struck on the head with a bottle, kicked in the face, and hit with a metal object, leaving him with serious brain injuries and about 10 days in a coma, according to his father; the suspected assailant is described as a Russian diplomatic officer who has not been identified or arrested, with police saying the case is under investigation and that detention was not applied because the injury was not serious, while the Russian embassy said press and social media reports were distorted regarding details and is investigating; Sukhbaatar had worn a red deel embroidered with a swastika—a traditional Mongolian symbol predating Nazism that he and his supporters defended against social media claims he shouted "Heil Hitler"—though the symbol is also used by some Mongolian far-right groups.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid staged a protest opposing the airport's expansion on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday; those involved were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted aerodrome area and will appear in court on 19 August, and the Metropolitan Police said airport security would be reviewed.

Nick Selman scored 101 off 144 balls—his second first-class century—after being dropped on eight, with Aneurin Donald contributing 36; Glamorgan reached a total eased by Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten securing a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles regularly took wickets in cloudy conditions, keeping bowlers dominant and leaving Gloucestershire’s innings a question of survival as the day ended evenly balanced. Michael Hogan captained Glamorgan in Jacques Rudolph’s absence due to a neck problem. Selman said the wicket was slow, he’d struggled after earlier low scores but was pleased to bat through and hoped to continue form; Taylor said conditions offered assistance to bowlers, was happy to bowl them out for 220, and welcomed red-ball opportunities after white-ball appearances.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested in August by North Wales Police after he chatted online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee and made threats to make a false report so police would attend a scene he planned to ambush and shoot on the Dee Estuary; the threats, made twice late at night while he was drunk, were raised amid fears of a planned murder bid involving police being ambushed following reports of a non-existent crime. Hughes admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court, has a 2009 conviction for possessing a firearm, was remanded in custody pending sentencing next week, and during earlier proceedings his lawyers said he had not intended to kill himself and would not have carried out any threat to kill police officers; the court had been particularly concerned because he was on bail awaiting trial for firearms offences (of which he was later cleared). The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling to people in difficulty.

Surrey recovered from 8-2 to post 255-7, bolstered by an influential 130 partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes (90), while Matthew Waite took 3-48 for Yorkshire but also dropped chances; Stuart Meaker then produced a decisive three-wicket burst in nine balls (3-61) to derail Yorkshire's chase, removing Jonny Bairstow, Gary Ballance and Jack Leaning, and despite Tim Bresnan's 68 and Waite's 38 Yorkshire were all out for 236 with 27 needed off the final three overs. Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised the Davies–Foakes partnership and timely wickets, and Yorkshire captain Alex Lees said his team were "gutted," noting good white-ball form but insufficient contributions from the top five when it mattered.

A 56 ft (17.1 m) converted trawler, located 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST because an onboard pump could not cope with incoming water; the RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner and final-year veterinary medicine student, will miss next April's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast because her exams are in May and conflict with the Games; she returns to university after a week off to complete her studies, prioritizing her degree though she is "gutted" to miss representing Scotland. Muir, who finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m at the World Athletics Championships and set an outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 while placing behind Hellen Obiri (gold) and Sifan Hassan (third), says the World Indoor Championships in March is a potential target and believes she has scope for two or three more Olympics.

Robbie Savage argues Liverpool are far from repeating last season’s title challenge and may be fighting merely for a top-four finish, with last season’s overachievement raising unrealistic expectations; losing Suarez and Sturridge’s goals, plus poor striker recruitment (Balotelli, Lambert, Borini) and reduced pressing/first-half threat, have left Liverpool pedestrian and often chasing games. Set-piece effectiveness has dropped, defensive problems persist despite expensive signings (Sakho, Lovren) and no clear leader at the back, while Mignolet is a shot-stopper who lacks command of his area. Savage backs rotating the lineup after resting players at Real Madrid and proposes a XI including Toure over Lovren, and says Liverpool need solid midfield cover and overlapping full-backs to compete, but still expects Chelsea to win. On Steven Gerrard, Savage believes the 2014 slip remains a painful legacy but insists Gerrard is not finished: he can adapt to a defensive midfield role, remain part of Liverpool’s future if he maintains fitness and mental resilience, and that his desire will prolong his career.

A new Â£45m campus at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre; East Ayrshire Council plans to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name it after William McIlvanney, the Kilmarnock-born writer and former English teacher who became a full-time novelist in 1975, gained recognition with his first novel Remedy Is None, wrote the acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy plus works like Docherty and The Big Man, was dubbed the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," and was also a poet, journalist, broadcaster and commentator on politics and sport before dying at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area near the swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated for much of the morning and early afternoon and residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors, open windows and avoid going outside while an exclusion zone remained on the river as experts made safe a sea mine spotted on Monday. The device, thought to be a British mine from the 1940s or 1950s, prompted evacuation of three streets, an exclusion zone at sea of about half a mile with small boats told not to sail, and some disruption to Caledonian MacBrayne ferry sailings from Gourock and Rothesay. Police described the evacuation as precautionary and said there was no immediate danger to Gourock; the Royal Navy’s Northern Diving Unit said the mine had deteriorated so its explosive content was uncertain, necessitating moving it to a safer location before disposal. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the cordon and evacuation.

UK Sport has allocated £345m across 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo, £2m less than for Rio, setting targets of 51–85 Olympic medals and 115–162 Paralympic medals; cycling’s funding was cut by over £4m to £25.98m, and several sports including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby and notably badminton lost funding despite badminton winning a Rio bronze and previously receiving £5.74m, prompting outrage from Badminton England and GB Badminton staff; judo saw a slight increase. UK Sport and ministers defended prioritising investment to protect medal potential, noting government commitment and that £9m remains to be allocated pending medal-potential review for newly added Tokyo sports (baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sport climbing, surfing) and new Paralympic events (Para-taekwondo, Para-badminton). Team sports and some federations criticized UK Sport for abandoning development funding.

Three Victorian hotels on East Cliff in Bournemouth — Bay View Court, The Cottonwood and the Ocean View — will be demolished by The East Cliff Project LLP to make way for a six-storey, 90-room four-star hotel and two assisted-living blocks (nine and seven storeys) totaling 122 apartments; councillors voted 7–3 in favour, arguing it will boost tourism and improve housing for older people, despite English Heritage and the Ancient Monuments Society objecting that the development’s scale would cause “severe harm” to the designated conservation area and that the buildings still convey the area’s historic character; the council received 246 letters supporting the plans and 49 residents objected.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, a Royal Gibraltar Regiment soldier from Carrickfergus training at Brecon's infantry battle school, was found unconscious after being punched, beaten and dragged from outside The Cellar bar in the early hours of 8 May; Jake Vallely, 24, attacked him after a lengthy drinking binge and will be sentenced on 8 December, while Vallely's friend Aaeron Evans was cleared after jurors heard he had left before the violence; Det Supt David Guiney called the assault "a despicable act" that shocked Brecon, and Boyd's family paid tribute describing him as loving, loyal and full of life, saying Vallely had created an unfillable void though the community's support has been strong.

Andrew Travers left his role as Barnet Council chief executive by "mutual agreement" after an error that initially turned away voters from all 155 polling stations because names were missing from the poll list; an independent investigation has been launched and a council review (to conclude by end of May and reported to the General Functions Committee) will assess the appropriateness of arrangements for the EU Referendum, while deputy chief executive John Hooton will act as temporary chief executive, the council apologized, offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents, Travers blamed electoral registration lists and the council said it is discussing who will lead the investigation.

Gateshead beat Wrexham 2-1 with Josh Gillies opening from a free-kick and Ryan Bowman scoring the winner with a header from Jamie Chandler’s cross; Wrexham’s Sean Newton had equalised before half-time from a set-piece. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his side’s improved second-half passing and the quality of the winning goal, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills lamented his team’s weaker second halves and missed chances. The passage also lists numerous in-game events: shots saved or missed, fouls, free kicks, corners, substitutions (Joel Logan for Wes York, Lee Fowler for Rob Evans, Adam Smith for James Gray), and the final scoreline Gateshead 2, Wrexham 1.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates social and economic welfare of people over 60 across 96 countries; Norway ranks first while Afghanistan is last, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb plans a global broadband constellation initially of at least 600 satellites (potentially over 2,000) to connect the world—especially schools—requiring a dramatic shift to high-volume, low-cost satellite manufacturing led by Airbus with car/plane-style assembly lines in Toulouse and future lines in Florida; the first 10 satellites must launch by April, more by November, and over 20 Soyuz launches will deploy clusters to reach nearly 300 satellites by early 2021, over 600 about a year later and 800+ by mid-decade. Airbus and OneWeb emphasize rapid, cost-driven production (three units per shift at under $1M each) and aim to offer manufacturing services to others, while addressing debris-mitigation concerns by committing to de-orbit satellites within two years and adding hardware and a capture adapter to reduce collision risk. OneWeb has raised $1.7bn in equity, seeks further loans, is registered in the UK and regulated by the UK Space Agency, and faces competition from other mega-constellation bidders though Airbus claims a first-mover advantage.

The passage reports that Scottish Finance Secretary John Swinney warned the UK government's spending review has placed "unprecedented pressure" on Scotland's public spending, saying cuts imposed since 2010 plus the recent review mean Scotland's discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 compared with 2010-11, with 4.2% of that reduction occurring between now and 2019-20 and over £1bn of cuts still to come; he vowed to protect priorities like schools, hospitals, police, and tuition-free university education and noted recent improvements in outcomes. The UK Scotland Office replied that Scottish ministers will have £390m more next year (rising to £750m including underspend) and argued the block grant, nearly £30bn due to UK economic stability, is preferable to independence. Labour's Jackie Baillie urged Swinney to move beyond "anti-austerity posturing" and produce a long-term budget, saying Scottish Labour would offer an alternative with different tax decisions to both the Tories and the SNP.

The passage describes the lack of adequately equipped toilets for people with severe disabilities and the campaign to make "Changing Places" toilets—larger, specially fitted facilities with benches and hoists—mandatory in larger new buildings. Families and carers report stress, isolation and indignity when forced to change people on dirty floors or in cars because standard accessible toilets are too small or lack equipment; campaigners like Lorna Fillingham have petitioned for changes to building regulations and given evidence to a parliamentary committee. Changing Places are recommended in BS 8300:2009 but not compulsory; there are currently 893 in the UK though an estimated quarter of a million people need them. Advocates argue compulsory requirements would give designers clarity, while businesses cite space (Changing Places are 12 m² vs standard 1.5×2.2 m) and cost/logistics as barriers, especially in existing buildings. Examples of positive impact include Arsenal FC’s conversion of toilets into a Changing Place and families who can now enjoy outings—such as trips to Cardiff’s stadium—when facilities are available.

A group of Italian consumer organisations has filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission alleging McDonald's forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees, uses longer-than-average contracts to prevent switching to competitors, and leases premises to licensees at above-market rates, which they say reduces consumer choice and raises prices in franchised stores; the Service Employees International Union and European unions back the complaint, McDonald's responds it shares risks and rewards with and supports its franchisees and says its franchise model benefits franchisees and customers, the European Commission will study the submission and may investigate, and franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's European restaurants while McDonald's got $9.27bn in revenues from franchised restaurants globally in 2014.

A #prayforjosh poster appeared in Holywood by the A2 after a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin of Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when an operation for his appendix revealed a large primary cancer and five smaller growths; the hashtag began on Facebook and Instagram via Bangor Elim Church (where his father is on pastoral staff) and went viral, with updates shared 948 times and seen by over 79,000 people, attracting global support, numerous Twitter posts from his classmates, and—through an anonymous donor—funding for a large billboard at Holywood playing fields.

The passage reports on plans to close Brecon Barracks as part of a wider reorganisation of UK military facilities and regimental resettling in Wales. Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies condemned the proposal, noting the barracks’ long history since 1805 and its links to troops who fought at Rorke’s Drift, launching a petition and warning of impacts on an area with high unemployment and a military tourism industry; he said about 85 civilian staff and 90 military are based there but jobs are not thought to be at risk and nearby Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school are expected to remain unaffected. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon told MPs a specialist light infantry centre will be created at St Athan, Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire (previously slated for closure in 2013) will now close in 2024, and a storage depot at Sennybridge will close in 2025. Labour’s Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith said the ministry was right to restructure its estate but warned closures would cause “gnawing uncertainty” for many livelihoods.

The House of Lords report warns that while many UK fishing communities supported Brexit hoping to regain control of waters and boost exports, the industry is small (0.5% of GDP, 12,000 fishers) and risks being marginalised in negotiations; most commercial stocks are shared with EU states, most UK-caught fish are exported to the EU and much domestic consumption is imported, so continued market access is essential and may require trade-offs such as allowing EU boats greater access to UK waters. The report recommends retaining many Common Fisheries Policy elements—scientific-based total allowable catches and quotas and international cooperation—and cautions that leaving the EU could fragment management across England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. Some industry voices, citing recent EU quota gains and the prospect of control over a 200-mile exclusive economic zone, are optimistic about opportunities for fairer shares and sustainable management, while the government emphasizes securing trade freedom with the single market and using Brexit to review fisheries management for fair access, sustainable stocks and a healthy marine environment.

Ed Snowden, a 29-year-old former CIA technical worker, revealed he leaked documents showing the NSA conducts large-scale surveillance—accessing chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers and social networking data—and requested millions of Verizon phone records including durations, locations and numbers; documents also allege the Prism program gave "backdoor" access to servers of nine major tech firms (Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube and Apple) to collect private posts, web chats and searches, though companies deny involvement and technical details are unclear. US officials (James Clapper, Keith Alexander, Barack Obama) defend the programs as vital to security and refuse to provide details, while some experts suggest access may be limited to named targets or court orders; legal protections vary by country but generally regulate companies more than government surveillance, and US laws like the Patriot Act and FISA can give US authorities access to data stored overseas. UK and EU officials have expressed concern or declined to confirm involvement by UK agencies; privacy groups warn Prism threatens global privacy because many cloud services fall under US jurisdiction, and Snowden says he leaked out of horror at the extent of surveillance.

OpenAI, backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys and Amazon Web Services, says it will pursue AI research free from financial obligations to focus on positive human impact and to "advance digital intelligence" for the broad benefit of humanity; its statement warns both of enormous potential benefits and risks if AI is built or used incorrectly, advocates that AI be an extension of individual wills and broadly distributed, notes only a tiny fraction of its $1bn pledge will be spent in the next few years, and references warnings from scientists (including Musk and Stephen Hawking) that advanced AI could pose existential risks while other experts consider such threats remote.

Ben Parkinson, a Doncaster-based lance/bombardier seriously injured by a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack who now walks with crutches and spent 12 hours a day on gym and rehab, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June with an assistant supporting his arm and was flanked by hundreds of people; since then he has received thousands of Facebook friend requests—exceeding Facebook’s 5,000 personal-page limit—along with massive website hits, emails and offers to host the torch, which his mother Diane described as phenomenal and buoying; his nomination notes a brain injury took his speech originally but not his personality or sense of humour and that he now speaks unaided, raises money for military charities as patron of the Pilgrim Bandits, and Facebook suggested public figures should use Pages or the subscribe feature; 8,000 people will carry the flame during its 8,000-mile, 70-day London Olympic torch relay ending 27 July.

In 2011 the U.S. poverty rate was 15%, with 46.2 million people in poverty, unchanged after three years of increases; real median household income fell 1.5%; the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021; income inequality rose 1.6% as measured by the Gini index—the first annual rise since 1993; the uninsured rate fell to 15.7% from 16.3%; poverty had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

The 25-year-old Jos Buttler, who moved to Lancashire (the Red Rose) from Somerset in 2013, has signed a new deal keeping him at the club until 2019; a short-format specialist, he has scored England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball hundred against Pakistan last year, and his presence helped Lancashire win last year's T20 Blast final at Edgbaston, with cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praising his talent, dressing-room presence and international experience; Buttler, who has been playing in the Indian Premier League for Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, Campbeltown, Chatham and Cornwall—are moored in Portsmouth Harbour and up for disposal; bidders registered interest by 23 January and are finalising bids with viewings in late February and March, though the BBC understands no preservation proposals were submitted and a final decision is expected in spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess industry capacity, while Portsmouth North MP Penny Mordaunt wants recyclers given a chance but hopes at least one ship can be preserved as a reef/diving attraction to generate tourism income. The MoD will “consider all options” for best financial return and declined to disclose bid details; Type 22s were originally anti-submarine specialists that evolved into versatile surface combatants and flagships with ~280 crew. Last year HMS Ark Royal was scrapped for £3m.

Since 1987 Fiji has suffered recurring racial and political instability—starting with a 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians that toppled an Indian-dominated government and led to a short-lived constitution favoring indigenous supremacy—followed by a 2000 coup led by George Speight that saw the Indo-Fijian prime minister and others held hostage, economic damage (especially to tourism), bitter disputes over amnesty, and a 2006 military takeover; suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009 ended only after the government pledged 2014 elections and diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand were restored. The population, concentrated on Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, is split between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians (descendants of indentured Indian laborers), with Indo-Fijians leaving in large numbers by the mid-2000s so indigenous Fijians now hold a small majority; social mixing is minimal and informal segregation is widespread, alongside very small minorities (e.g., Chinese, Rotumans). Economically, Fiji—formerly a British colony—depends on sugar and tourism for foreign exchange but also mines gold, silver and limestone, has services and light manufacturing, yet faces persistent trade and budget deficits and is a major per capita aid recipient.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad defended Syria's efforts to meet the timetable to destroy its declared 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons after the country missed a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile, saying shipments to Latakia were attacked by "terrorist groups" and stressing Syria's commitment to OPCW and UN obligations; US officials say only about 30 tonnes (4%) have left so far and express concern the UN-backed plan is behind schedule, while Russia urges transfer to the coast by 1 March and the final destruction by end of June; concurrently, heavy fighting in Aleppo has been reported—human-rights and activist groups allege recent deadly barrel-bomb attacks killing scores including children and that rebels (including Ahrar al-Sham and al-Nusra) captured Aleppo central prison and freed hundreds, claims denied by state media which says soldiers repelled the attack.

The 46th Booker Prize shortlist features six novels open to all English-language authors, with Jhumpa Lahiri Mukherjee's The Lives Of Others the 5/2 favourite with William Hill and Richard Flanagan's The Narrow Road to the Deep North at 3/1; the winner will be announced Tuesday at London's Guildhall. Shortlisted authors are Howard Jacobson (J), Ali Smith (How To Be Both), Joshua Ferris (To Rise Again at a Decent Hour), Karen Joy Fowler (We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves) and Flanagan, representing Australia and the only non-British Commonwealth entrant on the list. The books range from Mukherjee's 1967 Calcutta family drama to Jacobson's futuristic J, Smith's two-part historical/contemporary How To Be Both, Ferris's New York dentist novel about online identity, Fowler's family story narrated by Rosemary, and Flanagan's WWII love story about the Thailand–Burma Death Railway. Fowler's title is by far the bestseller with over 55,000 copies sold since March; Ferris has just over 6,000 and Mukherjee saw sales jump after the shortlist announcement. The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling and includes Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven and Erica Wagner; each shortlisted author receives £2,500 and a specially bound edition, and the ceremony will be covered on BBC News Channel and BBC Arts.

A celebrity referred to as PJS is appealing an appeal-court ruling that lifted a media anonymity ban in England and Wales; the UK Supreme Court will hear whether to grant his appeal and will decide to allow or dismiss it, with an interim injunction remaining in place until that hearing concludes. The dispute centers on The Sun on Sunday seeking to publish alleged extra‑marital activities involving PJS and another person, AB, including a December 2011 text about a three‑way with AB’s partner CD and a subsequent encounter; PJS argues a right to privacy and sought injunctions. A High Court judge initially refused an injunction, but two Court of Appeal judges later ruled in PJS’s favour and temporarily prevented identification; publishers then asked that ban lifted, noting the story had already appeared in the US, Scotland and online, and the Court of Appeal judges concluded confidentiality was likely lost and that PJS was unlikely to obtain a permanent injunction despite solicitors’ efforts to remove online reports.

Fosse Park, a retail park near junction 21 of the M1 that opened in 1989, was bought in August for £345.5m; the new owners are preparing plans to improve parking, traffic congestion, unit appearances and the quality of common areas and facilities after concerns it has become tired, and have met with Blaby District Council—whose leader Ernie White said they view Fosse Park as an investable gateway into the city and hope to improve its current unattractive appearance.

The live-action Beauty and the Beast faced controversy in Malaysia after Disney delayed its Thursday release for a content review due to an "exclusively gay moment" involving LeFou's feelings for Gaston; the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) said it had approved the film with a "minor edit concerning a gay moment" and granted a P13 classification, though screening dates and locations are not LPF's purview, cinemas offered refunds for advance tickets, and the review drew online criticism and debate amid Malaysia's laws criminalizing homosexual activity and remarks from the tourism minister calling a ban "ridiculous."

Southampton City Council says landlords letting to more than three unrelated people must apply for an HMO licence, which can cost about £1,000 though offending landlords face fines up to £20,000; the council estimates around 1,500 unlicensed HMOs locally and has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals. Shelter adviser Nadeem Khan says tenants often fear eviction and live in poorly maintained, unregulated homes amid a shortage of affordable housing, with the shelter receiving about five or six related calls daily. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to houses of three storeys or more occupied by five or more unrelated people; in Southampton the scheme covers specific wards in two designation areas introduced in 2013 and 2015.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) aim to avoid a second election; Martin says Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but will not back a programme for government. Water charges are a key sticking point: Fianna Fáil wants immediate removal of charges while Fine Gael supports some role for them, and a commission to examine the future of Irish Water is being considered. In the election nearly two months ago Fine Gael won 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23 and Labour seven, but no party secured a majority and TDs have not yet elected a taoiseach.

The ferry Sorrento caught fire on a car deck while en route to Valencia about 27 km from Mallorca, prompting a full evacuation after the blaze rapidly worsened; passengers were transferred to lifeboats and life rafts, rescued by other vessels — eventually boarding the ferry Puglia — and were being returned to Palma de Mallorca, with psychologists requested to provide counselling at the port. Several ships including two passenger ferries assisted, and three people were airlifted to hospital (one seriously injured). The fire’s cause was unclear, the ship’s owner is Atlantica di Navigazione, it sent distress signals at 13:50 local time, and authorities warned the Sorrento may sink where it currently lies.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs flagged claims—including about students—of people saying they had voted twice in the general election, and warned that disconnected local electoral registers and the separate online registration database are creating duplicate applications and administrative burdens; between 1 Dec 2016 and the 22 May deadline about 4.9 million registration applications were submitted (mostly online) but the electoral register grew by only 1.4 million, implying many duplicates (estimates of 30–70% in different areas), and 2.9 million applications arrived in the six weeks after the snap poll was called. A record 46.8 million were registered for the 8 June election (68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997), with some constituencies—especially student-heavy seats—seeing electorate rises over 10%. The watchdog urged better linkage or verification between systems (as used in Australia, New Zealand and Ireland), clearer online information, and that people registered at two addresses should choose in advance where they will vote in general elections; it stressed voting twice in a general election is a criminal offence and asked the public to report information to police. Labour cautioned against measures that would deter young or student registration, noting lawful reasons to be registered at two addresses while calling for sufficient police resources to prosecute double-voting.

Lawrence Phillips, 40, believed to have killed himself early Wednesday, was a former Nebraska star and NFL player (St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, San Francisco 49ers) whose career and life were marred by repeated legal troubles; after convictions including driving his car into teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend he was serving a sentence of more than 30 years, had been placed alone in a cell after being accused of killing his former cellmate Damion Soward, 37, and a judge had found sufficient evidence to try him in Soward’s death; the manner of his suicide is unclear, and his former coach Tom Osborne said Phillips was intelligent with good qualities but struggled with anger issues and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram officially classed as a soldier and the 30th mascot in a line dating back to the 1858 Private Derby of the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot, was promoted to lance corporal at an event in Chester marking eight years of the Mercian Regiment; his promotion for "good behaviour" was awarded by the regiment's colonel, Brigadier Andrew Williams. He joined the regiment in February 2014, has his own army number, receives pay for rations, takes holidays during mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire, and during his service has helped switch on Ashbourne's Christmas lights and met Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool produced a dramatic comeback under new manager Jurgen Klopp to beat Borussia Dortmund 4-3 at Anfield and reach the Europa League semi-finals, with late Dejan Lovren header securing victory after Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho and Divock Origi had overturned an early 2-0 deficit to Henrikh Mkhitaryan and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang; the night showcased Klopp’s infectious touchline passion and his success in quickly imprinting an identity on players and fans, rekindling belief reminiscent of the 2005 Champions League final, while highlighting strengths in attack (Coutinho, Origi) and remaining defensive concerns (left-back Alberto Moreno, Sakho’s positioning), and leaving Liverpool closer to a Champions League return via the Europa League.

Following an EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee meeting in London, UK Brexit secretary David Davis said the UK government will keep Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland updated by holding monthly meetings to share analysis and allow devolved administrations to voice views as Westminster prepares talks with Brussels; he described the meeting as constructive and pledged regular information-sharing while working with the devolved governments to implement the decision to leave the EU. Scottish minister Russell welcomed inclusion but criticized the UK for lacking clarity over strategic intentions more than four months after the referendum—notably whether the UK will remain in the single market or customs union—and urged greater transparency, saying single market membership is essential for Scotland’s prosperity. Meanwhile the UK government hopes a High Court ruling on triggering Article 50 will be overturned on appeal to the Supreme Court next month, but the Scottish government intends to oppose the UK in that appeal, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe seeking permission to be heard.

Veterinary surgeon Dr Sandra Corr examines Daisy, one of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham, including four (Daisy, Debbie, Denise and Diane) cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly, making them identical twin sisters of Dolly. Professor Kevin Sinclair, lead author on a forthcoming study, explains the study’s aim: to determine whether cloned animals age normally or inherit “age-memory” from differentiated adult donor cells that might cause premature cellular senescence and earlier onset of age-related diseases. Dolly died at about six-and-a-half after lung lesions from a virus and had osteoarthritis, raising concerns about premature aging; to investigate whether that was bad luck or cloning-related, researchers produced more clones from the original cell line and monitored them and nine other clones from different lines with extensive tests (regular joint X-rays, full-body fMRI and assessments focused on cardiovascular disease, diabetes and osteoarthritis). The results are due to be published next week, and the clones, now approaching nine and ten years old, currently appear to be in good health.

Trainer John Gosden allowed the unbeaten favourite Shutter Speed to race after walking the soft course; she beat Vintage Folly by 1 3/4 lengths and will go to Chantilly for France's Oaks over a mile and a quarter rather than the Epsom Oaks, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders. Dettori praised her class and commented she would be better on firmer ground. Gosden is worried about soft ground affecting his colt Cracksman for Thursday's Dante Stakes and will walk the course before deciding whether to run him, noting the tight 16‑day gap between the Dante and the Derby may rule Cracksman out. Separately, Tasleet (14-1) won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas, with Jim Crowley riding and Magical Memory second, Comicas third.

Sterling fell and recovered intraday before sliding again as markets reacted to polls showing the Remain vote probability declining and global economic worries; the volatility index hit levels not seen since 2008, sterling was down 0.2% v the dollar at $1.4226, 0.6% v the euro at €1.2605 and about 1% v the yen to just over 151, and hedge funds were short-selling amid rising Brexit uncertainty with polls tightening and Betfair cutting Remain's implied probability from ~80% to 68.5%. Analysts warned that incoming polls could further increase sterling volatility, markets were on “full Brexit alert,” and sterling lost over 2% in two sessions, contributing to sharp Asian stock falls (Japan Nikkei -3.5%, Hong Kong -2.5%) while London’s FTSE 100 ended down 1.1% at 6,044.9 with Lloyds the biggest faller; Leave campaigners noted sterling and the FTSE were around March levels and argued a weaker pound aids exporters as April trade data showed the UK trade deficit narrowed due to a rise in exports.

Braintree Town (the Iron) sit sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off positions after losing to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games; manager Cowley praised his side for challenging a strong Barrow team despite travel fatigue and an early concession, acknowledged the difficulty of their part-time status and three-game losing run, and described the season so far as "nothing short of remarkable" while urging the team to embrace and enjoy the ongoing tough challenge.

The passage describes a shift in Northern Ireland from centralized planning decisions by the Planning Service to local councils making most planning decisions from April 2015, giving councillors the final say on developments; supporters like Michael Corr see this as a democratic opportunity for local development planning, while critics warn of risks including possible discriminatory or partisan favoritism reminiscent of 1960s housing allocation controversies. Friends of the Earth urge strict enforcement of codes of conduct, greater transparency about political donations and safeguards against close relationships between developers and political parties; some politicians fear donor deterrence, others say a £7,500 donation-declaration threshold is irrelevant locally, and the Northern Ireland Secretary will decide when to require more disclosure under a recent law.

One-year-old cat Teenie was shot three times—twice in the shoulder and once through the left hind leg, which vets had to amputate—after being found injured by owner Sarah Nisbett in Winchburgh on 14 March and taken to the Scottish SPCA; she is now relearning to walk by hopping, and the incident has prompted calls from the Scottish SPCA and Ch Supt Mike Flynn for urgent licensing of airguns to limit possession to those with lawful reasons and help police trace irresponsible users. The passage notes a prior Scottish government consultation on air weapon licensing in which 87% of respondents opposed the proposed requirement that owners demonstrate a legitimate reason, with critics calling it “draconian” while a few said it did not go far enough; the Scottish SPCA asks anyone with information to contact them.

Liverpool signed 24-year-old Belgium international Christian Benteke from Aston Villa by triggering his release clause, making him the club's second most expensive signing on a "long-term contract" and their seventh summer signing; Benteke scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after joining from Genk in 2012, missed the 2014 World Cup with an Achilles injury but returned to score 15 goals last season, and said he joined Liverpool to win trophies and be part of the manager's project. The move follows Liverpool's lack of goals after selling Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge, with Brendan Rodgers also bringing in Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino and recalling Divock Origi; former Villa manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge praised Benteke's qualities and potential impact on Liverpool's attack.
