A study of 671 state and independent schools commissioned by Tablets for Schools found rapid growth of tablet use—now in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% of schools providing a tablet per pupil and academies using them most intensively—and predicted numbers rising from about 430,000 in 2014 to almost 900,000 by 2016; however, researchers led by Barbie Clarke found no clear evidence that tablets improve academic attainment because the impact of technology cannot be isolated, though headteachers report positive effects such as increased pupil motivation, greater family involvement when tablets go home, and a sense of empowerment and relevance to modern life, while a separate National Literacy Trust/Pearson study suggested touchscreens help boys and poorer pupils learn to read and children in poorer households read on touchscreens more than printed books, and survey data show widespread personal use—about two-thirds of pupils take a device or smartphone to bed and in fully tablet-equipped schools a quarter of secondary pupils called themselves internet “addicts.”

The Museum of Liverpool's exhibition Growing Up in the City features 25 photographs from the National Museums Liverpool collections spanning the 1880s to the 1990s that document children's lives and Liverpool's social history; highlights include the oldest 1887 portrait of Florence, George and Gertie Rollo of Waterloo Park dressed for a fancy dress ball at Stone House, and a circa-1900 portrait of a nervous young maid illustrating child labor. Curator Kay Jones selected the images from hundreds of postcards, photographs and glass plate negatives to show both the pleasures of street play and the hardships of working childhood, and the exhibition runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually terminated his Barrow contract to join National League rivals; an ex-Aldershot and Exeter player who has also played in Italy could face his former club on 18 February. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, has been recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams and previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, with his transfer pending international clearance. Nicholson described Anderson as a 27-year-old leader with stature and voice despite limited games, and called Keating young, raw but hungry; the Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone and have won one of their last six games.

Bolivia has passed a law allowing 12-year-olds to be contracted to work with parental authorization, while increasing penalties for violence against children—including a 30-year jail term for child homicide; Vice‑President Álvaro García Linera said the law reflects Bolivia’s realities and balances rights with international treaties. The measure, approved by Congress and signed in President Evo Morales’s absence, aims to help eradicate extreme poverty amid UNICEF reports that over 500,000 Bolivian children already work in urban informal jobs and in hazardous conditions in mines and agriculture. The ILO recommends a minimum working age of 15 (or 14 in some developing countries) and is studying whether Bolivia’s legislation breaches international child‑labour rules.

Fifty-year-old O'Donnell fell ill at home after experiencing chest ache, sudden nausea and aches, and feverishness following help she gave a woman; she searched "women's heart attack symptoms" online, took aspirin, did not call emergency services, but saw a cardiologist the next day who inserted a stent into an artery that was 99% blocked, identifying the event as a "widow maker"; she called herself "lucky to be here," urged women to know symptoms and call 911, and has acted in shows including Drop Dead Diva, Will and Grace and Nip/Tuck and recently hosted The Rosie Show, which was cancelled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was stabbed and later died after a scuffle in an alleyway off Belvedere Way, Kenton, around 00:30 GMT following a party; police said an earlier fight involved youths denied entry but Che—who had been invited and was not believed to have taken part in that initial altercation—appeared to have been targeted later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and taken to a north London hospital in stable condition. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder and taken to a west London police station, two boys aged 15 and 16 were arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed until mid-December, and a 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon; detectives asked anyone near the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate at the time to come forward.

A Welsh team visited Aarhus, Denmark to study a reorganisation of cancer diagnosis prompted by poor survival statistics; Denmark introduced a three-route model: fast-track pathways with strict time targets for alarm symptoms and a legal requirement for investigation within 30 days of GP referral; diagnosis centres (from 2007) providing rapid tests/scans for patients with vague or hard-to-diagnose symptoms to avoid repeated GP-specialist referrals; and "yes-no" centres offering quick tests for minor symptoms that are unlikely but occasionally reveal serious disease. Analysis of 30,000 cases showed over 25% were from the hard-to-diagnose group, and the reforms have sped diagnosis without overwhelming services and improved survival rates, prompting interest in adopting lessons in Wales.

The UK government disbanded the OFT and Powys won the competitive bid to replace it in handling certain estate agent enforcement functions, receiving £170,000 a year; Powys will issue warning and banning orders against dishonest agents or those breaching the Estate Agents Act, with local authority trading standards still handling complaints and prosecutions but referring cases to Powys when the Act may have been breached; James Munro of Powys council will lead the new team and hopes the role will demonstrate Powys can win more external contracts.

NHS Employers approved a Nuffield Trust review recommending expanded roles for the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce, citing examples of nurses and pharmacists already covering some doctor tasks to help with junior doctor rota gaps and rising GP demand; the report argued this shift fits the growing focus on managing long-term conditions and noted doctors comprise only about one in 10 staff, so greater contribution from other health staff is needed though funding for training must be allocated. Report author Candace Imison saw "huge opportunities" to improve care and staff roles, and NHS Employers’ Danny Mortimer urged applying the report’s recommendations, while BMA leader Dr Mark Porter and Unison’s Christina McAnea warned that expanded roles must not replace high-quality doctor training or become a cheap fix amid funding pressures.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot after a crash at 03:00 GMT, with the A36 closure lifted at 14:00 GMT; the closure caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour while investigations into the collision continue. First said some services have resumed normal schedules but it will take a few hours for all to return to normal, and managing director James Freeman expressed hope for a full service by the evening commute and thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated the Swansea tidal lagoon would kill 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually during migration, figures Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputed as lacking a clear scientific basis and accused NRW of refusing to share its methodology; TLP offered its own computer-modelled worst-case estimate of 2% mortality and called NRW’s scenarios “unrealistic and grossly misleading.” NRW rebutted that it had shared extensive evidence, data and methodology with TLP over 18 months, that independent and internal experts had assessed its work, and that it had confidence in its figures as the best available evidence for environmental decision-making. The £1.3bn Swansea project is being pitched as a test bed for larger lagoons around the Welsh coast, the UK government is considering a pending six-month review of the scheme’s viability, and Wales’ Environment Secretary expressed strong support while calling for clarity from the UK government soon.

Stormont ministers announced creation of an industry-led agri-food marketing body, proposed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board and backed by DETI Minister Arlene Foster, who noted Northern Ireland’s agri-food sector employs nearly 100,000 across farming, fishing, retail and distribution and that the body—modeled on Scotland Food and Drink—will provide strategic leadership and coordinate marketing for government and private organisations; Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the move as positive for export-led growth and improved marketing coordination but warned it could affect other organisations’ work and said she will discuss implications with the AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is inviting the public to help plant 40,000 native trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley as part of a four-year, four-wood UK project to plant "millions" of trees commemorating those who died in WW1; Brackfield's 40,000 trees will honor the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives, with hopes for wildflower carpets including poppies and a wildlife-friendly place for reflection. The trust is supplying saplings, asks volunteers to wear welly boots or stout footwear, notes limited parking, and is encouraging as many local people and visitors as possible to join the hands-on planting.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate for Someone Else's Skin, described by judges as emotionally exhausting, powerful, finely and tightly written, with strong atmosphere and a well-handled plot tackling domestic violence and honour crime and introducing Det Insp Marnie Rome; Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career creating VI Warshawski—praised as a game-changing, action-hero-like female detective—whose stories were adapted for film (Kathleen Turner in 1991) and radio, and who helped change perceptions of female writers, with Paretsky also founding Sisters In Crime.

Mitch Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner who debuted in Tests in 2015, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which director Steve Rhodes said was a major setback to their qualification hopes; Santner expressed frustration but said he enjoyed his time there and will rejoin the Rapids after June's ICC Trophy in England to try to make up for lost time, while Worcestershire signed Australian paceman John Hastings in August as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, 47, died in 2008 after being struck by a car while trying to hail a taxi on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev; Exeter coroner Dr Elizabeth Earland recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, finding overwhelming circumstantial evidence that the car—reportedly with stolen plates, no lights and travelling about 75mph—did not stop and witnesses described the incident as deliberate. Pring’s wife, Ganna (Anna) Ziuzina, 19 years his junior, had returned to a restaurant for a glove before the incident, made three statements to Ukrainian police, did not attend the inquest despite attempts to summon her, and within days of his death attempted to claim his assets, sold his Range Rover, removed items from his flat and transferred bank funds; the family allege she staged a hit-and-run to inherit his estate, and evidence presented included that she was entitled to the first £200,000 and was having an affair. Ukrainian police briefly closed then relaunched the inquiry as a murder investigation in 2011; the case remains active but not actively pursued.

Sophie and Rob Fearns of Litherland, Merseyside, say their son Charlie, who has been ill since age three and suffered a third relapse in April, urgently needs further T‑Cell Therapy at Seattle Children’s Hospital because the last transplant failed and the treatment is unavailable in the UK; they received an email from the hospital confirming an anonymous donor has offered to pay for Charlie’s experimental treatment, leaving the family “ecstatic,” “overwhelmed” and “extremely grateful,” financial clearance is now complete and treatment will begin as soon as a date is set, expected next week.

Following high-profile leaks of celebrities' private photos, Apple introduced an opt-in two-factor authentication measure for iCloud that requires a username/password plus a four-digit code sent to a trusted device (or entry of a 14-character recovery key) before allowing access or downloading backups; this change blocks tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker—whose maker says the new system prevents his software from listing devices or backups and triggers email notifications when backups begin—but raises concerns about users losing or having recovery keys stolen, prompting experts to argue two-factor should be default and Apple to more strongly encourage its use and stronger passwords, a position echoed by CEO Tim Cook.

Dan Groves said details are pending of a deal that could see 30-year-old Wright buy 20% of Billericay and become a club director, the Sun reported; the club, recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin—who said he was "comfortable" investing £10,000 a week—sit eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points off a play-off place, and have signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35; Wright, runner-up on I'm A Celebrity in 2011, previously played non-league football for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds.

Following a BBC investigation into Sports Direct's Derbyshire warehouse practices, MP Iain Wright has asked owner Mr Ashley to give evidence to the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee by 21 March; although Ashley invited the committee to meet at the Shirebrook site, the committee insisted on holding public hearings at Westminster and offered alternative dates which he has not accepted. Wright warned that if Ashley does not agree to attend one of the offered dates the committee may escalate the matter, including seeking the House of Commons' support for a contempt complaint. Sports Direct has not commented to the BBC; the company has said it will review worker rights under Ashley's oversight.

The unfinished report originated with the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov and has been completed by his colleagues led by Ilya Yashin as a Russian-language dossier entitled Putin. War, compiling already-public facts about Russia's role in Ukraine since the 2014 annexation of Crimea and the outbreak of conflict in Donetsk and Luhansk. The authors argue the material—names and numbers of units, photos of weaponry, testimonies from “volunteer” soldiers and a veteran recruiter—shows Russian army units and commanders, not local separatists, directed and secured key rebel victories, with pay reportedly reaching $2,000–3,000 a month and Russian spending on the conflict estimated at 53bn roubles. Nemtsov began the work after learning families of dead Russian soldiers had not received promised compensation; after his assassination relatives grew too afraid to go public. Yashin says publishers fear handling the dossier and the initial print run is only 2,000 copies, while public opinion remains divided—many Russians accept involvement as support for anti-Kiev forces, whereas the opposition accuses Putin of waging the war to boost his popularity, a charge that previous critical reports failed to translate into effective protest.

Craig Nelson (also known as Craig Preston), a 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham, was found at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday and a post-mortem concluded he died from head injuries; a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones criticized being excluded from seeing or contributing to the Article 50 letter before publication, calling it part of a pattern of disrespect toward devolved administrations, while Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government’s consultations and noted Wales was mentioned; Theresa May’s letter to Donald Tusk said the UK would consult on which powers return to Westminster or devolved governments and expects devolved administrations to gain significant decision-making power, but it is unclear which powers (e.g. farming, economic aid) and whether funding will follow them—Jones fears funding may not—some in Whitehall argue EU spending in Wales supports centralisation, and further detail may appear in a white paper on the Great Repeal Bill.

Two cars were damaged in an incident on Nursery Drive and Parkhead in Newry on Friday night; the PSNI said officers were "carrying out duties" when they were attacked, prompting Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin to say he was "appalled by mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community" and the PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook post to appeal to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr Charney, the company's founder and former chief executive, was ousted last year amid employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds; the board, in a San Francisco court filing responding to his defamation suit, said it does not expect him to return and documented illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts, asserting he repeatedly violated sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy and posed too great a risk to be rehired, while his lawyer Keith Fink denied the allegations as false and accused the company of invading Charney's privacy to extort him; earlier, American Apparel obtained a restraining order barring him from making negative public statements about the company or seeking to remove board members.

BBC will broadcast Britain's home game against Greece on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website/app, 17:30–19:30 BST. Greece beat GB 92-64 earlier this month in Patras, but three Greek players will miss the Copper Box match, giving GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor, from Stratford, said playing at the Copper Box will be amazing and good preparation for EuroBasket, with some players making their London debuts. The match is Britain's only home game before FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which begins in early September with a qualifying group in Istanbul; after the Greece game, coach Joe Prunty's team will travel to a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up.

The author recounts covering the iPhone’s launch when phones were primarily for calls, describing persuading Apple’s Phil Schiller to let him briefly show the device on the BBC Ten O’Clock News, the ensuing criticism and his defence that some products merit coverage for their potential to change lives; he reflects that the iPhone did indeed prove transformative, putting powerful computers in billions of hands, radically changing photography and other mobile activities (illustrated by a comparison of his poor SLR photo of Steve Jobs with a much better iPhone shot years later), and credits Steve Jobs’ emphasis on an attractive user interface for enabling wider use, while noting later innovations from Amazon and Google and calling that January morning in San Francisco the start of the mobile connected era.

Tests confirmed all the cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, had ingested a toxic substance; seven-month-old Meereen died after being confirmed to have consumed antifreeze, and three other cats in the area died in the last seven days with another cat dead two weeks earlier. The RSPCA said it was unclear if the poisonings were accidental or deliberate, and RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock urged residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, check for antifreeze leaks and clean up spills. Meereen’s owner, Adria Pearce, described the cat returning shivering, later found foaming at the mouth and trying to be sick, and said she has been devastated and crying since the death.

The passage describes a surprising calm in Greece despite Syriza’s apparent decision to accept another €86bn bailout with painful austerity measures—VAT hikes, pension cuts, subsidy reductions, privatisations and opening sectors to competition—measures it previously opposed; Athens is busy with tourists while Greeks have not protested, perhaps awaiting full terms or resigned to “there is no alternative” after July’s banking closures and economic collapse; Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity and, because banks remain partially closed, Greece also faces monetary austerity that restricts lending and risks disrupting businesses (notably pre-Christmas orders), deepening poverty; the author argues the bailout will only support recovery if creditors, particularly Berlin and Brussels, avoid triumphalism and provide substantial debt relief—reducing Greece’s unsustainable debt by a third to a half—to give hope of better times.

Ross Kemp will make a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell to reunite the Mitchell family for the final episodes of Dame Barbara’s storyline; Barbara returned to Albert Square after leaving in 2010 to tell eldest son Phil that her cancer has returned, and producers revealed Peggy will die from the disease in emotional scenes to air in the spring. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990–1999 and again in 2005–2006, said he could not turn down the chance to be with Barbara for her last appearances and is looking forward to filming classic episodes, while executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins called Grant an EastEnders legend and highlighted the drama of the reunited Mitchell brothers facing their mother’s death.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles last October; her parents, Sue Hills and Prof Clive Ruggles, recounted police informing them of her death and said they immediately suspected Dhillon. The trial at Newcastle Crown Court heard Dhillon had become obsessed and stalked Alice; he denied murder but was found guilty and given a minimum 22-year sentence. Dr Hills expressed guilt for having reassured Alice and dismissed warnings from another daughter shortly before the killing, while Prof Ruggles said none of them had realized how serious the situation was. Alice’s parents have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of stalking and to remember her vibrant, smiling character.

EDF approved financing for the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power project in Somerset, with contracts due to be signed, but the UK government has launched a further review and delayed final backing following Business Secretary Greg Clark's remarks; EDF CEO Vincent de Rivaz canceled a site visit and the decision surprised EDF after its board vote, amid concerns about EDF’s financial capacity despite Chinese investors providing one third of costs and EDF shareholders approving a €4bn share issue. Supporters warn delay risks energy supply, higher costs and reliance on dirty power, while critics and environmentalists protest potential environmental damage, high consumer costs, and reliance on foreign governments; key figures include expected peak on-site workforce of 5,600, 4,000 km of electrical cabling, 230,000 tonnes of steel and 5.6m cubic metres of earth to be moved, and Hinkley C is projected to supply about 7% of UK electricity. The project timeline notes government endorsement of new nuclear in 2006, construction approval in 2013, a guaranteed strike price of £92.50/MWh in 2013, EDF’s 2015 investment deal with CGN, the July 2016 EDF board approval, and the UK’s postponement of its final decision until autumn.

The new online divorce form for England and Wales explicitly asks for "the name of the person your spouse has committed adultery with," though the Ministry of Justice and the form's guidance state there is no obligation to name anyone and it is "not normally necessary." Family lawyers warn that naming a third party typically adds conflict, complexity, potential delays and costs because that person becomes part of the court case and must be served and may respond; judges disapprove of bringing new partners into proceedings. The online update aims to be more user-friendly for people who may apply without legal advice, but lawyers fear applicants will ignore the small-print warning—despite statistics showing adultery was cited in 12,148 of just over 100,000 divorces in 2015, compared with 46,815 for unreasonable behaviour—and the MoJ notes petitioners have always been able to name an alleged adulterer.

Industry group Confor says ministers are overemphasising environmental objectives at the expense of commercial timber production in Wales, which is part of Britain—the world’s third-largest wood importer; Confor warns at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest lost since 2001 need replanting. Conifer forests have supported the timber industry for decades, with forestry worth over £450m a year to the Welsh economy and half the woodland managed by Natural Resources Wales and half by private firms. Ministers favour native broadleaf species, public access and conservation, but some commercial forests are hard to access and harvest, causing transport conflicts with rural communities. The Welsh government seeks a balance of environmental, economic and social goals via schemes like Glastir and its Woodlands for Wales strategy; Confor’s Martin Bishop criticises bureaucracy, says only 90 hectares were planted last year versus a needed 20,000 hectares annually, and reports strong market demand with sawmillers able to double or triple production if timber supply existed.

A boy was badly injured after being struck on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School in Coatbridge at about 16:40; emergency crews took him to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to surviving men of the World War II Arctic convoys, whose missions from Britain to northern Russia supplied the Soviet Union under extreme danger from German U-boats, aircraft, severe cold, storms and ice floes; by May 1945 the route had cost 104 merchant and 16 military vessels and more than 3,000 men. The Russian embassy and Minister-Councillor Alexander Kramarenko said the awards recognized the convoys' crucial role in arming the Soviet effort on the Eastern Front and had been long-awaited by veterans; initially the Foreign Office blocked the awards because British rules barred acceptance of foreign medals for acts over five years old, leading Britain to create the Arctic Star in 2012, but an exception was later made and President Putin presented the first Ushakov medals in London on 16 June 2013.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant failures in the delivery and enforcement of unpaid work/community payback, including long delays to starting work and frequent allowance of non-attendance (one offender did 16 hours in 17 months); inspectors reviewed 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders, praised some high-quality work and positive offender attitudes, but identified organisational problems—getting chaotic, often substance-affected offenders to attend on time—and recommended 15 improvements, including reducing turn-aways and matching work objectives to offenders’ circumstances. The report noted the scheme’s history (10,000 orange bibs ordered under Gordon Brown, 2010 coalition aim to toughen unpaid work) and warned that treating unpaid work merely as punishment wastes rehabilitation opportunities. The chief inspector called for urgent remedial action, and the Ministry of Justice said it accepted the recommendations and is acting to ensure offenders attend and face consequences for non-attendance.

The Sun ran a front-page story calling comedian Russell Brand a hypocrite for advocating economic and political "revolution" for the poor while living in a luxurious London home—an accusation he's often faced. Brand's vlogs show his spacious, airy house, and when asked about his rent while supporting east London residents facing displacement, he dismissed the reporter as "a snide" and walked off. He did not respond to questions about legal action against The Sun but has tweeted criticisms using #TheSunLogic. Brand has previously acknowledged his wealth and fame, admitted past excesses, argued that personal change and sharing wealth matter but are insufficient without systemic change, and suggested accusations of hypocrisy may stem from reluctance to address real inequality; he called hypocrisy a problem that can be addressed incrementally.

J. Craig Venter, a once-controversial biologist and entrepreneur known for bold claims and lavish lifestyle, accelerated genomic science by pioneering faster sequencing methods—shifting focus from whole DNA to cellular RNA—founding The Institute for Genomic Research after leaving the NIH, and co-founding Celera Genomics to race to sequence the human genome; his work produced the first complete genome of a free-living organism in 1995, contributed to the 2001 human genome publications, and later led the J. Craig Venter Institute in creating a synthetic organism, Synthia, published in Science. Vilified by some for challenging scientific norms like open data, Venter used his personal wealth to pursue ambitious projects independently, including the Sorcerer II ocean expedition to catalog marine microbes, and he envisions synthetic microbes driving an industrial revolution by producing desired compounds, reducing oil dependence, and helping capture carbon dioxide.

A survey of about 1,000 parents in England (conducted online 26 Feb–5 Mar among parents with at least one child aged 4–17) found that four in five children who ate school lunches had tried foods at school they had not eaten at home, and half of parents said their children asked for foods they'd eaten at school to be cooked at home; 628 respondents had children who ate school lunches. The most popular vegetables reported were carrots, sweetcorn and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas and spinach were among the least popular. England’s School Food Trust commissioned the research following a Mumsnet survey suggesting some parents give packed lunches because children are fussy; Trust chairman Rob Rees and Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton said school meals help children try new foods and benefit from peer pressure and improved, healthier options. School meals in England must meet strict nutritional guidelines; about 40% of primary pupils and slightly fewer secondary pupils eat school lunches, while about 46% of children in Scotland do.

Álvaro Morata, a 23-year-old striker playing for Spain at Euro 2016, moved from Real Madrid to Juventus in 2014 after four seasons at Real; the transfer included a buy-back option for Real reportedly up to €30m. At Juventus he scored 27 goals over two seasons, won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, played in consecutive Champions League finals—appearing as a substitute in Real’s 2014 win and scoring in Juventus’ 3-1 2015 defeat by Barcelona—and had previously scored 10 goals for Real after making his first-team debut at 18; he has scored three goals for Spain in France and had been linked with Arsenal and Chelsea.

Wilson returned to Forest from Celtic in August 2013 for £2.5m, played 51 times in his second spell at the City Ground after an earlier four-season stint there, has also played for Preston North End and Notts County, and was released in May and has been without a club since.

Tesco is exiting the US by selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain to Yucaipa, with around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy’s 5,000 employees moving to the new business and about 50 stores expected to close; Tesco will loan the new business around £80m, will incur a £150m cost to dispose of the brand (partly a potentially repayable loan), and retains an option to buy a stake if Yucaipa turns the business profitable; Fresh & Easy operates 200 stores in California, Nevada and Arizona, has lost money since opening in 2007, Yucaipa is a Los Angeles private equity firm run by Ron Burkle, and Tesco described the deal as an “orderly and efficient exit from the US market” after reporting its first fall in annual profits for 20 years in April.

He initially experienced racial abuse but tells BBC Sport's Nick Hope he overcame it, briefly considered representing France, and is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics; the passage also notes a special guide is available on how to get into martial arts.

A new inventory of roughly 600 French Alps glaciers, led by Marie Gardent, used map archives, satellite imagery, aerial photos and manual checks to update a previous four-decade-old survey and shows alpine ice area declined from about 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to ~340 sq km by 1985–86 and to ~275 sq km by the late 2000s — an average loss of ~26% over 40 years; retreat is stronger in southern massifs (Belledonne glaciers have nearly vanished; Ecrins lost over three times more than Mont Blanc), while northern Alps (including the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, now just over 30 sq km versus 31.5 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s) fare better likely due to higher elevation, greater precipitation and more cloud, and these findings echo accelerating glacier mass loss reported elsewhere in the Alps.

Scotland have won all five qualifiers so far and host unbeaten Iceland at Falkirk knowing victory would all but secure qualification for next summer’s Netherlands finals; striker Kim Little’s club-mate (Perth-born) Evans—who has suffered play-off defeats for Euro 2013 and last year’s World Cup—says missing out again would be devastating and that the Iceland ties (home and away) will likely decide the group, with Scotland well placed to qualify automatically as one of the best six runners-up if needed. Evans, 24, who recently won the Frauen-Bundesliga with Bayern and praised the competitive German league and training environment, notes 12 of Scotland’s 20-player squad play abroad (England, Sweden, US) which she believes strengthens the national team, and she hopes for strong home support at Falkirk.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger who runs Wings Over Scotland and is a former games reviewer living in Bath, was arrested in the west of England after a woman in her 30s from south London made an allegation of online harassment covering a two-year period; he was released on bail until mid-September while police investigate. Campbell said the complaint concerned some tweets from his account, insisted none were threatening, accused the media of innuendo encouraging speculation, and announced he would post less frequently for reasons "totally outwith my control."

Peta has proposed replacing Skegness’s long-standing Jolly Fisherman mascot with a fish-themed, animal-friendly version featuring the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice," arguing the current figure "evokes images of cruelty to animals" by representing fishing-related suffering; the Jolly Fisherman, originally commissioned in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway for 12 guineas with the slogan "Skegness is so bracing," is synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort, and Skegness mayor Carl Macey, while welcoming suggestions, said the mascot is widely loved and does not, in his view, convey animal cruelty and likely will remain unless the council decides otherwise.

Scotland dominated a wet, cold match, overturning an early Vasil Lobzhanidze try to win emphatically: Tommy Seymour, a penalty try (after Kote Mikautadze pulled down a maul and was sin-binned), Sean Maitland and Stuart Hogg scored before half-time, Greig Laidlaw converting several kicks; Hamish Watson added a fifth try early in the second half, Lobzhanidze grabbed a second for Georgia from a powerful scrum, then Hogg finished a late counter for Scotland’s sixth. Georgia also kicked a couple of penalties and scored via a scrum-driven try, while Scotland endured scrum problems including a Moray Low yellow; replacements Ali Price and Rory Hughes helped set up Hogg’s second. Vern Cotter praised the team’s game management and Laidlaw’s leadership. Starting line-ups and replacements for both Scotland and Georgia were listed.

Widnes beat Castleford with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, Lloyd White (2) and Joe Mellor to lead 14-6 at half-time and pull away to a 38-12 advantage, despite Castleford responses from Paddy Flynn (a hat-trick while on loan from Widnes), Larne Patrick and Luke Gale in a late flurry; Mellor’s opportunistic short kick-off score had helped Widnes build a 26-point lead. Castleford, suffering their fourth straight home league defeat and having lost nine of their previous ten, saw Patrick — who signed a three-year deal to join Castleford from Huddersfield after his loan — and loaned players Gale and Flynn make the finish nervy, but Widnes held on to move above Wakefield into seventh while Castleford remain sixth, one point clear of Widnes. Team line-ups and replacements for both sides and referee J Smith are noted.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti held at Guantanamo Bay since 2002 after his arrest in Pakistan on suspected links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban (which he denies), was released after a US Periodic Review Board concluded his continued detention was not necessary to protect US security; he had previously challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. He boarded a Kuwaiti government plane and will face at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait under the release terms; Kuwait had pushed for release of its nationals. His lawyer said there was "no bitterness" and joy at his return. His release, the first since May’s exchange of five Taliban detainees for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl, reduces the Guantanamo population to 148; the facility opened in January 2002 after the 11 September 2001 attacks and President Barack Obama has repeatedly promised to shut it down.

"PPAP" (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen) is a minute-long, infectiously catchy song performed by DJ Piko-Taro, a fictional animal print-clad character created and played by 40-year-old Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka; its simple lyrics, addictive beat and easy dance made the video go viral after first appearing on Piko-Taro’s YouTube channel, gaining over 4 million views there and more than 44 million on 9GAG’s Facebook post, provoking mixed reactions from amused to irritated viewers, inspiring hundreds of tributes and covers—including vines by Japanese duo Riko and Rika, a heavy metal version and a Thai cover by Happy Polla—and earning comparisons to Psy, even though it had received little attention from mainstream Japanese media and had not particularly trended in Japan.

Thousands attended Anzac Day services in London, including an early morning dawn service at Hyde Park Corner, a Westminster Abbey service, and a parade of up to 400 people before wreath-laying at the Cenotaph; national anthems of New Zealand, Australia (and references to all three countries) were sung, prayers were read by schoolchildren, and veterans, service personnel and families took part. The commemoration marks the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces—the 1915 Gallipoli landings—and was first observed in the capital in 1916 when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service. Australian high commissioner Alexander Downer addressed the crowd, reflecting on the courage and sacrifice of Anzac troops, and the passage notes the eight-month Gallipoli campaign in Turkey as one of World War One’s bloodiest attempts to force the Ottoman Empire out of the war.

Clarkson, 30, rejoined Premiership club St Mirren for a second spell in July and could make his debut in Saturday’s Championship match against Alloa; he scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has mainly been used as a substitute so far this term but says he’s fit, has maintained match fitness by playing for the U20s, and is ready to contribute. Capped twice by Scotland in 2008 with one international goal, Clarkson has nearly 400 senior club appearances, having previously played for Bristol City, Brentford and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren sit eighth in the Championship, seven points above bottom side Alloa, and Clarkson hopes wins can boost confidence and help the club climb the table.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan; Unite had feared the new owners might not honor the existing workers' pension arrangements but were given guarantees that all current agreements would be honoured. Unite said the Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme closed in 2004 and members now have an alternative scheme unaffected by the takeover, and Boparan’s private office confirmed current pension arrangements would continue. Unite regional officer Steve Harley met Boparan representatives at the Great Witchingham headquarters, where the new owner expressed intentions to restore Bernard Matthews to profitability through greater investment, cost savings and using spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkeys.

At a council scrutiny meeting about problems with the new chain ferry, council leader Dave Stewart announced crossings at Cowes would be free until 2 July to acknowledge issues and gather feedback, and the council has ordered an auditor review of the project; since its launch on 14 May the ferry has broken down, run aground, been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training issues, and caused damage to cars boarding and disembarking. Local businesses report severe losses—shopkeeper Angie Booth warned of possibly not surviving almost six months of lost trade—and compensation for businesses and damaged cars is under discussion, while transport councillor Ian Ward described the vessel as a prototype with teething problems that included electrical faults now fixed, ramp extensions authorised to stop vehicles scraping concrete, and seamanship issues causing groundings that have been resolved.

The House of Lords report warns that while Brexit may let the UK reclaim control over fisheries and appeal to pro-Leave coastal communities, the industry is small (0.5% of GDP, 12,000 fishers) and risks being marginalised in negotiations; most commercial stocks are shared with EU states, most UK-caught fish are exported to the EU, and many UK-consumed fish are imported, so continued market access is essential and may require trade-offs such as allowing EU boats access in return for tariff-free exports. The report urges retaining CFP elements like science-based total allowable catches and international cooperation, and warns Brexit could fragment management into four regimes across England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. Recent CFP quota increases for species like plaice, haddock and prawns and industry statements express optimism about future control of a 200-mile EEZ and potential benefits for coastal communities, while the government says it aims to maximize trade access and use Brexit to review fisheries management for fair quotas, sustainability and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney admitted taking or allowing images of mostly partially dressed young boys in erotic poses between April 2004 and February 2014; he received a community payback order, was placed on the sex offenders register, ordered to take part in a special programme for sex offenders, and was sentenced at Dumfries Sheriff Court. A General Teaching Council Scotland hearing concluded his conduct “condoned and participated in an industry that violates and abuses children,” found the behaviour showed a lengthy pattern with a high likelihood of recurrence and that he failed to uphold professional standards, declared him unfit to teach, removed him from the register, and barred him from applying to re-register for two years; he was 69 at sentencing and did not attend the hearing.

Firefighters spent several days at the Duncan Street site after a blaze on 2 March that reduced train services and caused travel delays; the cause remains undetermined. The Environment Agency has suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste and decided to revoke the company's environmental permit—effective 7 August unless appealed—meaning it will no longer be able to operate from the site and must remove all waste. The firm, whose site was run by Asset and Land Group and could not be contacted for comment, was judged "broadly compliant" with fire safety law by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service, which visited the premises nine times in the past 12 months and had raised concerns to the EA in February about potential impacts on residents, transport and the environment, prompting joint visits and the EA's enforcement action.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad told the BBC Syria is trying to meet the timetable to destroy its declared chemical weapons but missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile; he claimed shipments to Latakia were attacked by "terrorist groups," defended government actions as fighting terrorists, and called US criticism (including on barrel bomb use in Aleppo) unacceptable. Opposition sources report heavy civilian deaths in Aleppo from barrel bombs, and conflicting accounts surround a rebel assault on Aleppo central prison—activist groups say rebels captured it and freed hundreds, while state media says the attack was thwarted. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons; only ~30 tonnes (4%) have left the country, prompting US and Russian concern about delays to the UN/OPCW-backed plan to transfer weapons to the coast by 1 March and destroy all by the end of June amid security-related slowdowns. Mr Mekdad reiterated Syria's commitment to its OPCW and UN Security Council obligations.

England crushed Pakistan at Old Trafford, securing victory with a day to spare to level the four-match series after scoring 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, producing their second biggest run win vs Pakistan. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was man of the match for his 254 and an unbeaten 71 off 48, plus four catches and a wicket; teammates praised his maturity and effort. Captain Alastair Cook scored 105 and 76*, and commentators hailed England’s batting, bowling discipline and overall performance, though Michael Vaughan warned the series could still be tight. Pakistan struggled on a benign pitch—batting only 63 and 70 overs in their innings—with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 so far; Misbah lamented poor shot selection and low confidence but urged recovery ahead of a Worcestershire tour game and the third Test at Edgbaston.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales and is calling on pensioners, their families and friends to share experiences to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. She intends to highlight both examples of high-quality care and the harms of poor care, and will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care home environment, while also consulting care providers, social care staff and public bodies. Rochira says older people’s voices are central to ensuring accountability and necessary change. Care Forum Wales chair Mario Kreft welcomed the review’s aims but criticized the omission of a provider expert on the main advisory panel, arguing it excludes those who have lived in, worked in, managed or owned care homes and misses an opportunity for partnership with the sector.

Former Dons midfielder Paul Sheerin, 39, who has been player-manager of Arbroath (the Red Lichties) since 2010, has been appointed to replace Neil Cooper at Aberdeen's Pittodrie after a comprehensive selection process chosen by boss Derek McInnes, with Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser noting Arbroath chairman John Christison cooperated despite wanting to retain Sheerin; Sheerin, who played for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden and earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s, led Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011 but saw them relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One in 2013–14.

After Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge for Saturday's match against Bournemouth while Swansea seek a new permanent manager, with ex-Derby boss Paul Clement the preferred candidate. Curtis warned relegation would make immediate return difficult given a stronger Championship and clubs' ability to retain top players, and he argued Swansea have lost direction since Michael Laudrup's 2014 departure amid frequent managerial changes and player turnover that diluted the "Swansea Way." He noted the club's rise from near-bankruptcy and promotion in 2011, believes the current squad can avoid relegation, and says new signings are made aware of the club's history and the importance of staying up.

J. Craig Venter, a brash and wealthy biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated genomics by using automation and focusing on RNA to sequence genes faster, provoking criticism and losing public funding, which led him to found private institutes (The Institute for Genomic Research, Celera Genomics) and rival the publicly funded human genome project; his teams published the first complete genome of a free-living microbe in 1995 and shared human genome results in 2001, and in 2006 he formed the J. Craig Venter Institute to pursue creation of synthetic life—culminating in the Science-published organism "Synthia"—while also conducting a global marine microbial sequencing expedition from his yacht Sorcerer II, all amid controversy over data access and scientific conventions and with the claimed potential to spur a new industrial revolution by using engineered microbes for production and environmental benefits.

The Sutton Trust, via a Boston Consulting Group study, warns many English apprenticeships are low-quality, too short and skewed toward older workers, with fewer than 200,000 of 520,000 annual starts at level three (A‑level equivalent) and only 61,000 new starts for young people; England offers far more qualifications (18,000) and far fewer employer-provided apprenticeships (20% of employers) than Germany (330 qualifications, 51% of employers), where 570,000 young apprenticeships largely reach A‑level standard. Since 2010, 58% of apprenticeships have been below level three, three-quarters aimed at over‑25s, and there are 11 young applicants per apprenticeship. The report calls for up to 300,000 new annual starts, mostly at level three (three years) with some four‑year level four courses, limits on short level‑two places, better facilities, expert teaching and improved careers advice; supporters warn expansion will be challenging given current shortages for 16‑ to 18‑year‑olds and that some respected level‑two trades should be retained. The Department for Education says it is reforming apprenticeships to raise standards, insisting on minimum one‑year durations, more English and maths, and that every apprenticeship is a job.

Briton Storey won by over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland, and can claim a 17th title in Saturday's road race; the 37-year-old, aiming for further Paralympic success in Rio, is Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze) across cycling and swimming over six Paralympics, including four golds at London 2012, has won 21 world titles across both sports, and began her career in swimming—winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics—before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United were expelled from the Conference Premier after failing to pay football creditors despite multiple deadline extensions; their debts included £148,000 to football creditors and about £225,000 overall with over £70,000 owing to HMRC, and efforts by fans and others (including a £1 takeover offer from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust) and last-minute board negotiations failed to secure required assurances. The club was taken over by Tommy Agombar but still missed payment deadlines (originally 5 June, extended several times to 12 June) and were expelled on 10 June, allowing reformed Chester FC—who had been relegated on the final day when Hereford had briefly stayed up—to take their place; former Hereford players including Kingsley James and Dan Lloyd-Weston subsequently moved to other clubs, and the club’s decline followed relegation from the Football League in 2012 and falling attendances.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player aged 30, earned 61 England caps after debuting in 2009, was in squads for two World Cups and two European Championships but played just three minutes at Euro 2016, and said the decision (implied about his international future) was about common sense while wishing Sam Allardyce, players, staff and supporters success; he also holds the record for most England Under-21 caps with 46 from his first appearance in 2004 and scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 win over Moldova during 2014 World Cup qualifying.

Christopher Hogwood, who died at his Cambridge home after a months-long illness, was a leading figure in the early-music movement who founded and directed the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) from 1973 for about 30 years, recording over 200 CDs including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments and a celebrated 1980 Handel's Messiah. He studied keyboard at Cambridge and with noted teachers, began his career with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and the Early Music Consort of London, and held roles as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, tutor at Harvard, honorary professor at Cambridge and professor-at-large at Cornell. Colleagues and musicians praised his generosity, scholarship, influence in training leading players, and his insistence that music should speak for itself; his funeral will be private with a memorial later.

A Northern Ireland boy whose family requested anonymity was removed from mainstream school in June because he was not coping; his mother quit her job to care for him. The family requested a place at a special school but were told in September that all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full with no timeframe for a place, leaving the boy isolated and upset that his siblings attend school. The family has since been told an extra classroom assistant was employed at a local special school and he may start in the next few weeks, but the mother fears other families will face similar problems because special schools are oversubscribed. The Education Authority declined to comment on the individual case for privacy reasons and said it is reviewing special school needs and working to ensure places are available locally, with changes intended to assist placements from 2016.

Newport County have a lease on Rodney Parade, giving them fixture primacy while in the Football League until 2023, and chairman Foxall insists that contract should be honored amid a WRU takeover bid for Newport Gwent Dragons—whose shareholders will vote on 9 May—as the WRU views Rodney Parade "as a rugby venue" and plans to install an artificial surface (which would breach Football League rules); Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey says County and Newport Squash Club are protected under current agreements and the WRU has been informed. On the field, County sit two points clear of League Two relegation with two games left after a recent run of six wins in 10 under caretaker Mike Flynn and can secure survival if they win while Hartlepool lose; Foxall warned relegation to the National League would be a massive blow for fans and the city.

A former child fighter abducted at 15 by the RUF during Sierra Leone’s civil war describes brutal initiation, forced violence, drug use, and atrocities, then his escape to Freetown, incarceration, and encounter with preacher Richard Cole who led him to Lifeline Nehemiah and encouraged education and rebuilding. When Ebola struck Sierra Leone in 2014, he and his group—though not medical professionals—focused on three efforts: educating over 10,000 people in Temne, Krio and Limba about Ebola; providing food and supplies to 11,000 people in urban and rural areas; and partnering with agencies to establish an Ebola treatment unit, actions that saved many lives despite fear, stigma, and scarce funds but with help from local chiefs and communities. He expresses remorse for his past, confidence in a better future, and commitment to investing in youth. The passage also lists regional Ebola deaths: 11,314 total (probable, confirmed and suspected) including 4,808 in Liberia, 3,955 in Sierra Leone, 2,536 in Guinea, 8 in Nigeria, plus one in the US and six in Mali.

About 80,000 items from the Wedgwood collection—art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs—faced auction to help pay the pottery firm's pension debt, but a public fundraising campaign led by the Art Fund reached its target within a month; administrators Begbies Traynor said the collection will remain on display at the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, after the Art Fund gifts it to the Victoria and Albert Museum and it is then loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum. Administrators and campaigners, including Tristram Hunt MP and Alison Wedgwood, hailed the outcome as protecting an important Staffordshire collection that might otherwise have been sold and scattered globally; the museum had inherited Waterford Wedgwood plc’s pension bill after the firm’s 2009 collapse, went into administration in 2010, and in 2011 a judge had ruled the collection could be sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund.

Dan Groves said details are pending on a deal that could see 30-year-old Wright buy 20% of Billericay and reportedly become a club director; the club sit eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points outside the play-off places. Wright, runner-up on I'm A Celebrity in 2011, has played non-league football for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay were recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who said he was "comfortable" investing £10,000 a week, and the club signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, in early March.

After the Brexit vote, Bank of England Governor Mark Carney surprised colleagues by choosing a one-year extension rather than staying until 2021 or leaving in 2018; while extending would help provide continuity during Brexit negotiations, his decision was primarily driven by personal and family reasons—two daughters finishing key exams in 2018 and a desire to return to Canada—so he felt able only to stay until 2019, by which time the Article 50 process should be complete and a new governor can take over.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1: Nathan Delfouneso set up Jamille Matt to score for Blackpool after 12 minutes, and Colchester equalised from a corner when Kurtis Guthrie prodded in after 17 minutes; Blackpool keeper Sam Slocombe made several key saves (denying Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi), Guthrie later hit the bar, and Tom Aldred missed a late headed chance; Colchester finished with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister, and the match featured multiple substitutions, bookings (including Matthew Briggs, Tom Eastman, Andy Taylor, Colin Daniel) and numerous blocked and saved attempts.

Action Mental Health has developed a Healthy Me programme to teach P6 and P7 pupils in Northern Ireland how to cope with change and protect their emotional wellbeing during the stressful transition to secondary school and transfer tests; five schools piloted interactive workshops that encourage children to seek help, identify support, teach relaxation and breathing exercises, and provide basic training for teachers, and the charity hopes to roll the initiative out across Northern Ireland. Chief executive David Babington and Carrick Primary P7 teacher and pastoral coordinator Helen Hamilton said the programme helps reduce anxiety for pupils and parents around moving to larger secondary schools, while officials note growing transfer-test entry (14,681 entrants this year) and the chief inspector Noelle Buick has called for strengthened resilience-building and preventative pastoral education within the curriculum.

Developers Fawley Waterside plan to retain the 198-metre chimney of the disused Fawley oil-fired power station as the centrepiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development on the 300-acre site sold to them in 2016, featuring a petal-shaped glass structure, marina, housing, restaurants and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth; the power station, commissioned in 1971 on the western shore of Southampton Water, was a 2,000 MW plant fuelled by a nearby Esso refinery, capable of powering one million homes, closed in 2013 after more than 40 years, and outline planning permission is due later this year with building potentially starting in 2018.

At the Hong Kong World Championships, 23-year-old Latham won GB's second medal—a bronze in the men's scratch—after chasing Poland’s Adrian Teklinski (gold) and Germany’s Lucass Liss (silver); GB lost the men's team pursuit bronze to Italy. Latham described timing his final sprint well; commentators Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised his positioning and sprint. In the women's team pursuit, a young GB quartet including Olympic champion Elinor Barker finished fifth in the heats and missed a medal, but Barker and Joanna Rowsell Shand highlighted the squad's potential with an average age of 19. Britain's sole men's keirin rider Joe Truman was outclassed in his semi-final, and Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint, though she plans to contest the 500m time-trial and keirin and framed her result as part of preparation for Tokyo.

Ross Kemp will make a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell to appear in Peggy Mitchell’s final episodes after her surprise comeback revealed her cancer had returned; Kemp, who played Grant from 1990–1999 and in 2005–2006, said he couldn’t turn down reuniting the Mitchell brothers for their mother’s last scenes, which producers say will feature emotional spring episodes and reunite Grant with old loves and brother Phil, a storyline praised by executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins.

Sadio Mané scored twice in quick succession as Spurs lost at Anfield, prompting manager Mauricio Pochettino to criticize his team's lack of desire and readiness to fight for the Premier League, warning that Chelsea could go 12 points clear if they beat Burnley; Spurs have won only twice away since 24 September and just once in 17 away matches against other top-six sides, and former player Danny Murphy also condemned their away form, defensive lapses and tactical choices, urging rapid improvement.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 declared governorships in Saturday's elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999 and reinforcing PDP's decline after losing the presidency to Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on 29 May; the PDP won eight governorships mainly in the south-east, held onto oil hub Rivers, lost key northern states including Katsina and Kaduna and Adamawa, while Taraba remains outstanding and Imo was inconclusive, with elections not held in seven states. Analysts say the APC has become dominant nationally while the PDP is now regional, performing well only in the south-east and Niger Delta; the APC did not win any of the five oil-producing states, raising concerns about potential disruption to oil revenue and cooperation with Buhari. The polls saw violence—66 incidents reported by INEC, especially in Rivers and southern states—though overall were more peaceful than past elections, and the PDP faces a period of introspection after defections, corruption allegations, and perceived failure to curb the Boko Haram insurgency.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis, taking place from 19 to 22 July, will offer an augmented-reality app that lets visitors trigger online content from signs and posters—including videos and band interviews viewable on phones and tablets; acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan said the AR experience is an extra feature to enhance enjoyment, enable people worldwide to interact with the festival and capture its atmosphere, and will be updated before and during the event to provide instant information, interviews and ticket purchases.

Ofsted rated several Birmingham schools inadequate amid allegations of a "Trojan Horse" campaign to impose a hardline Muslim ethos, prompting the Department for Education to move to terminate funding agreements for Park View and Nansen Primary and warn Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock they could lose funding unless prescribed changes were made by 4 July; criticisms included failure to promote pupils' spiritual, moral, social and cultural development, allowing unvetted external speakers with extremist views at Islamic-themed assemblies, segregation of boys and girls and less favourable treatment of non-Muslims. Park View Educational Trust said it would legally challenge the report and warned termination could remove the trust from running the schools; Oldknow and Golden Hillock were given lists of required actions, and Saltley School—placed in special measures—will get a temporary governing board and leadership support to improve. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw described a culture of fear and intimidation and reports of an organised campaign targeting certain schools, while some parents and staff criticised the inspections as biased and defended the schools, seeking meetings with ministers.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, 38, was sentenced in September to five years in Tehran on undisclosed charges of allegedly plotting to topple the government; her husband Richard Ratcliffe says she has spent time in solitary confinement since her arrest at Tehran Airport last April and that their two-year-old daughter Gabriella remains in Iran after her passport was confiscated and is being cared for by grandparents. The appeal against the sentence is reportedly being held in secret in Tehran, preventing the family from attending and leaving the outcome unpredictable—her husband says it could quash, reduce or increase the sentence—and he believes she is being used as a diplomatic bargaining chip; he also reports Nazanin suffered suicidal feelings and a hunger strike in custody but has shown more resilience since being moved out of solitary. Gabriella has largely lost English and become fluent in Farsi, with family contact mainly via Skype and relatives translating, and Mr Ratcliffe is attempting to obtain a visa to visit them. Amnesty International UK calls Nazanin a prisoner of conscience detained for peacefully exercising freedom of expression and association and hopes the appeal will order her immediate release.

Vincent "Vinnie" Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich; prosecutors at Ipswich Crown Court say eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, failed to detect and refer swollen optic discs during that test, and that a resulting buildup of fluid in his brain increased skull pressure and led to his death, with Jonathan Rees QC arguing her alleged failure was preventable and so far below competent optometrist standards it amounted to criminal conduct; Rose denies gross negligence manslaughter and the trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing a woman to have sex with a man he arranged via an adult website between 10 September 2013 and 17 September 2014, and of intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to view sexual images and of threatening or abusive behaviour on 25 December 2014, including sending an explicit clip to the sister on Christmas Day; he denied the charges but was convicted, placed on the sex offenders register, assessed as posing a "moderate risk" of sexual re-offending, and the sheriff remitted the case to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing because of its greater powers, with Lady Wolffe stating the sentence must reflect society's abhorrence and defence counsel saying his client was shocked to be remanded ahead of sentencing.

Ireland posted 165-5 in Greater Noida with Stuart Thompson scoring 56, Gary Wilson 41* and captain William Porterfield 39, but Afghanistan chased it down for 171-4 with two overs to spare thanks to Samiullah Shenwari’s 56 and Mohammad Shahzad’s 47 (with Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai adding a 51 opening stand); Afghan spinner Amir Hamza was the only bowler with multiple wickets (2-23). Porterfield said Ireland fell short of their target and underperformed with the ball, and Ireland also missed paceman Boyd Rankin for the T20s due to a back problem though he is expected to return for the five ODIs starting 15 March.

Barcelona insisted it had committed no offence in the Neymar transfer but, citing potential differing interpretations of contractual tax responsibilities, made a complementary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to defend the club's reputation while maintaining it believes its original tax payment was correct; the club had paid £48.6m (57m euros) to sign 22-year-old Santos striker Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m, and when adding signing-on fee, wages over five years, agents' fees and this tax payment the total cost to Barcelona would be £106.8m. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriation and is under investigation but denies wrongdoing; a Spanish judge recently ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer, and it is not yet confirmed whether the case will be dropped after Barcelona's payment. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found dead on a Koh Tao beach on 15 September; post-mortems found Miller died from drowning and a head blow and Witheridge from head wounds. Two 21-year-old Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are held by Thai police, charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape and robbery, and alleged to have confessed; Thai police say DNA from Witheridge matched the suspects and deny reports the confessions were withdrawn. Metropolitan Police detectives traveled to Thailand to review the investigation, have completed their on-site work, will return to the UK to compile a report and update the victims’ families, and thanked Thai authorities for facilitating the visit; the UK Foreign Office had earlier raised concerns about DNA verification and alleged mistreatment, prompting diplomatic discussions after Thai PM Prayuth agreed to the British delegation following talks with Mr Cameron.

The passage describes growing real-world uses of virtual reality across journalism, education, healthcare and retail: charities like the UK’s National Autistic Society and Alzheimer’s Research UK created VR films to help the public experience autism and dementia; retailers and estate agents use VR to showcase homes and products (Ikea’s kitchen app even let users toss virtual meatballs and may be rolled out in stores); healthcare uses include live-streamed virtual surgery for training (Dr Shafi Ahmed’s work and Medical Realities’ Virtual Surgeon) and VR therapies for PTSD and phobias with documented improvements; education initiatives include Google Expeditions bringing virtual field trips to schools and startups like Evanescent Studios trialing language-learning VR, with advocates highlighting VR’s engagement benefits while noting barriers such as cost and hardware requirements for widespread school adoption.

The Su-24 jet’s black box was opened in Moscow before journalists and diplomats, but investigators led by Nikolai Primak reported flight information appeared to be missing; data could clarify whether the jet was in Syrian or Turkish airspace when shot down, and an analysis is expected next week. The 24 November shootdown by Turkish F-16s left one crew member killed (apparently by militants after ejection) and the navigator rescued; a Russian marine sent to help was also killed and a helicopter destroyed. The incident triggered a Russia–Turkey crisis: Russia says the jet was in Syrian airspace while Turkey insists it ignored warnings to leave its airspace; Moscow has demanded an apology and imposed sanctions, including a ban on package holidays that could cost Turkey billions.

Scotland have won all five qualifiers and host Iceland at Falkirk knowing victory would nearly secure qualification for the European finals; both teams are unbeaten (Iceland one place above Scotland at 20th) and their two meetings will likely decide the group, with Scotland well placed to qualify automatically as one of the best runners-up. Forward Kim Little and veteran goalkeeper Gemma Fay are mentioned; striker Evans (24, Perth-born) — who has played for Glasgow City, Turbine Potsdam and now Bayern where she won the Bundesliga and celebrated with the men's team — stresses the pain of past play-off defeats and the squad’s aim to reach the finals, praises the development benefits of players competing in top foreign leagues (12 of the 20 in the current squad play abroad across England, Sweden, Germany and the USA) and hopes for strong home support at Falkirk.

A review for the Commission on Local Tax Reform found no "magic bullet" to fix problems in Scotland's local taxation, noting council tax had inherent flaws from its introduction and lack of modification had compounded difficulties. Professor Kenneth Gibb's review found property taxes are widely used in OECD countries and valued for stability, difficulty of avoidance and potential housing-market benefits, but cause confusion about whether they tax wealth or pay for services and are seen by some as unfair because they are not linked to current income. Local income taxes are generally viewed as fairer but create revenue volatility for local authorities and limit scope to vary rates for local priorities. The commission, set up by the Scottish government and Cosla, will hold public consultation and report in the autumn; ministers consider the current council tax unfair and await the commission's findings.

The passage describes Apple adding an optional two-step verification measure for iCloud that requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted device (or via Find My iPhone) after entering username and password on a new device, blocking access and iTunes/iBooks/App Store purchases unless the code or a 14-character recovery key is provided; this change aims to stop third-party forensic tools (notably Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker) that had been used to download complete iCloud backups and were implicated in recent celebrity photo thefts. Elcomsoft’s owner, Vladimir Katalov, says the update prevents his software from listing devices or obtaining backups and praises the new backup-download email notification, but warns recovery keys can be lost or stolen; other experts argue two-factor should be enabled by default rather than opt-in, and Apple says it will more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and stronger passwords, with CEO Tim Cook emphasizing increasing user awareness.

UKIP, which won May's election, spent £2,956,737 (68p per its 4,376,635 votes); the Conservatives spent £2,980,815 (79p per vote); the Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 (£1.45 per their votes) and lost 11 of 12 MEPs; Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339 (26p per vote); the Greens spent £534,249 (43p per 1,255,573 votes); including the SNP's £267,372, the six highest‑spending parties spent £9,347,087 total during the campaign period from 23 January to polling day on 22 May, and all but Labour increased spending compared with the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually terminated his Barrow contract to join their National League rivals; an ex-Aldershot and Exeter player who has also played in Italy, he could face his old club on 18 February. Striker Ruairi Keating, 21, recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams, has had spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps and his move awaits international clearance. Nicholson described Anderson as the stature, voice and leader-type he wanted and called Keating young, a little raw but hungry to prove himself. The Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred gelding and past winner of the Gold Cup trial (2015) and Hennessy Gold Cup (2014), collapsed after narrowly beating Thistlecrack to win the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day; veterinary staff treated him but he was pronounced dead from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage" confirmed by the British Horseracing Authority. BHA acting chief veterinary officer Tony Welsh said such episodes are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues; although Many Clouds had shown past post-race ataxia symptoms (overheating and wobbling) and had been monitored and treated, he had shown no such signs on Saturday, and the report concludes his death resulted from the rare haemorrhage rather than a significant underlying condition.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears after veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil's powerful valedictory speech as he and others, including Mr Salmond, Annabel Goldie and Ms Marwick herself, prepare to stand down before the 5 May election; McNeil, an MSP since 1999, warned Holyrood must learn from Westminster on accountability, scrutiny and committee work or face consequences. Former first minister Alex Salmond used his farewell to reiterate that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse," welcomed devolved powers under the Scotland Bill while saying it fell short of referendum-era unionist pledges, joked about competing with other events that day, wished election candidates luck "with varying degrees of enthusiasm," and called being an MSP both an honor and a public service; Ms Marwick thanked him for serving parliament and Scotland with distinction. Goldie quipped she would miss interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney, particularly his "huge outbursts of faux indignation."

The live-action Beauty and the Beast will star (unnamed) as Mrs Potts, Kevin Kline as Maurice, Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston and Josh Gad as LeFou; Bill Condon will direct, filming begins at Shepperton Studios in May, and the film is set for US release on 17 March 2017.
