The CPS will announce its decisions at an 11:00 BST private meeting in Warrington with relatives of the 96 fans who died in the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster; last year new inquests found the fans were unlawfully killed and in January evidence files on 23 suspects were referred to the CPS — 15 from Operation Resolve (investigating the disaster’s causes) and eight from an IPCC probe into South Yorkshire and West Midlands police conduct after the event. Relatives will be informed by Sue Hemming of the CPS special crime and counter-terrorism division, and family representatives including Margaret Aspinall, whose son died and who chairs the Hillsborough Family Support Group, said the wait has been long, emotions will be mixed, the families expect a continued long road but remain determined to seek accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its wall, with a local resident witnessing such occurrences multiple times in two weeks and the prison arranging an evening meeting for neighbours; a former inmate described the jail as notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis and alleged drones were used to deliver contraband, though the Ministry of Justice said there was no evidence of drone deliveries at Chelmsford, noted staff work hard to stop contraband, and added that the Justice Secretary has asked for a review of tools to tackle the problem while laws now allow up to two years’ jail for people who smuggle packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady of 20 years, suffered serious head injuries last December outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston while escorting a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road when Brian Wright, 55, driving a VW Golf, failed to stop for a red light and hit her; Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright, who told Luton Crown Court he was blinded by the setting sun and could not recall the light colour, accepts striking her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving; he expressed remorse in court, saying he had "turned [her] world upside down" and thought only of Mrs Blackburn and her family since the incident. The jury heard traffic in the other direction had stopped, the sun was about ten minutes from setting, and the trial continues.

Laura Muir, 24, will miss next April’s Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her final-year veterinary medicine exams are in May and clash with the Games; she returns to university next week and prioritises completing her degree though she’s “gutted” to miss the opportunity to represent Scotland. Coming off fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5000m at the World Championships, Muir set a new outdoor PB of 14:52.07 in the 5000m in a race won by Hellen Obiri (with Almaz Ayana second and Sifan Hassan third), is pleased with her performance after five races in ten days, believes she has two or three more Olympics in her, and names the World Indoor Championships in March (Birmingham) as a potential target despite a busy study schedule.

Trevor Deely, 22, went missing in December 2000 after walking home from a Christmas party; CCTV from that night—enhanced by specialists and released in April—shows him talking to a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street and the same man apparently following him later on Haddington Road, but that man remains unidentified. Earlier this year six detectives began a complete review of Deely’s disappearance, and a search involving excavations started on Saturday in a three-acre wooded area beside the R112 down to the River Liffey in Chapelizod, Dublin; gardaí said the search will take a number of weeks and renewed their appeal for the man on the CCTV to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th after over two years out with wrist injuries, beat Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 to reach the third round at Wimbledon, saying he feels "alive" and grateful after difficult years; he is in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray and will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Also in Murray's half, Nick Kyrgios came from two sets to one down to defeat Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 after rain delays and will meet Feliciano Lopez in round three (Lopez had rallied from two sets down to beat Fabio Fognini), with the winner set to face Murray or John Millman in the last 16. Additionally, seeds Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga progressed with straight-sets wins over Benjamin Becker and Juan Monaco, respectively.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologising to CAF over complaints stemming from a controversial quarter-final defeat to hosts Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 tournament, when a late penalty led to a 2-1 extra-time loss and Tunisia accused CAF of poor referee selection rather than corruption; reconciliation followed meetings with CAF president Issa Hayatou and FTF vice-president Maher Snoussi says relations are now repaired. Morocco, initially banned after refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup over Ebola fears and replaced by Equatorial Guinea, were reinstated in the 2017 qualifying draw after CAS overturned the ban and reduced a $1m fine to $50,000. For the 2017 qualifiers Tunisia were drawn in Group A with Togo, Liberia and Djibouti, and Morocco in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé; if Tunisia qualify they would make a record thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

McLaren, once a dominant F1 team with 182 grand prix wins, a 23.18% win rate, 12 drivers' titles and eight constructors' championships, has fallen to scoring modest points and qualifying around the fourth row, despite fielding two world champions including Fernando Alonso; the slump began in 2013 after chassis design failures left them with a good engine, and today their car is reportedly strong but hampered by an inadequate Honda power unit following a premature 2015 Honda return. The team’s greatest successes came in the late 1980s with Honda (notably 1988) and later with Mika Häkkinen and Mercedes in 1998–99; they narrowly missed 2007’s title amid controversy and penalties, and suffered other scandals such as the 2009 “lie-gate.” Founded by Bruce McLaren, the team has cycled through peaks and troughs, with Ron Dennis engineering revivals and resuming control after 2013, insisting McLaren will break Mercedes’ dominance and return to winning championships—an assertion that currently rests largely on belief and incremental progress rather than results.

Paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014; police found patrons still at the bar and till receipts showed alcohol was served until 04:49 BST, leading a judge at Limavady Magistrates Court to order the pub closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, the licence holder from Kevin Lynch Park, was charged with two counts of allowing consumption of liquor outside licensing hours and fined £3,000; James Thomas, 44, of the same address, faced one such count and was fined £1,000. A defence solicitor said licensing laws in Dungiven were not strictly adhered to and the premises had been running well into the morning; the judge called O'Neill's record "appalling" and said the case was as bad as he had seen, expressing concern he lacked power to impose a custodial sentence.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA single-season three-point record by hitting eight 3-pointers (entering the game four shy of his previous mark of 272) while scoring 45 points and adding nine assists to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 comeback win over the Portland Trail Blazers; Klay Thompson scored 26 as the pair erased a 13-point deficit, while LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 points and six rebounds and Damian Lillard added 20 points and eight assists for Portland. Elsewhere, Pau Gasol posted 16 points and 15 rebounds as the Chicago Bulls rallied from a 19-point halftime deficit—erasing a 33-12 second-quarter hole with a 39-8 run to start the second half—to beat the Miami Heat 89-78; Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson scored 14 each, Mike Dunleavy and Derrick Rose 12 each, while Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds and Dwyane Wade managed nine points on 4-for-20 shooting.

YouTube free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen surprised Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Markovic at Melwood after being presented as a competition winner, demonstrating advanced dead-ball skills by scoring into the top corner and outshining expectations; van Velzen, who has become a YouTube sensation for his free-kick videos, said meeting the players and pretending to be a poor free-kick taker before showcasing his ability was amazing and satisfying, and he also surprised Balotelli by unveiling the forward’s infamous slogan, a phrase associated with a T-shirt Balotelli wore during Manchester City’s 6-1 win over United in October 2011.

A Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients carrying BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations found that oophorectomy (removal of ovaries) after diagnosis was associated with substantially reduced mortality: a 62% drop in breast cancer death among BRCA1 carriers (but not seen for BRCA2), a 65% reduction in death from all causes, and a 73% reduction when oophorectomy occurred within two years for BRCA1 carriers; the protective effect appeared immediately and lasted about 15 years. Nearly half the cohort had oophorectomy an average of six years after diagnosis; there were nine ovarian cancer deaths among women who did not have the surgery. The authors and journal editors recommended considering oophorectomy in treatment discussions for BRCA mutation carriers, particularly BRCA1 and those with estrogen-receptor–negative cancers, and called for further studies, especially in BRCA2 carriers. The passage also notes BRCA1/2 mutations confer a lifetime breast cancer risk of about 50–80% (up to 70% mentioned earlier), are more common in Ashkenazi Jewish women (~2.3%), and that Angelina Jolie underwent oophorectomy after prior double mastectomy and reported feeling feminine and grounded.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by Amtrak train No. 80, the Carolinian, shortly before 10 a.m. on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina, on Norfolk-Southern property; both were pronounced dead at the scene, none of the 166 passengers were injured (though one man fell ill during the delay and received treatment), and the train was delayed about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its Charlotte–New York City route (a trip that normally takes about 13 hours 30 minutes) toward its next stop near Raleigh, roughly 25 miles southeast of Durham.

Carlos Toro, 66, a former mid-level Medellín cartel member who fled Colombia in the 1980s and spent 27 years as a DEA undercover informant—helping prosecute figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega and participating in undercover stings worldwide—says he faces deportation after retiring due to declining health because the U.S. never granted the promised citizenship; his final temporary visa expired on January 1, he is technically living illegally, cannot collect Social Security without a green card or passport, the DEA declined to assist after he went public, a former handler and a colleague have privately given him $5,000, and Toro fears returning to Colombia where he says he would be killed.

The passage reports that ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for selling new ".sucks" top-level domains, which critics say are being used to extort celebrities and companies—examples of purchased or targeted names include youtube.sucks, bing.sucks, visa.sucks, bankofamerica.sucks, yahoo.sucks and personal names like Kevin Spacey’s, who reportedly paid to have his removed; Vox Populi charged trademark holders about $2,499 a year (resellers sold many around $2,000) while offering public registrations for $10 a year starting in September; an ICANN advisory panel of industry groups including Microsoft, Verizon and eBay called the rollout a “shakedown scheme” and asked ICANN to halt it, and ICANN has asked U.S. and Canadian regulators to determine whether Vox Populi’s actions are illegal and warned it could seek remedies or declare the company in breach of its contract.

A baby boy was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury’s bag floating in Windmill Pit, Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, on June 5, 1988; villagers paid for his burial at St Peter’s church, and he was buried unnamed. During a periodical review last year police exhumed his remains, took DNA from his leg bone, and matched it via the national database to a relative, which led them to a woman who admitted she had secretly delivered a stillborn baby and placed him in the pond; she was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped after she gave a detailed account and investigators found no evidence of third‑party involvement or foul play. A second post‑mortem also found no signs of foul play, the baby was reburied on June 5 last year with a headstone naming him Peter paid for by the stillbirth support group Hana’s Gift, and police said the case—unsolved for 27 years—was closed while the CPS considers whether to charge the woman with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, mistakenly believed passenger Kristopher Hicks intended to "do a runner" and, after driving him nearly a mile back toward the taxi rank to teach him a lesson, caused Hicks to jump from the moving vehicle at over 20mph in November 2010; Hicks, then 23 and now severely brain-injured, developed epilepsy and requires round-the-clock care from his mother, and the High Court, where Mr Justice Edis found Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, ruled Hicks is entitled to damages (reduced by 50 percent for the risky choice to jump) plus £250 for unlawful imprisonment, with the final compensation—expected to be around half the family’s request and thought to be in the hundreds of thousands of pounds—to be decided at a further hearing and both sides given permission to appeal.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas Wednesday night as multiple storms produced tornado reports, including one about 6 miles northwest of Goddard (under 15 miles west of Wichita) that moved northeast and missed the city, plus three sightings near Aetna in southwestern Kansas; the Storm Prediction Center and CNN expert Chad Myers warned nighttime tornadoes are especially dangerous and more storms could pop up overnight. The severe weather affected other states too: the National Weather Service reported a possible tornado in Potosi, Missouri (about 70 miles from St. Louis), where CNN affiliate KMOV received reports of wind damage, flooding, a fallen tree, roof damage and flooded streets; nearby residents posted photos of dark clouds and reports of baseball‑size hail. More storms were forecast Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold says he'll be the aggressive "bull" against Lyoto Machida's evasive "matador" in their New Jersey middleweight clash, aiming to cut Machida off, pressure him, exploit perceived holes in his game (especially on the ground), and use his complete skill set to dominate and earn a title shot after a three-fight win streak since losing to Vitor Belfort. Rockhold praises Machida's long-standing martial-arts pedigree and mutual respect but plans to chase and overwhelm him, while Machida, coming off a win over CB Dollaway, believes his style and technique can stop Rockhold, sees some potential weaknesses but must feel them out in the fight, and feels well prepared after an eight-week camp.

A light Aerostar twin aircraft touched down gear-up on a runway at Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, skidding on its belly with propellers striking the tarmac and wings bouncing; the pilot re-engaged full throttle, the engines remained running despite propeller and belly damage, and the plane took off again, later flying about 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where 85-year-old pilot Chris Georgaklis—an almost 50-year veteran flyer who had his dog Buddy aboard—landed safely; the videographer described the impacts and presumed severe damage, noted the pilot initially appeared to forget to lower the gear, and the FAA is investigating, with gear-up landings most commonly caused by human error or mechanical failure.

Manuel Pellegrini said he is disappointed with Yaya Touré’s performances this season but will back the Manchester City midfielder until at least the end of the season, rejecting calls that Touré needs a rest; Sportsmail reported City will listen to offers for the 31-year-old, who has two years left on a £220,000-a-week deal. City have struggled, taking 18 points from the last 39 and face West Ham without injured captain Vincent Kompany; goalkeeper Joe Hart said players must take responsibility but that Pellegrini retains the dressing room’s backing. Separately, West Ham’s Aaron Cresswell has drawn City and Chelsea interest, and Sam Allardyce warned him not to make the same mistake as some English players who moved to City but did not play much, citing Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair.

Domenico Rancadore, a 65-year-old Sicilian mafia member who fled to Britain in 1995 and lived in the Uxbridge area under the name Marc Skinner for around 20 years, will be allowed to remain in the UK after an Italian seven-year sentence for mafia association (convicted in absentia in 1999) was declared expired and his European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn; although his conviction stands, Italian law extinguishes sentences once a period longer than double the penalty has passed, and an Italian appeals court agreed the conviction was too old to sustain imprisonment, with the case still potentially subject to the Italian supreme court. The extradition proceedings had been protracted — Rancadore was arrested on a European arrest warrant in London in August 2013 and fought extradition, with UK judges raising human-rights concerns over his health — and the Crown Prosecution Service acknowledged errors, including failing to file appeal papers in time in 2014, which opponents say contributed to delays and the eventual expiry of the enforceable sentence.

Mr Mole, AP McCoy’s mount, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites for the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, alongside Irish raider Special Tiara (trained by Paul Nicholls) and Nicky Henderson’s Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville in place of the injured Barry Geraghty; Mr Mole will be McCoy’s last ride in a Grade One race, his final-day ride bookings won’t be finalised until Friday morning, and McCoy had announced his intention to quit riding after Mr Mole’s Newbury victory in February; other runners include Mick Channon’s Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter recently viewed crime-scene photos of her daughter Marcia, who was raped, strangled and left clothed in a garage under a shower curtain and a child's wading pool in 1975; Marcia's body, found 33 days after she disappeared with a fractured neck bone, vomit on her, pulled-out hair and blood on her scalp, made the case Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years. Ritter had long declined to see photos at the urging of her then-husband Charlie, but last year asked lead investigator Mickey Miller to show them; seeing the close-ups devastated her and provoked a desire for revenge. Jerome Sidney Barrett, who had been incarcerated on sex charges for much of 1974–2002, was arrested in Memphis in 2006 after DNA from the child's clothing matched him, and in 2009 a Davidson County jury convicted the 68-year-old of second-degree murder and sentenced him to 44 years.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one, says it is "unthinkable" he won't eventually win the Masters to complete the career Grand Slam and aims to claim his first green jacket at Augusta, a course he believes he can win multiple times; he views his 2011 final-round collapse—when he held a four-shot lead but shot 80 and finished 10 behind Charl Schwartzel—as the most important lesson of his career, saying it taught him what to change and helped him subsequently win the 2011 US Open by eight shots and later the 2012 US PGA and both the Open and US PGA last year. McIlroy has only one top-10 in six Masters appearances (T8 last year), hopes the course can be a "sanctuary" from hype, and acknowledges if he doesn't win this year it may simply not be the right time.

The passage recaps this week’s trending online stories: four rainbows were photographed over the New York area by Amanda Curtis after heavy rain; China is cracking down on the growing practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes; Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during a UK Channel 4 interview about his private life; the viral #kyliejennerchallenge involves lip-plumping by sucking on jars; filmmakers helped 102-year-old Alice Barker revisit her past; a prom proposal referencing bombs sparked accusations of racism when a school objected; Ewan McGregor was announced to play Lumière in Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp appears nearly unrecognizable in the Black Mass trailer; someone announced a pregnancy using a Fresh Prince of Bel-Air reference; and a military dad photobombed his son—these items all trended this week.

New figures show 272 children with foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalised in England over the past 12 months, though experts warn many more are likely affected; WHO research cited suggests at least 1 in 100 UK babies (about 7,500 a year) could suffer learning, behavioural and physical problems from prenatal alcohol exposure. The condition is lifelong and under-diagnosed, says Elizabeth Mitchell of the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome. A highlighted case, 15-year-old Niamh Brown, needs help dressing, has no sense of danger, and cannot live independently after being diagnosed at five. Associated medical issues include liver, kidney and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss and epilepsy. Government advice currently says pregnant women should not exceed two units up to twice a week, but Mitchell argues guidance should recommend abstinence.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender nicknamed "boomerang boy" for repeatedly returning to crime, burst into Shildon post office and stores in County Durham on March 15 waving an axe and demanding cash; shop owner Sab Dhillon tackled and wrestled him to the floor while Dhillon’s wife Sam struck McKerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him and exposing his face to CCTV, after which police arrived and arrested him; McKerry, who began shoplifting at 12 and had numerous prior arrests and convictions, pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court and was jailed for six years.

Four Royal Navy sailors — Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31) and Darren Smalley (35) — have been charged in Canada with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault after an alleged gang rape of a young Halifax-area woman following a Royal Navy ice hockey tournament at Shearwater naval base on April 10; they appeared in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia court, were granted bail of over £2,000 each with unusual conditions requiring them to surrender passports, remain in Nova Scotia (living at Stadacona naval base), continue employment with the Royal Navy and avoid contact with the victim and six witnesses, and were ordered to return to court on May 27 while Canadian investigators and the British High Commission assist the ongoing early-stage investigation that could yield further charges.

A Las Vegas mother, Valerie Jackson, cares for her four-year-old son R.J., one of about 70 people worldwide with the rare congenital skin disorder Netherton’s syndrome, which makes his skin appear red, scaly and scalded, causes pain, hair/infection/allergy problems, and often required intensive neonatal care; R.J. is regularly covered in creams (Vaseline) and bathed infrequently to manage symptoms, but because his appearance is misunderstood the family faces ignorance, bullying, denial of entry to play centers and even a false child-abuse report that led to armed police surrounding them while shopping; Valerie found the diagnosis via an international Facebook support group, says there is no cure though symptoms often improve with age, and stresses her son is a happy child who deserves understanding.

Protein World’s “Are you beach body ready?” London Underground posters featuring 24-year-old model Renee Somerfield sparked widespread backlash from feminists, body-image campaigners and social media users, prompting a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures, hundreds of complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) and defacement of some posters; Transport for London said the ads are being removed at the end of their paid three-week run and that future similar ads would be considered in light of customer reaction. Protein World defended the unretouched image and its campaign as promoting fitness, with its marketing head calling the controversy the work of an “irrational minority,” while the company and staff reported threats including a bomb scare under police investigation. The campaign prompted protests in Hyde Park, intense media debate (including on Good Morning Britain where presenter Susanna Reid called the ad “anxiety inducing”), and divided responses from public figures—some defending the ads and urging fitness, others condemning them for promoting unhealthy or unrealistic body standards—against a backdrop of rapidly growing UK protein powder sales.

Rail firms planned significant fare increases—up to 87% on some routes—shortly after the general election despite major parties pledging fare freezes or caps. Prime Minister David Cameron asked First Great Western to urgently review plans to nearly double fares on services between London and the Cotswolds (e.g., an off-peak return from Charlbury rising from £33.30 to £62.40 from May 17), prompting local anger. Train companies may raise "unregulated" fares (about half their revenue) at three annual windows; these include off-peak, leisure and advance tickets. First Great Western says the change aligns the North Cotswolds route with other services and offers cheaper advance singles (returns as low as £20 if booked ahead). Other increases cited: London Midlands off-peak first-class single Crewe–Northampton £30→£37; Virgin anytime Stafford–Liverpool £26.50→£33 (24.5%); Virgin Manchester–Stoke first-class day return £29→£35.30 (22%). Virgin said most rises affect its cheaper "Virgin-only" fares and that its overall West Coast fare increase was 1.65%, below the industry average. Trainsplit.com noted many anytime and off-peak returns rose by 40% in January and highlighted fare hikes on day-purchase and rural-route tickets.

Former soldier and retired HGV driver John Young, 66, and his new wife Elaine, 54, were at home in Oldham writing wedding thank-you cards about 11:20pm when vandals began throwing stones and bricks at their front window and door; after a brick smashed the glass John opened the door to remonstrate and was struck in the left eye by another brick, suffering a forehead wound and a serious eye injury that, despite emergency surgery, left him blind in that eye. The attack, three weeks after the couple’s wedding, prompted a Greater Manchester Police investigation; officers say there appears to be no known motive and it may have been yobs “messing around.” The couple, frightened to remain in the neighborhood, plan to move, and police urge anyone with information to call 101.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, who missed the entire 2014 season after suffering leg injuries in a road accident last April that also killed his father Keith and required an ankle operation, has signed a one-year contract extension keeping him at the county through the end of the 2016 season following a successful comeback during Derbyshire’s pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi; Elite Performance Director Graeme Welch praised Poynton’s character, training and off-field work since the tragedy, noted his good form in training and Abu Dhabi, and said the new contract should give him confidence to perform this summer.

A five-year-old boy, Harley Renshaw from Stretford, was diagnosed with aggressive neuroblastoma affecting his kidney, neck, lungs and bones and underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, surgery to remove a kidney tumour, a stem cell transplant with complications, and weeks of radiotherapy during which he decorated his immobilisation mask as a Ninja Turtle to feel braver; after about a year of treatment he has been declared cancer-free, will have regular check-ups, received recognition (Cancer Research UK’s Little Star award) and became the face of its Kids & Teens campaign, and his story prompted Nickelodeon to send Ninja Turtle gifts. Neuroblastoma is a rare childhood cancer (fewer than 100 UK cases yearly), arising in specialised nerve cells often in adrenal glands or nerve tissue along the spinal cord, can spread to bone marrow, bone, lymph nodes, liver and skin, mainly affects children under five, causes variable symptoms depending on tumour site, and is treated with surgery, chemotherapy, antibody therapy, radiotherapy and sometimes stem-cell transplant.

Tim Sherwood says Jack Grealish should focus on forcing his way into Aston Villa's first team rather than his international future, after the 19-year-old impressed in Villa's FA Cup semi win over Liverpool and is being courted by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood—who likened Grealish's choice to Nabil Bentaleb’s decision between France and Algeria—stresses the player should play more for Villa before deciding, praising Grealish's confidence, dribbling and composure. Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England at season's end, is currently split between the two, has played for Ireland's youth teams, and his father Kevin agrees club form should come first.

Private jet landing fees vary widely worldwide, with some unexpected hubs charging the highest prices: a list (based on a 767-400 aircraft) compiled by The Richest and PrivateFly shows the three most expensive are all in Japan—Haneda (£4,559/$6,850), Narita (£3,728/$5,600) and Kansai (£3,594/$5,400)—followed by Toronto Pearson (£3,461/$5,200), Darwin (£3,059/$4,600), Bristol (£2,929/$4,400), Chūbu Centrair Nagoya (£2,863/$4,300), Dublin (£2,729/$4,100), LaGuardia (£2,630/$3,950) and Salzburg (£2,530/$3,800). Private jet travel is a growing, high-value industry—2.5 million private flights in the US and 705,000 in Europe (2013), with US and European markets worth $16.7 trillion and $15.8 trillion respectively—and peak demand and prices occur around major events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix (example charter round trips for Super Bowl: ~$38,000–$54,000). Popular short private routes include Los Angeles–Las Vegas (~£2,890/$4,340) and Milan–Rome (~$5,880 one way).

Katie Gallegos of Clackamas County, Oregon, filmed her Labrador Cooper and smaller pal Daisy getting fast-food treats: at a McDonald’s drive‑thru Daisy takes a few licks of an ice cream cone while Cooper gobbles the rest in one bite, and a separate video shows them at Starbucks where Cooper takes a “pup‑uccino” (a cup of whipped cream without coffee); Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, says Cooper always eats very quickly so she lets Daisy go first, defends giving them occasional ice cream citing her healthy, athletic dog and the long‑lived example of a previous dog, and the McDonald’s clip has been viewed over seven million times, though some viewers criticized feeding the pups such treats.

Kilmarnock have appointed interim manager Gary Locke on a permanent three-year deal; the 41-year-old, who had joined last summer as assistant to Allan Johnston and took charge when Johnston resigned in early February, has lost just once in seven games since taking over and will speak at a Friday morning press conference.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp of Eustis, says Seminole County elementary school staff threatened to suspend her five-year-old autistic son Logan because of scented essential oils (from doTERRA, including lavender, chamomile and sandalwood) she applies to his head and neck to help him stay calm and focused; she claims he has used them all year until a teacher’s aide complained and the local school board sent a letter saying the oils created a “problem” for staff and students, though Lake County school district later told the station they would not suspend Logan, calling it a “health issue,” and Kemp says she will continue to fight the decision.

A beachfront Hamptons apartment complex, the Sandpiper in Westhampton (used as a holiday home between May and November), was destroyed by a fire Wednesday afternoon that spread through 90 condos and caused the building to collapse; smoke and flames were visible from about three miles away and reportedly melted paint on nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews used cranes and fought the blaze but could not enter the summer homes; firefighters said offshore wind helped visibility, and investigators are looking into claims the fire began near a parked car. Residents and the building manager, Rob Taber, said they lost everything, and witnesses described flames pouring from every window.

The passage describes the 88-year-old queen riding her black fell pony Carltonlima Emma in Windsor Great Park without a helmet, preferring a silk scarf and explaining she never wears riding hats because of her hair; she has ridden since age four when given a Shetland pony named Peggy, has long loved and bred horses and ponies (including fell ponies and highland ponies at Balmoral and a stud at Hampton Court), has cut back on riding due to a niggling knee injury that ended her trooping the colour on horseback, and remains a familiar sight at Windsor stables with some grandchildren riding her animals; it also outlines the fell pony breed—docile, hardy, mostly black/grey/bay, 13–14hh, ancient Cumbrian origins, valued by the Carvetii, Romans, Vikings and Normans, used historically as pack animals and for industrial transport, later becoming a popular riding pony from the 1950s—and notes the queen breeds fell ponies at Hampton Court (source: The Fell Pony Society).

An argument between Brisbane neighbours over noise left 55-year-old Leon Yeaman dead after 28-year-old Phillip Pama allegedly struck him once in the head during a confrontation outside their North Brisbane homes; Yeaman, who neighbours described as generous and also as a schizophrenic pensioner who played loud music, was making noise in his yard around 9 pm while Pama, a married father of three who works a 3 am warehouse shift and had been sleeping, confronted him, after which paramedics could not revive Yeaman and he was pronounced dead at about 11 pm. Pama, who has no history of violence and was reportedly distraught, was charged with manslaughter, granted conditional bail with conditions including surrendering his passport, a 6 pm–2 am curfew and twice-weekly police reporting, and the case is due back in court on May 18.

A 52-year-old Russian music teacher, Yulia Simonova, allegedly tried to hire a hitman to torture and kill her 15-year-old former pupil, Damian Vanya, after he ended their year-long sexual relationship and began seeing a classmate; she offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) and was filmed by a hidden camera during a sting operation with an undercover officer posing as the killer, explicitly instructing him to break the boy’s arms and legs, damage his kidneys so he would bleed out, and cause unbearable pain before she would “finish him”; after handing over some expense money she was arrested in her car, remanded on attempted murder charges and faces up to 15 years in prison, while Vanya said he was relieved and hoped they would “throw away the key” for her cell.

Jose Mourinho, the 52-year-old Chelsea manager and father of two, says he prays and talks to God every day but only prays about his personal life—not about football—and does not discuss the game with his wife; he attends church when he feels the need and more regularly when in Portugal. He and his family have worked with the World Food Programme as ambassadors against hunger and say they understand poverty. Mourinho insists he separates professional and family life, considers himself a good family man and friend despite being competitive and emotional in his job (which has led to incidents such as a £25,000 fine earlier this season), and Chelsea are currently top of the league ahead of a match with struggling QPR.

Bob Barker, who hosted The Price Is Right for 35 years before stepping down in 2007, returned to host for the April 1 edition, marking his first time back in eight years; at age 91 he looked spry, handled the first game, "Lucky Seven," then handed hosting duties back to current host Drew Carey, and appeared not to miss a beat.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested at 12:30 a.m. Friday on the 3200 block of D Street SE in Washington, D.C., accused of attempting to break into a house; he faces felony attempted burglary and destruction of property charges and was to be arraigned Friday afternoon. The Metropolitan Police arrested him after returning to the scene, and the Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave; Baldwin is posted to the Foreign Missions Branch attached to the State Department. His arrest follows other recent misconduct allegations within the agency — including a supervisor placed on leave and an inspector general probe into a March 4 incident involving two senior officials allegedly driving into a secure White House area after drinking — adding to scrutiny of the agency.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore risked his life at the city safari park by leaving his car to photograph a male lion; he crept to within about 10 feet, lay on the ground and fired off a few frames with only his camera before the shutter alerted the hungry lion, which then aggressively jumped toward him and forced him to scramble back into his car; he said he wanted to show the lion's character and status, found the encounter very close, and now doubts he would do it again.

New York City police released images of a distinctive faded tattoo — a heart topped with a rose and a ribbon bearing the name "Monique" — found on the right leg of an unidentified woman, believed to be 25 to 45 years old, who was discovered unconscious and later pronounced dead on the evening of March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn; she had no identification, authorities are awaiting the medical examiner’s report on the cause of death, and anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, bought a 1986 Hino flatbed and spent about a year and a half converting it into a solar-powered, wood-and-steel two-bedroom home on the truck bed after returning from the UK because they couldn't afford property; costing roughly $25,000, the home features aromatic cypress interiors, stained glass, a wood-fired stove, gas hot water and stove, water from a nearby spring, mostly solar electricity (their first bill was $25), and sits on a lot in Nelson surrounded by trees and a brook, with plans to build another like it someday.

Researchers report that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class over an academic year performed significantly better on early literacy tests than peers in classes with no iPads or with one device per student, scoring about 30 points higher; the study by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern involved 352 students in a midwestern suburban district and suggests collaborative learning around the tablets—rather than mere collaboration—drove the improvement, leading her to suggest schools reconsider how tablets are used in early grades; she will present the findings at the 65th annual International Communication Association conference in Puerto Rico.

A piglet in Qionglai City, Sichuan province, born without hind legs, has become an online and local sensation after learning to balance and move on its front trotters; filmed wobbling and foraging with its snout to the ground, the animal—nicknamed "super pig"—manages to regain balance when close to tipping, mixes happily with its fully-legged littermates, and has drawn villagers to see it, while similar two-legged animals (like a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo) have previously attracted attention in China.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, pit crew member Todd Phillips, the front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was struck when Francesco Dracone spun while exiting his pit box after coming in on lap 25 for tires and fuel, clipping Phillips’ leg; Phillips received stitches at the infield care center and was released. Many cars struggled with traction after hours of rain before the green flag, and Dracone did not finish, placing 23rd.

CCTV shows Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, drag his wife Cicera Alves de Sena, 29 — a dancer in the troupe Jaula das Gostozuedas who performed as Amanda Bueno — into their apartment garden in Rio de Janeiro, slam the back of her head into concrete 11 times, punch her about 10 times, leave her unconscious, then return with a handgun and shoot her in the face five times; he reportedly yelled that she was a "slut" and confessed the killing, saying he was jealous of men looking at her, stole a neighbor’s car after the shooting, crashed during the getaway, and was arrested with four handguns, a shotgun and a bulletproof vest in the car and now faces life in jail.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, 41, revealed in an interview that her anxiety, compounded by stress, thyroid disease and family distance, once led her to feel life was not worth living and to come close to suicide; she described feeling isolated for not having a husband or children, believing she had “missed out on a guide book to life,” and now accepts she is an anxious person who has recently found some peace, arguing that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and warning anxiety is becoming “the new depression,” with Beyond Blue reporting one in three Australian women will experience anxiety and resources like Beyond Blue and Lifeline available for help.

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old Portland woman who was seven months pregnant in November 2014, was charged with second-degree assault for striking her boyfriend’s former girlfriend in the head and arm with a crowbar after finding her shooting heroin in Curtin’s bathroom; prosecutors dropped the case this week, saying Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." Oregon law permits physical force against an intruder who won’t leave a resident’s home; Curtin gave birth in January and is now living with her parents while the boyfriend, who has struggled with heroin and is the father of Curtin’s child, has not been part of the child’s life. Curtin’s lawyer said the ex had harassed, threatened, stolen from and tried to draw the boyfriend back into addiction, and had previously reconciled with the boyfriend with whom she shares a five-year-old child; had Curtin been convicted at trial she faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed being fed treats when her owner tried to trick her by adding a broccoli spear; she made a disgusted face, chewed it, then spat it onto the floor. The passage notes she lives with two children who hopefully won’t imitate her, and that other videos show Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologised after a hyperlink on its official website’s community projects page, which had pointed to the Young Entrepreneur Awards page (scrapped in 2011), directed visitors to a pornographic site because the awards’ URL registration was allowed to lapse and the porn site took over the address; HSBC removed the link, denied any association with the external site, said its website remained secure, and apologised for any inconvenience.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 shortly before 7 a.m. after smelling smoke and calmly guided firefighters during an 11-minute call while trapped with his nine-year-old sister Aaliyah in a second-floor bedroom of their Clinton home because the hallway was too hot; he told the dispatcher their older brother, mother and stepfather were also home, soothed his sister and gave directions to the firefighters, who entered by breaking a window, Lieutenant Kenny Ward handed Marcus out and gave his gas mask to Aaliyah after feeling her tug his leg; both children were taken to Children’s Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, and the three other family members escaped on their own and were treated at MedStar Hospital.

Photographs from Jervis Bay on New South Wales' south coast show blue fluorescent bioluminescence lighting up a popular beach, which photographer Andy Hutchinson called a "beautiful supernatural scene" produced by millions of plankton emitting light; experts say the glow is caused by noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled, carnivorous phytoplankton that preys on diatoms and typically blooms in spring and autumn, and a similar display occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014.

New genetic tests that analyze tumour markers, such as the EndoPredict test, can determine how aggressive a breast cancer is and estimate a patient’s risk of recurrence within days after surgery, allowing some women to safely skip chemotherapy when a low score indicates recurrence risk as low as about 5 percent—similar to or better than the benefit chemotherapy would offer. Chemotherapy is commonly given after tumour removal to reduce recurrence but causes severe side effects; these tests (mostly privately available at about £2,500) could spare patients those effects and help inform choices, with specialists arguing the NHS should adopt them because savings from avoided chemotherapy may offset costs. A patient example: Becca Cornford received a low EndoPredict score after surgery, was told her ten-year recurrence risk was about 5 percent, and chose to forgo chemotherapy while continuing regular monitoring.

Freedom of Information data and media reports show more than 25 Royal Navy women have been airlifted from ships because of pregnancy, including five emergency medevacs from HMS Ocean over nine years and at least one from now-decommissioned HMS Illustrious; 18 other ships such as HMS Dragon, Enterprise and Richmond also had evacuations. The MoD enforces a strict "no touching" rule at sea, implying most conceptions occurred before deployment or during leave; women have served on ships since 1990 (about 9% of personnel in 2014) and the first female submariners joined in 2014. Separately, nearly 100 British servicewomen were sent home from Afghanistan for pregnancy between 2006 and 2013 (99), with 16 returned in 2013, 18 in 2011, and 102 evacuated from Iraq; strict rules bar pregnant personnel from war zones, they are flown back at the first opportunity—often on flights for injured troops—and troops are reminded (but not forced) to check for pregnancy before deployment.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material was found on the roof of Japan’s prime minister Shinzo Abe’s residence, prompting police and government concern about potential drone terrorism; the quad-rotor, about 50 cm wide, carried a small camera, smoke flares and a plastic bottle believed to contain small, not immediately harmful traces of cesium, a common nuclear byproduct also found after the Fukushima Daiichi meltdown. The find occurred the same day a court approved restarting two reactors at Sendai, a move unpopular with many Japanese, and raised warnings from Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga about possible future terrorism risks at events like the Olympics and G7, prompting calls to review drone operation rules; current law restricts flights near airports but not over most of Tokyo, including the prime minister’s residence, and Abe was in Indonesia at the time.

A devoted security guard in Zhejiang province, China, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old mother—who has Alzheimer’s—on the back of his motorbike to work every day because she used to wander off and there is no one else to care for her after his father’s recent death; he wakes her at 5 a.m., ties a sash around both their waists to prevent her falling, rides four kilometres slowly (the trip takes an hour) so they can chat, checks on her during work where his employers (a bank) have given her a room, and says he feels it is his duty to repay her for raising him.

A University of Washington Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation study published in the American Journal of Public Health found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2% from 2005 to 2012, driven largely by increases in women’s drinking and binge drinking; nationwide in 2012, 8% were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers, with county variation (e.g., Madison County, Idaho 6% binge rate; Menominee, Wis. 36%). Heavy drinking is defined by the CDC as averaging more than one drink per day for women and two for men over the past month, and binge drinking as four-plus drinks for women or five-plus for men on a single occasion at least once in the past month. Researchers reported that overall alcohol use prevalence stayed about the same, noted about 88,600 U.S. deaths were alcohol-attributed in 2010 and excessive drinking costs exceed $220 billion annually, and cited cultural and economic factors for rising consumption—changing social norms for women, greater binge drinking among young people, affluence in certain urban areas, relatively cheaper alcohol due to taxes not keeping pace with inflation, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. The study analyzed roughly 3.7 million adults aged 21+ from the CDC’s Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System and is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level.

UN officials, including WHO experts, warn that doctors are overusing caesarean sections, putting women and babies at risk by performing them when not medically necessary; while C-sections can save lives, they can also cause infections, significant complications, disability or death and divert funds from other patients. In England just over a quarter of births are by C-section—more than double since the early 1990s—partly due to planned C-sections for anxious women (tokophobia) and for reasons such as prior complicated birth, maternal age over 40, or medical conditions. WHO says an ideal rate is 10–15%, contrasts with NHS/NICE guidance (revised 2011) that allows offering C-sections without strict medical justification, and notes a planned C-section costs the NHS about £2,369 versus £1,665 for a natural birth; prior research indicates up to 1 in 10 C-sections cause infections.

A 44-year-old woman, Michelle Filkins of West Wareham, was arrested April 17 after owner Mark Conklin found her sitting in his Edgartown summer home on Court Street; she is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Conklin confronted her, she claimed she owned the $800,000 property and fled in a gray Nissan pickup; police later found a broken front-side glass window covered by a blanket. A neighborhood construction worker reported seeing Filkins outside with items from the home appearing to be sold or given away in a yard sale; missing items listed by police include deck chairs, a Weber grill, side tables, lamps, framed posters, pots, pans, linens, and a painting. Filkins was arrested after attempting to re-enter the home hours later, is due in court May 14, and police ask anyone who received items to return them or contact EPD at 508-627-4343 for assistance seeking restitution.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke of Melbourne, lost at a friend’s birthday party Saturday night, was handed in to Albury police station on the NSW–Victoria border Sunday morning; officers discovered it was unlocked and used it to post selfies, puns and photos (including the phone in a holding “cell”) on Bella’s Facebook page to prompt her to collect it, joking about charging and “release” for good behaviour and even replying to friends’ texts; by the time Bella arrived she had not seen the posts, officers recognized her from Facebook so she reclaimed the phone without giving her name, laughed at the stunt, has since set a password, and praised the police for their humor.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was caught and killed during a fight between two adult male hippos in iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa: the mother stayed with her herd while the males battled in muddy water, one sub-adult grabbed the calf in its jaws, the mother tried to intervene but the attacker bit down harder and flung the baby into the air before dragging it along the water; the calf died hours later, witnessed by tour operator Stacey Farrell.

A three-bedroom, 1,990 sq ft unmodernised maisonette on exclusive Egerton Place in Knightsbridge has been listed for £575,000 but carries just three years left on the lease, making the effective cost roughly £191,000 per year (about £15,000 per month), similar to local rental rates; if renovated and the lease extended, agents estimate its value could rise to around £6m (the larger 2,500 sq ft maisonette to £7.5m), with lease extension to 90 years likely to cost between £3.35m and £4.5m payable to the freeholder (thought to be the Wellcome Trust). The property, described as bright and well proportioned with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, reception, utility, lift, parking and communal garden, is one of two such short-lease flats offered by Russell Simpson (£575k and £595k) and has attracted strong interest, though advisers warn buyers the apparent bargain masks a “massive premium” required to extend the lease and significant renovation costs.

Starbucks experienced a point-of-sale computer outage Friday evening that affected registers at about 8,000 company-operated stores in the U.S. (7,000) and Canada (1,000), preventing credit-card transactions and prompting some baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods before many locations closed early; the company said the outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh and also affecting Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores, was resolved by late Friday and stores were expected to reopen for business as usual Saturday, while social media lit up with photos and reactions amid reports that some stores chose not to give free products; the incident came a day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion and its shares rose 4.4%.

An officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, Detective Constable Gareth Jones, warned that rural areas of west Wales—specifically Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire—are being used to radicalise Muslims and conduct training, with extremists blending into ordinary community activities; historical links include alleged 1998 training in the Brecon Beacons, 2005 photos of two 7/7 bombers rafting in North Wales, a 2010s al-Qaida-inspired plot by Cardiff men, and Michael Adebowale’s reported study at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder, and DC Jones urged the importance of community intelligence.

A juvenile 5.68 m female Omura's whale, a species only formally described in 2003 and usually found in Indonesian, Philippine and Sea of Japan waters, was found dead after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn on a remote Exmouth beach at the tip of Western Australia’s North West Cape—the first WA sighting and only the second in Australia; identification required DNA profiling, the carcass has been buried, and its skeleton will be recovered later for scientific study and possible museum display to improve field identification and understanding of the species’ regional distribution and unique features (sleek body, 53 vertebrae, four digits on each pectoral fin).

The passage criticizes claims that women's hormones make them unfit for the presidency, sparked by Texas businesswoman Cheryl Rios saying Hillary Clinton shouldn't be president because of female hormones and threatening to move to Canada if Clinton won; it counters that men’s hormones have led to poor decisions and infidelity among male politicians, and cites studies showing women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks. The piece highlights pervasive gender bias—both overt (few women on boards) and covert (men labeled “geniuses,” women “nice”)—that makes it harder for women like Clinton to win office, notes Time called Clinton the “perfect” age because she’s postmenopausal, and argues equality benefits everyone—improving companies, families, marriages, and teams—so society must challenge stereotypes that limit girls and women. A correction clarifies an earlier error about Canada’s election of Kim Campbell.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is auctioning more than 200 antiques and collectibles—238 lots—through Dominic Winter auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, in a sale expected to raise around £100,000 as he downsizes his Cotswolds home; the collection, built from his interests in classic literature and military history (he studied English at Magdalen College under J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis and has written two books on the longbow), includes a hand-painted limewood 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt by L.M. Rendall (est. £4,000–£6,000), a yew longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle and a portrait of Hardy with the bow (up to £2,000), Gillows cabinets (up to £4,000), paintings (including an early 20th-century Alfred the Great by Frank Owen Salisbury), furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers and dozens of books dating back to the 17th century; Hardy, sad to part with his treasured library, has retired from the stage after a fall but intends to continue television work and is known for roles including Siegfried Farnon in All Creatures Great and Small, multiple portrayals of Winston Churchill, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a Florida man wanted as a suspect in the murder of his 57-year-old mother, Sandra Shemansky, whose body was found Saturday at the Winter Garden home they shared after an out-of-state relative requested a welfare check; police say foul play is suspected and they have the murder weapon but have not disclosed how she died. Shemansky drew attention after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son the same day; neighbors and reports suggest family stress from his divorce and recent paperwork may have triggered him, and his estranged wife had previously filed a domestic violence injunction. He is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar disorder and a past involuntary psychiatric commitment for a suicide attempt, was seen asking for water at the trailer park office after the murder, and was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication; authorities urge anyone with information to call 407-656-3636.

Eugene, Oregon, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships after the IAAF Council bypassed the usual bidding process, calling it a "unique strategic opportunity" to stage the championships in the USA; Eugene had lost a 2019 bid to Doha but a recent presentation convinced the IAAF it could host the event, and IAAF president Lamine Diack said public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC and an enthusiastic public are joining forces—similar non-bidding awarding occurred for the 2007 Osaka championships.

Leonie Granger, 25, an aspiring model and care assistant from Gillingham, Kent, was jailed for 16 years after being found guilty of manslaughter for luring 56-year-old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his Islington flat—having befriended him at Mayfair casinos by exploiting him as a “soft target”—so her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson, 28, and Nicholas Chandler, 29, could enter, tie him up with parcel tape, kick him to death and ransack the flat for hidden cash; Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and given life sentences with minimum terms of 36 years. The court heard Hassan had flashed large winnings and kept cash at home, was treated to meals and gifts by Granger, and was attacked after she left the door unlocked; his battered body was found in a pool of blood with bound knees and ankles. All three were convicted of robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison, and evidence included CCTV from the casino and footage of the defendants throwing stolen £50 notes around after the killing; Granger was convicted by a 10–2 majority, and mitigation cited her being led by love for Jackson, but the judge called the attack “pitiless and wicked.”

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fàbregas has shown a pattern of declining form in the second half of seasons, and his recent poor display for Spain in a 2-0 loss to Holland highlighted that slump; after a strong start to 2014-15 (15 Premier League assists by mid-January), he has managed just one assist in his last five games and four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015, jeopardizing his chance to break Thierry Henry’s single-season assist record. Despite captaining Spain and remaining ever-present for Chelsea, fatigue from playing many minutes appears to be affecting his impact, prompting concern from manager José Mourinho as Chelsea pursue the Premier League title with nine games left—six of which are against teams Fàbregas has previously assisted—so a return to form (for example his recent assist to Diego Costa at Hull) would be crucial for both personal and club ambitions.

West Ham are negotiating to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford from Montego Bay United after he impressed during a two-week trial with their academy; he is considered a top Caribbean prospect and also has offers from Belgian clubs. Separately, West Ham announced season tickets for their move to the 54,000-capacity Olympic Stadium in 2016–17 will start at £289, the lowest in the Barclays Premier League to help fill the venue.

Wiltshire police have shelved their investigation into the January 24 assault on 40-year-old Mike Lane, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, despite video footage and a dossier containing names and car registration numbers reportedly handed to them; Lane was knocked to the ground, kicked in the head, suffered concussion, broken teeth, facial swelling and memory loss, and the assailant’s face was captured on video though not identified. The attack occurred during a hunt using an artificial scent, after protesters—some wearing balaclavas and face coverings—sprayed hounds with citronella and confronted riders; Lane and hunt supporters have condemned the decision to record the case as undetected, saying police could have done more, while Wiltshire police say the inquiry cannot progress without further evidence but will reopen if new information emerges.

Adam Gadahn, born 1978 and also known as Azzam the American and Abu Suhayb, was an American who converted to Islam in 1995, left for Pakistan in 1998, joined al Qaeda, and became its chief English-language propagandist and prominent spokesman; he appeared in numerous videos (sometimes disguised, in English and Arabic) urging attacks on American, Western and Jewish targets, praising attackers like Nidal Hasan and the Benghazi killers, and urging lone‑wolf violence, and he was indicted by a federal grand jury in California in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda and listed among the FBI’s most wanted terrorists. The White House announced Gadahn, 36, was killed in January in a U.S. counterterrorism operation (he was not specifically targeted), and another U.S. citizen operative, Ahmed Farouq, also died in a likely separate operation that also killed U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein and Italian hostage Giovanni Lo Porto; documents found in Bin Laden’s compound included a 2011 Gadahn letter on media strategy.

A viral video in China features five-year-old Mai Zizhu, who has been shooting hoops since age two-and-a-half and displays advanced basketball skills—scoring successive baskets, dribbling two balls while focused on camera—earning him widespread fans and thousands of astonished online comments, with viewers comparing him to top Chinese player Yao Ming and expressing disbelief, admiration, or shame at their own abilities.

Tom O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer and key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned in the 1970s–80s to legalise sex with children and sought to legalise incest and lower the age of consent (with the NCCL lobbying to cut it to ten), has joined the supporters of media pressure group Hacked Off and attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25, chaired by John Cleese, to lobby MPs for statutory press regulation as recommended by the Leveson inquiry; O'Carroll, 69, who was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals," confirmed his attendance in a blog, and Hacked Off said the meeting was open to all members of the public.

Bondi’s iconic Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as an unusual catwalk for Ten Pieces’ presentation during Mercedes‑Benz Fashion Week Australia, where models paraded through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall against an ocean backdrop on a sunny 28°C day; Ten Pieces, a monochrome, unisex capsule label led by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and partner Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased a ten‑piece collection designed to be worn in 20 ways for day‑to‑night wear, guests enjoyed Icebergs nibbles and Santa Vittoria drinks, and both lap swimmers and passing beachgoers paused to watch the minimalist, androgynous presentation.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a Friday with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California, posing with and feeding animals including a rare white tiger, giraffes and sea lions; earlier the week he ended speculation about his next opponent by announcing he will fight former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri at welterweight on May 30, despite pressure to face British rival and IBF welterweight champion Kell Brook and links to Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian who prosecutors say was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, was listed this week on Jerusalem’s Mount Herzl memorial for fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism, prompting objections from his family and from Almagor, an Israeli victims-of-terror organization; his father said he was not asked permission and refused to have his son listed “between soldiers of the occupation,” while Almagor called the killing a rogue, individual act and demanded removal, threatening to remove their own relatives’ names if it remained; after the complaints, Israel’s National Insurance Institute — which maintains the memorial — agreed to remove Abu Khdeir’s name and it was already removed from the memorial website, and a panel of judges has been hearing evidence since January against the three suspects.

A California YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, filmed his young son chasing the family cat around the garden trying to use the cat as a pillow; the footage shows the cat licking its fur, the boy plonking himself onto the cat, the cat getting up and moving to a new spot—this repeats twice more before the cat wanders indoors, though a later video shows them reconciled with the boy gently feeding the cat handfuls of treats.

Robert Kushner, 32, a witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial and one of more than a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the government, lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after revealing he sold marijuana and testified that undercover officers stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest; school officials said the 2007 history was new to them despite Kushner having passed a 2010 background check, and Kushner said the 2007 charges were expunged and that he was innocent of separate 2011 charges (for which he received four years’ probation), while defense lawyers for six accused former drug squad officers contend the case rests on testimony from 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, after an oil leak injured six people and sparked a large fire; five victims were hurt by broken glass and hospitalized. More than 600 firefighters fought the blaze, which is now under control, and local residents reported hearing the blast and feeling tremors. The plant, which produces a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used for polyester, had a previous explosion in July 2013 with no casualties or toxic leaks. Construction of PX plants has provoked protests in China; the Zhangzhou facility was relocated from Xiamen after 2007 pollution concerns and public backlash.

Jack Grealish, the Aston Villa teenager and Republic of Ireland under-21 international, says he will keep wearing his socks low above his children's-size shin pads out of superstition despite referees telling him to pull them up; he claims he hasn't been kicked on the shin and hopes it stays that way. Grealish made his first Premier League start in the 3-3 draw with QPR, was pleased to have it over with even if unhappy with the result, and welcomed the manager saying he deserved the start and giving him confidence to earn more starts before season’s end.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, 22, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage" and remains unresponsive despite being taken off a medically induced coma, her grandmother Cissy Houston said after visiting her; doctors report she does not respond to visitors or voices, her eyes do not track people, and she has a tracheostomy. While family attorney Christopher Brown and sources say her condition has improved enough for her to be out of ICU and beginning a long rehabilitation, the long-term quality of her life is unknown and could take years to determine; Bobby Brown and his wife Alicia Etheredge-Brown described his onstage announcement that she was "awake," had opened her eyes, and started rehabilitation, noting he was emotional when speaking.

Russia moved within one win of the Fed Cup final after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Germany’s Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3, following Svetlana Kuznetsova’s straight-sets victory over Julia Goerges; Pavlyuchenkova struggled with 13 double faults while Lisicki’s 63 unforced errors proved costly, and Russia needs one win from Sunday’s three matches to reach the final and claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales already affected by last week’s east coast low are being warned to prepare for another potential storm later this week, with meteorologists and the Bureau of Meteorology indicating an east coast low or trough could bring heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday—particularly affecting coastal northern and north-eastern areas and the hard‑hit Hunter region—and raising flood levels on already saturated catchments; the State Emergency Service, with over 1,000 personnel (including 200 from other states) and 4,409 of 24,196 jobs still unfinished, is concerned further storms will hamper clean‑up efforts and urges communities to prepare homes and families, while forecasts suggest the new system may be quicker, situated further offshore and likely to produce two days of rain rather than a repeat of last week’s three days of wind and rain.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin’s "La Vida Loca" video, denied Italian media reports that she attempted suicide, saying she collapsed from low blood pressure after a domestic accident and was treated in hospital before recovering at home; she posted photos of bruising on Instagram, said her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso was in Naples at the time, and expressed shock at the suicide claims, while Italian outlets had reported her mother found her and that Favoloso suggested she tried to commit suicide; the passage also notes Moric was once married to paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son, and that Corona was jailed for blackmailing celebrities amid a high-profile media culture.

As Kate and William prepare for their second child, a YouGov poll for the Sunday Times found Diana is the favourite girl’s name (12%), followed by Alice and Charlotte (9% each), while James (13%) and Alexander are top choices for a boy; of 2,200 polled, a quarter wanted a girl and only 3% wanted another son for George. Social media users echoed support for the name Diana, and 68% of respondents approved William taking six weeks’ paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber detonated near a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, on Thursday around 10 a.m., killing 17 and wounding dozens; among the 64 wounded was an Afghan lawmaker participating in the protest, which was en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor, provincial police chief Faizullah Ghairat said. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied responsibility and no group has claimed the attack. CNN reporters Masoud Popalzai, Jethro Mullen and Elizabeth Joseph contributed to the report.

Dani Alves looks set to leave Barcelona this summer after his agent and ex-wife Dinorah Santana said he rejected the club’s final contract offer: a three-year extension conditioned on him playing in 60% of matches. Alves, 31, who has spent seven successful years at Barcelona—winning four Spanish titles and two Champions Leagues—was unable to agree a new deal, and Santana declared negotiations over.

Pablo Osvaldo, who joined Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton and has scored three goals in six games, has urged Italian stars Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca, saying both would suit the club’s South American style and that La Bombonera fans would go "absolutely crazy" for them; he described Pirlo as one of the best midfielders in world football and called Totti a Roma legend who would be equally loved in Argentina.

Eighteen-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson, who suffered a spectacular double somersault fall from favourite Merrion Square in the 4.20pm at Wincanton that has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times online, was back mucking out stables at Paul Nicholls’s yard the following Thursday with only a cut on his nose; he watched the replay in the weighing room, said he could not remember the incident until then, called the fall “a blur,” felt he was lucky, received some teasing and a few hundred Twitter followers, and joked he might pursue gymnastics after his racing career.

James Haskell celebrated the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron by posting an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Iron Man with the caption about releasing his "inner iron man" and hashtags including @underarmouruk, #transformyourself, #iwill and #avengersageofultron. The London Wasps captain, Windsor-born Haskell first joined Wasps in 2002, earned his first England cap in 2007, left in 2009 for Stade Français (two seasons), then had brief spells with Japan’s Ricoh Black Rams and New Zealand’s Highlanders before returning to Wasps for the 2012 season; since his return he has exceeded 100 club appearances and has 57 England caps to date.

The wide-leg trouser is a key SS15 trend—available in denim, cropped, printed or striped styles—and offers an alternative to skinny jeans with a 1970s-inspired silhouette seen on runways like Gucci, Céline and Stella McCartney and adapted for high street by Topshop’s Miller jean; to wear it flatteringly keep proportions simple (pair with a simple knit, shirt or tee), wear high heels (preferably with an exposed top of foot) to elongate the leg, choose high-waisted very long trousers for extra length, and opt for denim for an easy entry to the trend, with lower-cost options like Finery London and Topshop available.

The University of Michigan will proceed with a student screening of American Sniper despite a petition by over 200 students asking it be canceled because they felt the film’s depiction of the Iraq war reflected negatively on the Middle East and its large local Arab-American population; after a backlash and counter-petition, Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper said canceling the showing was a mistake inconsistent with the university’s commitment to free expression and students’ right to choose, so the screening will go on while UMix will also offer a family-friendly Paddington for those who prefer not to attend, a decision that drew praise from football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists allegedly set an aerosol spray alight with a lighter on Rottnest Island (off Perth) on April 3, producing a large flame that contacted and singed a quokka (a small marsupial about the size of a domestic cat found on Rottnest and Bald Island). Detectives questioned the men, seized video evidence, evicted them from the island, and charged the 18- and 24-year-olds (both living in Cockburn Central) with animal cruelty; they will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

At 102, former chorus-line dancer Alice Barker—who performed at 1930s–40s New York venues like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar alongside stars such as Bill “Bojangles” Robinson and Frank Sinatra—had never seen the motion pictures of herself or had any of her lost photographs and memorabilia, so with help from filmmaker Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers a compilation of early music videos called "soundies" was assembled and shown to her at her nursing home, delighting her, and prompting her to call it "just fabulous."

A study of 1,100 UK adults by vehicle leasing firm OSV indicates DIY car washing is declining: 31% of men have never washed their own car and only 12% of those who do wash regularly, while three-quarters of women never wash their own car; just 5% have ever asked children to wash cars for pocket money. Causes cited include shops open on Sundays, more live football, the growth of hand car washes, and larger 4x4s that are hard to clean. Around 15 million cars were cleaned by owners over the recent Easter break, and one in four owners say washing is mainly an excuse to get out of the house. Owner-washed cars are most common in Birmingham, Chelmsford and Sheffield and least common in Oxford, Bath and Edinburgh; Audis, Toyotas and BMWs are washed most by owners, while Range Rovers, Peugeots and Mercedes are washed least. OSV spokesperson Andrew Kirkley noted changing habits, bigger cars, less time and the availability of automated or inexpensive professional washes.

Martin Skrtel praised Steven Gerrard’s influence since Skrtel joined Liverpool in 2008, saying Gerrard helped him settle, was always there to assist, and remains “one of the best players in the world” and synonymous with the club; Skrtel acknowledged Liverpool will be different after Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy following the FA Cup final on May 30 if they defeat Aston Villa at Wembley, but believes the club has players who can replace Gerrard if supported and that both he and Gerrard could return for the Villa match after serving three-match bans for violent conduct.
