At 75, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth during the Augusta National par-3 contest, his first ace at Augusta, playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw; he celebrated with the crowd and later remarked he'd joked about needing only to win the par-3 and make a hole-in-one. The day featured five aces—Camilo Villegas also made two (fourth and eighth) but lost the contest in a playoff to world No. 74 Kevin Streelman—while Nicklaus, who became the youngest green jacket wearer in 1963 and won his sixth in 1986, is one of five men to complete the career Grand Slam, an achievement Rory McIlroy could match by winning a third consecutive major.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas Wednesday night as storms produced reports of twisters, including one about 6 miles northwest of Goddard (under 17 miles west of Wichita) that moved northeast and missed the city; other tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna, 125 miles southwest of Wichita. The National Weather Service said a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri (about 70 miles from St. Louis), where CNN affiliate KMOV reported wind damage, flooding, a fallen tree, damaged roofs and a flooded street; nearby reports included dark clouds in Leadington and baseball‑size hail in Farmington. Nighttime tornadoes were noted as particularly dangerous, and more storms were forecast Thursday for the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee river valleys and near the southern Great Lakes.

Oklahoma reserve deputy Robert Bates pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, claiming he meant to use a taser during an April 2 weapons sting but accidentally shot Harris; the judge allowed Bates to travel to the Bahamas for a family vacation, prompting criticism from Harris's family, and Bates’s preliminary hearing is set for July 2. Bates, 73, apologized along with Sheriff Stanley Glanz; the family’s lawyer alleges Bates was unqualified but received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff, and the Tulsa World reported supervisors were told to forge Bates’s records and reassigned when they refused, allegations the sheriff’s office denies. One of Bates’s lawyers released most of his training documents asserting he had proper training, and two deputies involved in the arrest were reassigned because of threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irish fighter challenging featherweight champion José Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas, unveiled a new tiger-stomach tattoo (adding to an existing chest gorilla-eating-a-heart tattoo) and posted the image on Instagram with the caption "if you see the tiger, it's too late. you're food." McGregor, who recently grabbed Aldo's belt during a Dublin promotional tour before 5,000 home supporters, says he is more motivated to win the title than Aldo is to defend it and claims Aldo "doesn't want this the way I want it" as their already fractious relationship continues ahead of Aldo's eighth title defense.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a schooner of beer in about six seconds at a University of Technology Sydney event, prompting cheers from players and chants of "skol" and "Tony"; footage and eyewitnesses described him drinking quickly and proudly. Anti-drinking campaigners and cultural studies professor Julie Robert criticized the stunt as glorifying binge drinking and linking masculinity to heavy drinking, warning the performance and media reaction risk promoting irresponsible drinking and the "true blue" Aussie bloke stereotype. Opposition leader Bill Shorten joked about Abbott's drinking, while Health Minister Sussan Ley defended him, saying his fitness habits were positive. Commentators noted past prime ministers, like Bob Hawke, similarly skolled beer, but Robert argued attitudes toward binge drinking have shifted and leaders should be mindful of that change.

Indiana reported a sharp rise in HIV cases tied to Scott County more than two weeks after Gov. Mike Pence approved a 30-day emergency needle-exchange program: 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases, up from 106 the prior week. The outbreak, declared an epidemic, has occurred among IV drug users largely using the prescription painkiller Opana; Scott County normally sees about five HIV cases per year. Since the program began March 26, 86 participants received 5,322 clean syringes and about 1,400 used syringes were returned; a mobile unit has increased participation by building trust. Pence is reviewing whether to extend the program beyond April 25 and opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy. Legislation to allow exchanges in 23 high–hepatitis C counties—viewed as indicators of needle sharing and potential HIV risk—passed the House and faces further hearings, but support in the Senate is uncertain and funding is unresolved because federal public funding for exchanges has been banned since 1989 and Pence’s order did not provide money, raising questions about sustainability.

An obsessive Arsenal fan made his girlfriend Saskia take a school-style Arsenal quiz (multiple choice, tables, short answers) and marked it with red pen; she scored 43.5/50 (87%), earning an A and sparing her from being “dumped.” The test asked about topics like the meaning of “FC,” the fans’ nickname, current manager, kit, the season’s starting XI and positions, top scorers, the 2014 FA Cup final score and who scored the winner, and to explain why Alexis Sánchez is better than Eden Hazard; Saskia misidentified some positions (confusing Özil and Welbeck) and struggled to name one starter, but earned creative answers (e.g., calling Hazard a “p***k”) and partial credit. Her boyfriend corrected wrong answers emphatically and noted areas for improvement; the story, shared on her Twitter, drew mixed reactions—many praising Saskia as “proper gf material” and calling the boyfriend a “legend,” while others thought he’d gone too far.

Carlos Toro, 66, a former mid-level Medellín cartel member who fled Colombia decades ago and spent 27 years working undercover for the DEA in exchange for a promised U.S. citizenship, now faces deportation after retiring due to declining health; despite aiding prosecutions of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega and participating in global undercover stings, he was never granted citizenship, his final temporary visa expired January 1, the DEA refused to assist after he went public, he cannot collect Social Security or obtain a passport or green card, has received a $5,000 gift from a former handler/colleague, fears for his life if returned to Colombia, and says he atoned for past crimes and only wants the promised residency.

A 14-year-old girl in Kosi Kalan, Mathura district, Uttar Pradesh, allegedly was gang-raped by five men while relieving herself and, after her family reportedly told her to stay silent, set herself on fire on Tuesday by dousing herself with kerosene; her brother extinguished the flames and she is now critically injured with 70% burns at Safdarjung Hospital in Delhi, while the accused men have been arrested. The report situates the case amid heightened sensitivity in India over sexual assault following the gang rape and murder of 23-year-old Jyoti Singh Pandey—whose attackers were convicted and several sentenced to death—bans on a documentary about that case, widespread protests, and recent vigilante killings and mob violence in response to alleged sexual crimes.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal says he has been dreaming of beating rivals Manchester City in Sunday’s derby at Old Trafford but has ruled Robin van Persie out because he is not yet fit enough to play; Luke Shaw is also considered not match-fit. Van Gaal urged controlled aggression, noted City will be a stern challenge, and stressed the importance of winning to move up the table—potentially into third and almost certainly into the top four—and to avoid a Champions League qualifier. He watched his players train in the sunshine (including Rooney, De Gea, Di Maria, Falcao, Mata, Rojo, Herrera, Valencia and others), praised United fans’ support, and said he hopes the team has learned from their earlier 1-0 loss to City.

Arsenal and Liverpool supporters staged a joint protest at the Emirates by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of a sold-out lunchtime Premier League match to highlight rising ticket prices after the Premier League’s £5.14bn TV rights deal; with the cheapest tickets for the 12:45 kickoff at £64, fans displayed banners reading messages such as “£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket” and “football without fans is nothing,” organized by Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement with Liverpool’s Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906, denouncing “extortionate” prices, fixture changes and kick-off times, calling for ticket reductions to reflect working-class incomes and warning the game risks losing a generation of supporters, with further protests expected after full-time.

A newborn in Barnsley, West Yorkshire, named Star was diagnosed within days of birth with biliary atresia after persistent jaundice and pale stools; an attempted operation to unblock her bile ducts failed and doctors said a liver transplant was necessary. Neither parent was a suitable donor, but the baby’s maternal aunt, Shanell Reader — the twin sister of Star’s mother, Jade Reader — donated part of her liver in November, saving Star’s life. Star spent six weeks in hospital, has since made a good recovery, will require lifelong anti-rejection medication and regular blood and liver function tests, and both baby and donor recovered well after the operation. Biliary atresia, affecting about 1 in 16,000 births, involves blocked or absent bile ducts and can lead to liver failure if untreated; the Kasai procedure is a common early surgical treatment.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Aké beat teammates Loïc Rémy and Willian in an Audi-sponsored football challenge consisting of rounds like firing balls into a car boot, sinking shots into convertible Audis from long range, and playing over an Audi R8 V10 Plus used as a tennis net; Hazard and Aké won the first two rounds 5-3 and then 6-0 on the decider, but Rémy and Willian won the final long-range shooting game, during which Willian accidentally smashed an Audi’s wing mirror while celebrating being allowed to drive one of the cars.

Former Fortune 500 executive Robert Dellinger, 54, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and an assault count for causing a December 7, 2013 highway crash in Lebanon, New Hampshire, that killed 24-year-old Amanda Murphy (eight months pregnant), her fiancé 29-year-old Jason Timmons, and their unborn child; prosecutors say Dellinger told investigators he was trying to kill himself after arguing with his wife about medications and driving across the median at over 100 mph, causing his truck to sheared the top off their SUV and produce plane-crash–like injuries, while his defense contends he suffered Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac effects and advanced multiple sclerosis; at sentencing Dellinger denied being suicidal, his wife Deborah described him as a man of ethics and they expressed devastation to the victims’ families, he faces 12–24 years in prison when sentencing resumes, and the couple’s family has filed a wrongful-death lawsuit.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son Garnett-Paul Spears with salt and was sentenced to 20 years to life, spared the 25-to-life maximum; prosecutors said she repeatedly made him ill to gain attention, subjecting him to repeated hospitalizations and unnecessary procedures while blogging about his illnesses, and the judge noted she suffers from a mental illness though the crime was called "unfathomable in its cruelty." Garnett’s father, Chris Hill, publicly lashed out on Facebook after the sentence, expressing anger and wishing harm on Spears; her lawyer plans to appeal, blaming hospital negligence and calling her a hardworking single mother, and Spears did not testify at trial.

Australia's influenza vaccine arrival is delayed by about a month because scientists updated it to include protection against two strains—influenza A (H3N2) and influenza B (B/Phuket)—after those strains caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the US when last season's vaccine did not match them. The modified vaccine also protects against influenza A (H1N1); world health authorities adjusted the formulation and Australia will use the same vaccine through the coming northern winter. Free, government-funded shots for high-risk groups (very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians) will be available from April 20; experts, including Dr Alan Hampson, urge everyone to get vaccinated now to help protect vulnerable people despite the stock delay.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln’s tomb in Springfield are defending the site after a critical National Geographic piece called its interior “all the historical character of an office lobby” and as looming state budget cuts threaten management; Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed folding the state historic preservation agency into another department amid a financial crisis, and lawmakers last year cut $1.1 million for Springfield-area sites, leading to reduced hours and staffing. Supporters say the criticism is unfair and point to more than $2.5 million in recent repairs and renovations — including $730,000 in interior and lighting upgrades and roughly $390,000 more for waterproofing, stone repairs and landscaping — leaving the tomb in “excellent physical condition.” The 1874 tomb, designed by Larkin Mead and redone in 1899 and 1930, is a circular obelisked structure with marble and bronze interiors and a family burial chamber bearing the inscription “now he belongs to the ages”; volunteers and visitors expressed concern over possible further cuts and disagreed with the magazine’s assessment.

The passage surveys revived nineties and noughties fashion trends that some think should stay in the past, prompted by JNCO’s planned comeback and other retro revivals; it lists nine specific items—bucket hats (worn then by Christina Aguilera, now by Rihanna), camouflage print (Destiny’s Child then, Jourdan Dunn now), maximalist styling/double denim (celebrity excess in the noughties, Kylie Jenner now), Ugg boots (Paris Hilton then, Kristen Bell now), very short “daisy duke” denim shorts (Jessica Simpson’s 2005 Dukes of Hazzard promotion, Miley Cyrus now), Juicy Couture velour tracksuits (Britney and other celebs then, Nicki Minaj now), coloured/mirrored sunglasses (NSYNC/Britney then, Cara Delevingne and Kylie Jenner now), corsets worn as outerwear (Victoria Beckham popularized the look, Selena Gomez wears corset-based gowns now), and harem trousers (Kim Kardashian championed them, Elle Macpherson wears them now).

CNN's weekly roundup highlighted viral stories: four rainbows appeared over the New York area after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis; rural China is cracking down on hiring exotic dancers for wakes; Robert Downey Jr. grew agitated during a UK Channel 4 interview about his private life; the Kardashian-inspired "Kylie Jenner challenge" involves lip plumping by sucking on a jar; filmmakers helped 102-year-old Alice Barker "go back in time"; a prom proposal referencing bombs sparked accusations of racism after a school objected; Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp looked nearly unrecognizable in the Black Mass trailer; someone announced a pregnancy with a Fresh Prince of Bel-Air reference; and a military dad photobombed his son's photo.

At the Miami Open, giant celebratory cakes have been common after milestones: Andy Murray received one for his 500th career win and Serena Williams for her 700th after she beat Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 to reach the semifinals; Williams, the world No.1, had sought a match with sister Venus but Venus lost to Carla Suarez Navarro, and Serena will face Simona Halep (who defeated Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5) for a place in the final — the match avenging Serena’s 2013 Wimbledon shock loss to Lisicki.

Sabeen Mahmud ran a colorful second-floor cafe called T2F in Karachi that hosted books, discussions on technology, human rights, women’s entrepreneurship and controversial topics; she was a prominent, outspoken advocate for free speech, secularism, humanism and tolerance who welcomed young Pakistanis seeking freedom of thought. After defying authorities by hosting a discussion on disappearances in Balochistan that had been shut down elsewhere, she and her mother were shot by two gunmen after locking up—Mahmud died of five bullet wounds and her mother was hospitalized but expected to be released for the funeral. No group claimed responsibility and police named no motive; Mahmud had previously received death threats. Her death provoked national grief and tributes on social media, and T2F—decorated with socially critical graffiti and art—was remembered as a brave, creative space that challenged Pakistan’s limits on open discussion.

The passage describes the plight of about 100,000 people classified as West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs)—mostly Hindus whose families fled to Jammu after the 1947 partition—who for nearly 70 years have been denied full state citizenship rights in Indian-administered Jammu and Kashmir: they cannot own land, vote in state elections, attend state-run training colleges, or work in the state government, leaving roughly 18,000 WPR families living in slums and multigenerational poverty despite being born and raised in India; this exclusion stems from a pre-independence law and political reluctance to alter the Muslim-majority state’s demographic balance, though the Bharatiya Janata Party’s recent entry into the state government has raised hopes it will press to normalize WPRs’ status, while activists warn they may resort to protest or violence if rights are not granted.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is weighing a possible summer move to Premier League leaders Chelsea after FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane said Chelsea had bid around £4 million; Chelsea would likely loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem, but the 22-year-old wants to join a team where he will play regularly and develop. Muto said he is taking time to consider the move, seeking a club that suits him, while former FC Tokyo boss Ranko Popovic praised Muto’s pace, strength, intelligence and confidence, predicting he could succeed at Stamford Bridge. Chelsea boss José Mourinho acknowledged knowing a little about Muto but declined to discuss him publicly, noting commercial and Financial Fair Play considerations affect transfers and that the club signs only players who are good players or good prospects.

The passage argues that Australia made the right decision to drop a policy barring selection of overseas-based players, and England should follow by allowing Stuart Lancaster to pick the best players regardless of where they play; examples cited include Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell at Toulon returning to Wallabies contention, Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon improving since moving to France, and Jonny Wilkinson becoming better after his move, while Toulon also fields internationals Bryan Habana and Leigh Halfpenny. It contends that home-world-cup England must select their best XV to avoid “what ifs,” that players improve, benefit and deserve selection irrespective of club location, and that RFU or Premiership constraints should not dictate national selection.

Open Garden, maker of the off‑grid chat app FireChat (downloaded over five million times), has developed Greenstone, an egg‑shaped beacon designed to strengthen wireless mesh networks that FireChat leverages via iOS 7’s Multipeer Connectivity Framework (and similar Android Bluetooth features). FireChat creates a local mesh in which phones act as nodes to pass messages (secure and anonymous, sent by app username) either to nearby users (Bluetooth/Wi‑Fi range ~30 ft/9 m) or to wider audiences by relaying between nodes (practical message range normally about 200 ft/61 m). Greenstone aims to bridge gaps in that range by storing messages (up to 1,000 recent) and holding them until another FireChat device comes in range; it currently works only with FireChat at about 20 ft (6 m), runs on a one‑year battery, and is intended for use in communities, events, hospitals or other places where resilient, offline communication is needed while Open Garden pursues manufacturing partnerships to bring it to market.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle, 5'3" and weighing 240 lbs, used a TED Talk to reclaim the word "fat" as an honest, body-positive descriptor alongside labels like "short" and "wife," arguing it needn't equal "ugly"; she cited rising size discrimination (66% increase in 30 years) and that girls 11–17 most desire to be thinner, but noted studies show exposure to body diversity increases tolerance and preference for different body types, which motivates her glamorous burlesque performances to challenge narrow beauty norms, empower herself (after starting in 2012) and offer a "courage reference" for insecurity; though some trolls left nasty comments, the 2014 talk recently posted on YouTube has nearly 38,000 views and mostly positive responses, including gratitude and stories from viewers, leading her to feel optimistic about body-positivity gaining ground.

Theo Walcott, 26, who has been frequently overlooked this season and named on Arsenal’s substitutes’ bench for 17 of 33 Premier League games, has been pictured sitting on a bench in a Lanvin photoshoot alongside teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini and Mesut Özil plus runway model Olga Sherer; Arsenal’s first-team will wear the same attire for the FA Cup final at Wembley on May 30. Walcott, who came on for the final six minutes of Arsenal’s 0-0 draw with Chelsea and was also pictured with Wojciech Szczesny, has not started since the 3-0 win over West Ham on March 14 and will hope to return to the starting lineup against Hull at the KC Stadium on Monday.

Legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker is auctioning 417 original props and puppets from his Cinovation Studio—spanning more than 50 productions—at a no-reserve live sale May 29 at the Hilton Universal City and online via PropStore; the collection is estimated at $746,100 and includes high-value lots such as an Alien Edgar bug (est. $40,000), a Mikey costume from Men in Black (est. $30,000), The Grinch costume from How the Grinch Stole Christmas (listed $8,000), various Men in Black pieces (including a Worm Guy at $10,000 and a hammerhead alien at $8,000), Batman Forever and Batman & Robin items (Two-Face mask $1,500, bat puppet $6,000, frozen thug “Frosty” $4,000), Gremlins 2 puppets (bat gremlin $8,000, mohawk Mogwai $8,000, Daffy gremlin $6,000), the Harry suit from Harry and the Hendersons ($6,000), the hero Joe head from Mighty Joe Young ($6,000), and a Michael Jackson robotic transformation face from Moonwalker ($3,000); Prop Store’s Brandon Alinger called the sale an exciting chance for collectors to own Baker’s creations from his 30-plus year career, which also includes work on An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Hellboy and others.

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell, described by family as "daring, outgoing and determined" with a "handsome smile," died after becoming separated from his mother while skiing with his family in Flaine in the French Alps; footprints in the snow led police to his body in dense woodland beneath a 164ft drop, with his final steps showing sliding marks where he appears to have descended on his backside. The Welsh boy, from Talybont-on-Usk, had been a competent skier and snowboarder who started skiing at three and admired Bear Grylls; he left the piste after his sister lost a ski and may have tried to reach the resort he could see through the trees. His family—who said the holiday had been their happiest—called his death a vast void in their hearts and paid tribute to his loving, lively nature; his school, community and friends expressed devastation, and police have prepared his body for repatriation.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed severe anorexia after trying to diet at nearly 13 stone and feeling pressured by bullying and cultural ideals of being a "size zero"; over two years she became obsessive about losing weight, hid food, lied to her mother, and at her worst ate about 100 calories or a single piece of fruit a day, causing her heart rate to slow and eventually collapsing and spending a week on a heart monitor in intensive care. After discharge she received support from eating disorder services (EDICT and CAMHS) and eating disorder charities were recommended as help; she has since improved her body image and reached the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a contest promoting confidence and steering away from size-zero stereotypes. The passage also defines anorexia nervosa as a serious mental health condition involving food restriction, purging, excessive exercise, obsessive behaviors, and notes that in 2015 about 725,000 people in the UK had an eating disorder, with 10% having anorexia.

Liverpool unveiled their 2015/16 home kit — a gingham design and the first for US sports brand New Balance under a record £300m four‑year deal — at Anfield, where players including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Škrtel, Simon Mignolet, Adam Lallana, Jordan Henderson and Philippe Coutinho modeled the strip to fans in the Centenary Stand; supporters loudly urged Sterling to stay after he had recently revealed rejecting a £100,000‑a‑week deal and being flattered by Arsenal links, while players spoke about the upcoming FA Cup semi‑final at Wembley, the kit features (white) New Balance branding and a tribute to the 96 Hillsborough victims, and legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush attended the launch.

Researchers at the University of Manchester released the largest single high-definition map of dark matter to date, covering about 0.4% of the sky (roughly 150 times the area of the full Moon) using two years of Dark Energy Survey (DES) data from the 570-megapixel Dark Energy Camera on the 4-m Blanco telescope at CTIO; the map, constructed from shape measurements of galaxies (130 million images) via gravitational lensing, reveals clumps, filaments and voids of dark matter and supports theories that galaxies form in regions of higher dark matter density, and is the first in a series that aims to produce a three-dimensional map of dark matter and dark energy over 12.5% of the sky by the end of DES, enabling studies of the clumpiness evolution of dark matter to probe dark energy.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven and Netherlands winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him an early summer signing; PSV confirmed contact from Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain and another big European club and say offers now would be for significantly more than Tottenham’s rejected £15m bid last summer. Depay has enjoyed a prolific season—20 goals in 26 league games—helping PSV win the Eredivisie, and impressed at the 2014 World Cup after Van Gaal included him in the squad. Born in 1994, Depay joined PSV at 12, debuted for the first team in 2011, signed professionally in 2012 and has over 100 appearances; known for pace, dribbling (most dribbles in 2013/14 Eredivisie), a strong right foot and cutting in from the left, he can still make occasional poor passes but is highly rated—PSV manager Phillip Cocu compares him to Arjen Robben in potential, and scout Ed van Steijn has likened his early ability favorably to a young Cristiano Ronaldo.

Chelsea beat Manchester City’s youth side 3-1 at the Academy Stadium, taking a 3-1 lead back to west London after Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half and Dominic Solanke added a late third; Abraham was substituted injured on 67 minutes. City had briefly equalised through Isaac Buckley-Ricketts but squandered chances from Aaron Nemane, Kean Bryan (who was injured after 36 minutes), Brandon Barker and Manu Garcia. Chelsea players praised included goalkeeper Bradley Collins, centre-backs Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, full-backs Ola Aina and Jay DaSilva, midfielders Charlie Colkett and Charly Musonda, and substitutes Kasey Palmer and Isaiah Brown; City performers mentioned were keeper Kjetil Haug, captain Tosin Adarabioyo, Cameron Humphreys-Grant, Pablo Maffeo, Jose Angelino, Bersant Celina, Ruben Sammut and others.

Marco Rubio, a Florida senator and presidential candidate, said on CBS's Face the Nation that while he believes people are largely born with their sexual preferences and would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer he cares about, he does not view same-sex marriage as a constitutional right and thinks marriage’s definition should remain one man and one woman, with state legislatures — not courts — deciding the issue; he also said, as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would still love someone who’d divorced, and his campaign has already secured donor commitments reportedly exceeding the $51 million needed for a competitive primary.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, quit restaurant jobs in Manchester to cycle the world cheaply, traveling open-endedly since leaving London; in 356 days they covered nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries and made over 225 stops, living on about €2.99 each per day (less than €3 each), chiefly spending €2.74 on food while camping 161 nights and using Couchsurfing and WarmShowers for many others; they keep costs down by free accommodation, cycling instead of paid transport, eating pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal produce, sometimes accepting meals or foraging/dumpster-diving, and carry heavy gear as they move from Western Europe through the Alps, the Balkans, Turkey, Georgia and Armenia with plans to continue across Asia, the Pacific and the Americas.

A Texas couple who wed in 2012 allege that Premiere Photos owner James Evans provided a photo booth that printed a racist slur ("poor n***** party") on the bottom of wedding snapshots; they say they only learned months later when the bride’s sister, who had kept quiet to avoid spoiling the wedding, told them. Represented by attorney Cathy Hale, the couple sued Evans under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract, saying Evans did nothing and refused to apologize—reportedly telling the groom "sue me"—while Evans denies the allegations, says there is no evidence linking his company to the caption at a 103-person party, and contends the couple showed no sign of mental anguish. Mediation is scheduled tomorrow with trial set for July if no agreement is reached; the couple says they chiefly want an apology rather than money.

England full-back Mike Brown said he will take a cautious, stage-by-stage approach to recovering from concussion after pulling out of Harlequins' Aviva Premiership clash with Saracens and being unsure when he'll return, having experienced headaches after the France game and previously being knocked out against Italy in the Six Nations; increased awareness from World Rugby online modules helped him recognise symptoms and avoid rushing back, citing examples of long lay-offs for other players like George North—who has been advised not to play again this season after four quick concussions and will see a neurosurgeon—and Johnny Sexton, who was stood down for 12 weeks; Brown, speaking at Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” campaign launch, said he would urge teammates not to play on if symptomatic and praised the value of concussion education.

A Cambridge statistician, Professor David Spiegelhalter, says smartphone and internet use may explain a long-term decline in how often Britons have sex: a typical heterosexual couple now averages three times a month versus four in 2000 and five in 1990, according to research in his book Sex by Numbers. He and others suggest increased solo living and, more plausibly, greater technological connectedness blurring work/home boundaries has made lives busier and squeezed out couple time; Catherine Mercer of the British National Survey adds that competing demands and checking work emails at night leave partners too connected to focus on each other.

Tibetan mastiffs, once status symbols in China with puppies fetching up to £1.2 million, have sharply fallen out of favor: anti-corruption measures ended their use as gifts to officials, city bans on dogs over 50 kg and rapid urbanization made them unsuitable for city life, and overbreeding produced many low-quality animals; as a result hundreds are reportedly being sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat and leather, stolen or abandoned, with rescuers finding 20 crammed in cages—many dead, starving or injured.

A poll of 600 women in the Paris area, compiled by the High Council for Gender Equality, found every woman surveyed reported experiencing sexual harassment on public transport, with half first harassed before age 18; harassment ranged from insults, persistent flirting, whistling and comments on appearance to sexual attacks or rape. As a result six in ten women feared attack on public transport (versus three in ten men), and many women alter routes, transport modes, schedules, attitudes and clothing to avoid confrontation, effectively excluding them from public spaces. The council called for campaigns to curb sexist and threatening behaviour, stressing that some victims are unaware they have been conditioned to accept low-level abuse, that attackers feel they can act with impunity in crowds, and that women should be informed that actions like groping constitute sexual assault punishable by up to five years' imprisonment and a €75,005 fine.

Leeds-based Direct Line ran the #everydayfix design makeathon with Makerversity to solve common “everyday emergencies” identified in a survey of 2,000 people (top concerns: not being able to sleep 46%, losing keys 37%, being stuck in traffic 35%, losing important documents 33%, nowhere to park 32%, printer failure 31%, phone battery dying 31%, discovering no toilet roll 30%, machine customer service 26%, forgetting a bank card 25%). Three prototype products were shortlisted: Snooze (an alarm clock by Instruments that links to your phone and silences notifications to improve sleep), Forget Me Lock (by Onn Studio — a key-mounted device that swivels green when the door is open and red when locked so you can check remotely), and Nipper (by Impulse — a tiny mobile charger that uses any household battery via two terminals to boost your phone). Direct Line is running a Twitter vote (retweets with #everydayfix) through 46 April to choose which prototype will enter a Kickstarter campaign for production; other rejected ideas included a bone‑conduction “hat nav” helmet, a parking pin that alerts you when a space frees up, and the Relay app to forward messages when your phone dies.

Vera Baird, Northumbria’s police and crime commissioner and a director of the charity Victims First Northumbria, is under a Ministry of Justice investigation after allocating more than £500,000 of public funds to that charity, whose top table also includes Northumbria chief constable Sue Sim; critics, including MP Keith Vaz, call the award inappropriate and a conflict of interest and say PCCs should not have the power to allocate such funding, while Baird says MoJ procedures were followed and defenders argue the charity was created after contacts with predecessor Victim Support fell and that coordinators will justify the decisions; Sim, who has faced prior bullying allegations and misconduct proceedings and will retire in June, was praised by Baird for her service.

Three people pleaded guilty and have been sentenced or await sentencing after abducting, torturing and tattooing 53-year-old Greg Valecce in a Mayfair rowhouse basement in late March 2014; ringleader Corry “Corey” Campbell, 21, believing Valecce had hurt his cat Pebbles and stolen money and weed, led a roughly 42-hour attack in which Valecce was punched, tied to a chair, repeatedly tattooed with obscene and hateful images and slurs, and suffered three busted ribs, two broken wrists and facial fractures before escaping on April 1 to contact police. Campbell and accomplice Carl Halin, 18, were each sentenced to 20 years; Sandra Ng, 19, Campbell’s girlfriend, received 23 months; David Thomas, 28, is awaiting sentencing and Jennifer Pratt, 40, is awaiting trial. Police found tattoo equipment, needles, ink, 155 g of marijuana, prescription bottles and Valecce’s debit card in the house; Valecce has had the tattoos removed with pro bono help but says he suffers lasting psychological damage.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him an early signing after having included him in Holland’s 2014 World Cup squad; PSV’s technical director Marcel Brands confirmed contact from Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain and another big European club and said offers now would be for substantially more than the rejected £15m bid from Tottenham last summer. Depay has enjoyed a prolific season, scoring 20 league goals in 26 games as PSV won the Eredivisie, and is noted for pace, close control, dribbling (most dribbles in 2013/14), an explosive right foot and cutting in from the left, though he can sometimes make poor passes or hold the ball too long. Born in 1994, he progressed from local club VV Moordrecht to Sparta Rotterdam and joined PSV at 12, debuting in 2011, signing professionally in 2012 and making over 100 appearances; he starred for the Netherlands at the 2014 World Cup, scoring against Australia and Chile and earning a Best Young Player nomination, and has drawn high praise comparing his potential to players like Arjen Robben and, at the same age, a young Cristiano Ronaldo.

Chelsea beat Manchester City’s youth side 3-1 at the Academy Stadium, taking a commanding first-leg lead back to West London after Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half and Dominic Solanke added a late third. Chelsea’s side featured strong defensive displays from Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, an influential right-back performance from Ola Aina, midfield control from captain Charlie Colkett, and lively but quieter contributions from Charly Musonda and Isaiah Brown; Abraham was substituted injured on 67 minutes and Kasey Palmer came on. City’s young team saw Isaac Buckley-Ricketts briefly level the game, with notable efforts from captain Tosin Adarabioyo, Cameron Humphreys-Grant, Brandon Barker, Manu Garcia, Aaron Nemane and Ruben Sammut, while goalkeeper Kjetil Haug looked shaky under high balls.

Marco Rubio, a Florida senator and recent presidential candidate, said on CBS’s Face the Nation that while he believes people are largely born with their sexual preferences and would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer he cared about, he does not view same-sex marriage as a constitutional right and thinks states — not courts — should decide marriage definitions, arguing the institution should be between one man and one woman; Rubio, a Catholic who also believes divorce is wrong but would still love someone who divorced, announced his presidential run last week and has reportedly received donor commitments toward an estimated $47 million primary war chest.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester and set off from London on an open-ended, low-budget cycling odyssey to "discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time." In 356 days they rode almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries, camping 161 of 256 nights and using hosts like Couchsurfing and WarmShowers for another 110 nights, keeping costs under €3 each per day (food €2.74) by eating staples, accepting invitations, foraging, and occasionally dumpster-diving. Their route covered France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey (entire northern coast), Georgia and Armenia, and they plan to continue into Asia, cross the Pacific and cycle the length of the Americas, traveling indefinitely with minimal gear and no fixed agenda.

England full-back Mike Brown said he will take a cautious, staged approach to returning from concussion after withdrawing from Harlequins’ Aviva Premiership match with Saracens; he experienced a headache after the France game and was previously knocked out versus Italy in February, and because of increased awareness from World Rugby online modules he pulled out of the England‑Ireland Six Nations match and will monitor symptoms through graded tests (e.g., 20‑minute bike) rather than rush back. The piece notes other concussion cases — Northampton’s George North has been advised not to play again this season after four quick successive concussions and will see a neurosurgeon, and Ireland’s Johnny Sexton was stood down for 12 weeks — and Brown, speaking at Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” campaign launch, urged honesty about symptoms and warned against pushing through head injuries to avoid long‑term harm.

A Cambridge statistician, Professor David Spiegelhalter, suggests smartphone and internet use may explain a long-term decline in how often Britons have sex: his book Sex by Numbers reports a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Spiegelhalter and cited researchers point to more solo living and, more plausibly, increased technological connectivity blurring home and work life, making people busier and checking emails late into the evening so sex becomes a lower priority and partners remain too connected to focus on each other.

Tibetan mastiffs, once status symbols in China that could fetch up to £1.2 million, have plunged in popularity and many are now being sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat and leather; rescuers found 20 crammed mastiffs en route to an abattoir (one third dead, several injured, none fed or watered for three days). The collapse is blamed on China’s anti-corruption crackdown that ended gift-giving to officials, bans in several cities on dogs over 50 kg, urbanisation making the breed unsuitable for city life, and a market glut from cross-breeding and unscrupulous breeders or gangs stealing and selling dogs to slaughterhouses. Tibetan mastiffs can weigh up to 80 kg and were traditionally used in Tibet to herd animals.

Leeds-based insurer Direct Line ran the #everydayfix design makeathon with Makerversity to tackle common daily “emergencies” identified in a 2,000-person survey (top problems: not being able to sleep 46%, losing keys 37%, traffic 35%, losing documents 33%, parking 32%, printer 31%, phone battery 31%, no toilet roll 30%, automated customer service 26%, forgetting bank card 25%). Three shortlisted prototypes face a Twitter vote to win Kickstarter funding: Snooze (by Instruments), an alarm clock that connects to your phone and silences notifications to improve sleep; Forget Me Lock (by ONN Studio), a key-attached swivel indicator that shows green when the door is open and red when locked so you can check remotely; and Nipper (by Impulse), touted as the world’s smallest mobile charger that clips to any household battery to boost phone power. Other concepts that weren’t shortlisted included a bone-conduction “Hat Nav” helmet for cyclists, a parking pin that alerts you when a space frees up, and Relay, an app that forwards your messages when your phone dies.
